text: Thaepa "1" ho ya ho "9" haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka leqheka le itseng.

SourceText: Remember that you’re in charge of what they eat, but not how much. Newborns have stomach the size of a grape! They need to eat often (sometimes in the middle of the night.
text: Hopola hore o ikarabella ka seo a se jang, eseng hore na o ja hakae. Masea a qetang ho hlaha a na le mala a lekanang le morara! A tlameha ho ja kgafetsa (ka dinako tse ding hara mpa ya bosiu).

SourceText: It’s important to build trust around eating, especially as your baby starts on solid food. Let them know you are listening to their wishes in the eating department. They’ll be ravenous again soon!
text: Ho bohlokwa ho etsa hore le tshepane tabeng ya dijo, haholoholo ha lesea la hao le qala ho ja dijo tse tiileng. Mo tsebise hore o mametse ha a bua ka seo a lakatsang ho se ja. Haufinyane o tla boela a ja sampana-phatloha!

SourceText: Would you like suggestions for active and calm things to do with @fields.child_nickname?
text: Na o ka thabela ditshisinyo tsa dintho tseo o ka di etsang le @fields.child_nickname tse hlokang ho ba mahlahahlaha le ho kgutsa?
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: When your children ask you about COVID-19, be willing to talk. They will already have heard something. Silence and secrets do not protect our children. Honesty and openness do. Think about how much they will understand. You know them best.
text: Ha bana ba hao ba o botsa dipotso tse amanang le COVID-19, ikemisetse ho bua. Ba tla be ba se ba utlwile ntho e nngwe. Ho thola le makunutu ha di sireletse bana ba rona. Empa ba sireletswa ke botshepehi le ho ba phetlela sefuba. Nahana hore na ba ka utlwisisa dintlha tse kae. Ke wena ya ba tsebang hantle.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you talk about COVID-19 with your children!
text: Shebella video ena ho o thusa ho bua le bana ba hao ka COVID-19!

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you talk about COVID-19 with your children!
text: Mamela molaetsa ona o mamelwang ho o thusa ho bua le bana ba hao ka COVID-19!

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about how to talk about COVID-19 with your child. Chat to you later!
text: O ska kgathatseha! Ka dinako tsohle o ka thaepa “Thuso” haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka tsela ya ho buisana le ngwana wa hao ka COVID-19. Ke tla bua le wena hamorao!

SourceText: Here are 4 simple steps that you can do when talking about COVID-19 with your children:
text: Bona mehato ena e bonolo e 4 eo o ka e etsang ha o buisana le bana ba hao ka COVID-19:

SourceText: 1. Be open, honest, and supportive
text: 1. Ba phetlele sefuba, bua ka botshepehi mme o ba tshehetse

SourceText: 2. It is okay not to know the answers
text: 2. O ska kgathatseha ha o sa tsebe dikarabo

SourceText: 3. Be a hero not a bully
text: 3. Eba mohale eseng mpodi

SourceText: 4. End on a good note
text: 4. Moqoqo o felle hamonate

SourceText: Type "1" to "4" to learn more about each tip. Type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Thaepa “1” ho ya ho “4” hore o ithute haholwanyane ka keletso ka nngwe. Thaepa “N” ho emisa keletso ena.

SourceText: Step 3. Be a hero not a bully
text: Mohato wa 3. Eba mohale eseng mpodi

SourceText: Explain that COVID-19 has nothing to do with the way someone looks, where they are from, or what language they speak.
text: Hlalosa hore COVID-19 ha e amane ho hang le tsela eo motho a shebahalang ka yona, moo a tswang teng, kapa puo eo a e buang.

SourceText: Here is a comic on how to talk to your child about COVID-19.
text: Ena ke tsela ya boswaswi ya ho buisana le ngwana wa hao ka COVID-19.

SourceText: Child: “Am I going to get coronavirus?”
text: Ngwana: “Na ke tlo tshwarwa ke corona?”

SourceText: Parent: “It is very possible that we will all get coronavirus. But younger people do not normally get very sick.”
text: Motswadi: “Ke ntho e ka kgonehang hore kaofela re tshwarwe ke corona. Empa hangata batjha ha e ba kudise haholo.”

SourceText: Child: “I am scared…”
text: Ngwana: “Ke tshohile...”

SourceText: Parent: “It is okay to be afraid. We are all a bit scared about this. But we have each other and can do our best to keep ourselves and other people safe and healthy.”
text: Motswadi: “Hase phoso ho tshoha. Kaofela ha rona e a re tshosa. Empa re tla thusana le ho etsa sohle seo re ka se kgonang ho itshireletsa le ho sireletsa batho ba bang le ho dula re phetse hantle.”

SourceText: Child: “How can we keep safe?”
text: Ngwana: “Re ka itshireletsa jwang?”

SourceText: Parent: “We can wash our hands regularly for 20 seconds. We can also keep a good physical distance away from people. We also need to try to avoid touching our faces as much as possible.”
text: Motswadi: “Ka hore re hlape matsoho kgafetsa ka metsotswana e ka bang 20. Hape re se ke ra atamellana haholo le batho ba bang. Ebile re tlameha ho leka ka hore re se ke ra itshwara sefahlehong.”

SourceText: Child, “Okay…”
text: Ngwana, “Ok...”

SourceText: Child: “What happens to your body when you get coronavirus?”
text: Ngwana: “Ho etsahalang ka mmele wa hao ha o tshwarwa ke corona?”

SourceText: Parent: “To tell you the truth, I don’t know exactly. How about we look on the UNICEF website together?”
text: Motswadi: “E re ke o bolelle nnete feela, ha ke tsebe hantle. Ho ka ba jwang re ke re shebe webosaete ya UNICEF mmoho?”

SourceText: WHO: https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public
text: WHO: https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public

SourceText: UNICEF: https://www.unicef.org/coronavirus/covid-19
text: UNICEF: https://www.unicef.org/coronavirus/covid-19

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to talk about COVID-19 with your children:
text: Ka kopo kgetha palo e nngwe haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka tsela ya ho buisana le ngwana wa hao ka COVID-19:

SourceText: Step 1. Be open, honest, and supportive
text: Mohato wa 1. Ba phetlele sefuba, bua ka botshepehi mme o ba tshehetse

SourceText: Allow @fields.child_nickname to talk freely. Ask them open questions and find out how much they already know.
text: Tlohella @fields.child_nickname a bue a lokolohile. Ebe o mo botsa dipotso le ho utlwa hore na o se a ntse a tseba hakae.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Allow your child to talk freely. Ask them open questions and find out how much they already know.
text: Tlohella ngwana wa hao a bue a lokolohile. Ebe o mo botsa dipotso le ho utlwa hore na o se a ntse a tseba hakae.

SourceText: Always answer their questions truthfully. Think about how old @fields.child_nickname is and how much they can understand.
text: Ka dinako tsohle araba dipotso tsa hae ka nnete. Nahana hore na @fields.child_nickname o dilemo di kae le hore na a ka kgona ho utlwisisa dintlha tse kae.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: @fields.child_nickname may be scared or confused. Give them space to share how they are feeling and let them know you are there for them.
text: Mohlomong @fields.child_nickname o tshohile kapa o ferekane. Mo fe monyetla wa ho ntsha maikutlo a hae mme o mo kgodise hore o tla wa o tsoha le yena.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Always answer their questions truthfully. Think about how old your child is and how much they can understand.
text: Ka dinako tsohle araba dipotso tsa hae ka nnete. Nahana hore na ngwana wa hao o dilemo di kae le hore na a ka kgona ho utlwisisa dintlha tse kae.

SourceText: Your child may be scared or confused. Give them space to share how they are feeling and let them know you are there for them.
text: Mohlomong ngwana wa hao o tshohile kapa o ferekane. Mo fe monyetla wa ho ntsha maikutlo a hae mme o mo kgodise hore o tla wa o tsoha le yena.

SourceText: Step 4. End on a good note
text: Mohato wa 4. Moqoqo o felle hamonate

SourceText: Check to see if @fields.child_nickname is okay. Remind them that you care and that they can talk to you anytime. Then do something fun together!
text: Utlwa hore na @fields.child_nickname o ntse a ya hantle. Mo hopotse hore o a mo tsotella le hore a ka bua le wena neng kapa neng. Ebe le etsa ho hong ho monate mmoho.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Check to see if your child is okay. Remind them that you care and that they can talk to you anytime. Then do something fun together!
text: Utlwa hore na ngwana wa hao o ntse a ya hantle. Mo hopotse hore o a mo tsotella le hore a ka bua le wena neng kapa neng. Ebe le etsa ho hong ho monate mmoho.

SourceText: Step 2. It is OK not to know the answers.
text: Mohato wa 2. O ska kgathatseha ha o sa tsebe dikarabo.

SourceText: It is fine to say “We don’t know, but we are working on it; or we don’t know, ‘but we think’.”  Use this as an opportunity to learn something new with @fields.child_nickname. The WHO and UNICEF websites are great first steps to learn.
text: Hase phoso ho re “Ha re tsebe, empa re ntse re sebetsana le taba eo; kapa ha re tsebe, ‘empa re nahana’.”  Nka monyetla ona ho ithuta ntho e nngwe e ntjha le @fields.child_nickname. Diwebosaete tsa WHO le UNICEF di tshwere dintlha tsa bohlokwa tseo le ka qalang ho ithuta tsona.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: It is fine to say “We don’t know, but we are working on it; or we don’t know, ‘but we think’.”  Use this as an opportunity to learn something new with your child. The WHO and UNICEF websites are great first steps to learn.
text: Hase phoso ho re “Ha re tsebe, empa re ntse re sebetsana le taba eo; kapa ha re tsebe, ‘empa re nahana’.”  Nka monyetla ona ho ithuta ntho e nngwe e ntjha le ngwana wa hao. Diwebosaete tsa WHO le UNICEF di tshwere dintlha tsa bohlokwa tseo le ka qalang ho ithuta tsona.

SourceText: Tell @fields.child_nickname that we can be compassionate to people who are sick and those who are caring for them.
text: Bolella @fields.child_nickname hore re lokela ho qnehela batho ba kulang le ba ba hlokomelang.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Tell your child that we can be compassionate to people who are sick and those who are caring for them.
text: Bolella ngwana wa ha hore re lokela ho qnehela batho ba kulang le ba ba hlokomelang.

SourceText: Well done for adding another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Over the next few days, try to talk about COVID-19 with your child in a supportive way. It will make them feel loved and safe. You are the hero of this story!
text: O sebeditse ka ho eketsa boiphihlelo bo bong Mokotleng wa hao wa Dithulusi tsa Botswadi! Matsatsing a seng makae a tlang, leka ho buisana le ngwana wa hao ka COVID-19 ka tsela e mo tshehetsang. Seo se tla etsa hore a ikutlwe a ratwa ebile a sireletsehile. Ke wena mohale paleng ena!

SourceText: Well done for adding another layer to your House of Support! Over the next few days, try to talk about COVID-19 with your child in a supportive way. It will make them feel loved and safe. You are the hero of this story!
text: O sebeditse ka ho eketsa mokato o mong Ntlong ya hao ya Tshehetso! Matsatsing a seng makae a tlang, leka ho buisana le ngwana wa hao ka COVID-19 ka tsela e mo tshehetsang. Seo se tla etsa hore a ikutlwe a ratwa ebile a sireletsehile. Ke wena mohale paleng ena!

SourceText: I understand that these times can be really difficult.  Please type "Help" if you want any extra support or guidance. Chat to you later!
text: Kea utlwisisa hore kannete ho ka ba thata dinakong tsena.  Ka kopo thaepa “Thuso” haeba o batla thuso kapa tataiso efe kapa efe e eketsehileng. Ke tla bua le wena hamorao!

SourceText: Sometimes we feel frustrated with our children because we expect them to behave in ways that they are not yet developmentally ready for.
text: Ka dinako tse ding re nka hore bana ba rona ba re swetsitse hobane re lebeletse hore ba itshware ka ditsela tse itseng empa ba eso hole ka ho lekaneng hore ba ka itshwara jwalo.

SourceText: Learning about child development means we can have realistic expectations and also to spot any problems with their growth and development.
text: Ho ithuta ka kgolo ya ngwana ho bolela hore re ka ba le ditebello tse utlwahalang le ho lemoha mathata afe kapa afe ka kgolo le ho hola ha ngwana.

SourceText: All children develop at different rates. Here's a video to help you understand what to expect from your children.
text: Bana bohle ba hola ka sekgahla se sa tshwaneng. Shebella video ena ho o thusa ho utlwisisa seo o ka se lebellang ho bana ba hao.

SourceText: All children develop at different rates. Here's an audio message to help you understand what to expect from your children.
text: Bana bohle ba hola ka sekgahla se sa tshwaneng. Mamela molaetsa ona o mamelwang ho o thusa ho utlwisisa seo o ka se lebellang ho bana ba hao.

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about child development.
text: O ska kgathatseha! Ka dinako tsohle o ka thaepa “Thuso” haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka kgolo ya ngwana wa hao.

SourceText: All children develop at different rates. But there are some things that we expect children to be able to do at an age. These are called ‘development’ milestones.
text: Bana bohle ba hola ka sekgahla se sa tshwaneng. Empa ho na le dintho tse itseng tseo re lebellang hore bana ba kgone ho di etsa ha ba le dilemo tse itseng. Tsena ke dinako tsa bohlokwa ‘kgolong’.

SourceText: Many things affect our children's development. For example, development is helped by eating healthy food, having immunisations, and parents or caregivers who talk to them a lot.
text: Dintho tse ngata di ama kgolo ya bana ba hao. Ka mohlala, kgolo e ntshetswa pele ke ho ja dijo tse nang le phepo, ho entelwa mafu le batswadi kapa bahlokomedi ba buang le bona haholo.

SourceText: Which child development milestones do you want to learn about?
text: Ke dinako dife tsa bohlokwa kgolong ya ngwana tseo o ka ratang ho ithuta ka tsona?

SourceText: Sorry I don't understand what you mean.
text: Ke maswabi ha ke utlwisise hore na o bolelang.

SourceText: Young children have similar needs as toddlers.  Here's an audio message to help you understand your child's developmental needs better.
text: Bana ba banyane ba na le ditlhoko tse tshwanang le tsa bana ba seng ba tseba ho tsamaya.  Mamela molaetsa ona o mamelwang ho o thusa ho utlwisisa kgolo ya ngwana wa hao ka tsela e betere.

SourceText: Babies from 0 to 1 year need lots of play and attention. Here's a video to help you understand your child's developmental needs better.
text: Masea a nang le selemo se 0 ho ya ho 1 ba hloka ho bapala haholo le ho behwa leihlo. Shebella video ho o thusa ho utlwisisa kgolo ya ngwana wa hao ka tsela e betere.

SourceText: Babies from 0 to 1 year need lots of play and attention. Here's an audio message to help you understand your child's developmental needs better.
text: Masea a nang le selemo se 0 ho ya ho 1 ba hloka ho bapala haholo le ho behwa leihlo. Mamela molaetsa ona o mamelwang ho o thusa ho utlwisisa kgolo ya ngwana wa hao ka tsela e betere.

SourceText: Young children have similar needs as toddlers.  Here's a video to help you understand your child's developmental needs better.
text: Bana ba banyane ba na le ditlhoko tse tshwanang le tsa bana ba seng ba tseba ho tsamaya.  Shebella video ho o thusa ho utlwisisa kgolo ya ngwana wa hao ka tsela e betere.

SourceText: Young children (4-6 years):
text: Bana ba banyane (dilemo tse 4-6):

SourceText: • Same as toddlers, but also...
text: • Ba tshwana le bana ba seng ba tseba ho tsamaya, empa hape...

SourceText: • Learn through actions and play.
text: • Ba ithuta ka diketso le papadi.

SourceText: • Develop friendships with other children
text: • Ba qala setswalle le bana ba bang.

SourceText: • Find it difficult to separate make-believe from reality. Still express feelings in dramatic ways!
text: • Ba fumana ho le thata ho arola ditaba tsa bobare ho tsa nnete. Ba ntse ba ntsha maikutlo a bona ka ditsela tse matla!

SourceText: Young teenagers (10-12 years)
text: Batjha ba banyane (dilemo tse 10-12)

SourceText: • More interested in learning in school.
text: • Ba thahasella ho ithutela sekolong.

SourceText: • Start to want independence and trust.
text: • Ba qala ho batla bolokolohi le ho tshepuwa.

SourceText: • Want to spend time with other children and young teenagers.
text: • Ba batla ho qeta nako le bana ba bang le batjha ba banyane.

SourceText: • May be interested in religion or spirituality
text: • Ba ka nna ba thahasella bodumedi le borapedi

SourceText: • May answer back to adults to show that they “know”.
text: • Ba ka nna ba arabisa batho ba baholo ho bontsha hore ba a “tseba”.

SourceText: • Can be very self-conscious and sensitive
text: • Ba ka ba hlokolosi haholo ka boemo ba hae le ho kgopiseha le feela

SourceText: • Can learn to better manage anger and tolerate frustration.
text: • Ba ka ithuta ho laola bohale le ho mamella ho swetseha.

SourceText: Infant (0–1 year) needs:
text: Ditlhoko tsa masea (dilemo tse 0-1)

SourceText: • Us to provide food, sleep, cleaning, comfort and safety.
text: • Ke rona ba lokelang ho mo fa dijo, ho mo robatsa, ho mo hlwekisa, ho mo tshedisa le ho mo sireletsa.

SourceText: • A strong bond with parent/ caregiver.
text: • Kamano e matla le motswadi/ mohlokomedi.

SourceText: • Lots of play and attention - the most active time of brain development is during the first 1000 days of life!
text: • A bapala haholo ebile a batla tlhokomelo e ngata - nako eo boko bo holang ka potlako haholo ke matsatsing a qalang a 1000 a bophelo ba wona!

SourceText: Middle teenagers (13-14 years)
text: Batjha ba dilemo tse mahareng (dilemo tse 13-14)

SourceText: • Begin to challenge adult rules
text: • Ba qala ho phephetsa melao ya batho ba baholo

SourceText: • Are often insecure and confused.
text: • Hangata ba ikutlwa ba sa sireletseha ebile ba ferekane.

SourceText: • Feelings get hurt easily and have mood swings
text: • Ba kgopiseha lefeela ebile ba dula ba halefa

SourceText: • Try to be the boss and are unhappy if they lose.
text: • Ba leka ho ba dinkwapo ebile baa halefa ha ba hlotswe.

SourceText: Infants (0-1):
text: Masea (0-1):

SourceText: • 0–6 months: Smile, babble and cry to attract your attention. We should provide care, cuddling and protection.
text: • A dikgwedi di 0–6: Aa bososela, ba mahlahahlaha mme a lla hore o a hlokomele. Re tlameha ho ba hlokomela, ho ba kuka le ho ba sireletsa.

SourceText: • 6–11 months: Cling to you, especially when feeling insecure or frightened.
text: • A dikgwedi di 6–11: Aa o kgomarela, haholoholo ha a ikutlwa a sa sireletseha kapa a tshohile.

SourceText: • 12–23 months: Start to walk, talk and explore things around them!
text: • A dikgwedi di 12–23: A qala ho tsamaya, ho bua le ho ithuta dintho tse haufi le wona!

SourceText: • Their friends are important and affect their choices
text: • Metswalle e bohlokwa mme e ama dikgetho tsa bona

SourceText: • Need some freedom but also reliable rules that don't change
text: • Ba hloka bolokolohi bo itseng le melao e tsitsitseng e sa fetoheng

SourceText: • Need affection, reassurance, self-esteem, encouragement to believe in their abilities
text: • Ba hloka lerato, ho kgodiswa, boitshepo, kgothatso ho tshepa bokgoni ba bona

SourceText: Toddlers (2-3 years):
text: Bana ba ithutang ho tsamaya (dilemo tse 2-3).

SourceText: • Become a curious little explorer - watch out for climbing!
text: • Mofuputsi e monyane ya bohelehele - mo hlokomele a ka hlwa dintho!

SourceText: • Learn through play and trying things out
text: • Ba ithuta ka ho bapala le ka leka dintho tse ntjha

SourceText: • Want to learn how to do new things (like getting dressed) and make their own decisions.
text: • Ba batla ho ithuta tsela ya ho etsa dintho tse ntjha (jwaloka ho ikapesa) le ho iketsetsa diqeto.

SourceText: • Want your praise and your approval
text: • Ba batla pabatso le kamohelo

SourceText: • May talk a lot; ask many questions. We should be honest when we reply! Our child may ask again if they don't understand or want to know more
text: • Ba ka nna ba bua haholo; ba botsa dipotso tse ngata. Re tlameha ho araba ka botshepehi! Bana ba rona ba ka nna ba re botsa ntho e itseng hape ha ba sa utlwisise kapa ba batla ho tseba haholwanyane

SourceText: • Does not like to lose, share or take turns, but losing and taking turns can be taught.
text: • Ha ba rate ho lahlehelwa, ho kopanela dintho kapa ho tjhentjha, empa ba ka ithuta ho amohela ho lahlehelwa le ho tjhentjhana.

SourceText: Older teenagers (15–19 years)
text: Batjha ba baholwanyane (dilemo tse 15–19)

SourceText: • The teen years are the second most active time of brain development!
text: • Dilemo tsa botjha ke nako e nngwe eo boko bo holang ka lebelo le leholo!

SourceText: • Your child is almost an adult, they are able to communicate with you about
text: • Ngwana wa hao o atamela dilemo tsa motho e moholo, mme a ka bua le wena

SourceText: almost anything.
text: hoo ekabang ka eng kapa eng.

SourceText: • They can think about new ideas, develop their own ideals and set their own course.
text: • A ka nahana dikgopolo tse ntjha, a tla menahano ya hae ya se lokileng mme a ikgethela tsela ya hae.

SourceText: • Start speaking in sentences and  learning new words.
text: • A qala ho bua dipolelo le ho ithuta mantswe a matjha.

SourceText: • Does not like to lose or take turns, but sharing can be taught.
text: • Ha a rate ho lahlehelwa kapa ho tjhentjhana, empa a ka ithuta ho kopanela dintho le batho ba bang.

SourceText: • May express feelings in dramatic ways (like screaming on the floor!). Can start to learn how to manage their feelings.
text: • A ka nna a ntsha maikutlo a hae ka ditsela tse matla (jwaloka tleroha le ho lahlela dintho fatshe!). A ka qala ho ithuta ho laola maikutlo a hae.

SourceText: Older children (7-9 years)
text: Bana ba baholwanyane (dilemo tse 7-9):

SourceText: • Same early childhood, but also…
text: • Ba tshwana le bongwaneng ha motho a le tlaase, empa ba boetse…

SourceText: • Interested in learning at school.
text: • Ba thahasella ho ithutela sekolong.

SourceText: • Starts to want independence and trust.
text: • Ba qala ho batla bolokolohi le ho tshepuwa.

SourceText: • Wants to spend time with other children.
text: • Ba batla ho qeta nako le bana ba bang.

SourceText: • They are forming their own identity and have a growing sense of their
text: • Ba qala ho hlahisa hore na ke bomang mme ba qala ho bontsha tshekamelo ya bona

SourceText: sexuality
text: ya tsa thobalano

SourceText: • They may prefer being with peers more than with you
text: • Ba ka nna ba thabela ho ba le dithaka tsa bona ho feta ho ba le wena

SourceText: • They may show risk-taking behaviours, frequent mood swings, and rebellious
text: • Ba ka nna ba bontsha boitshwaro ba ho leka dintho tse kotsi, ho fetofetoha ha maikutlo le mekgwa

SourceText: attitudes. They can also have exciting new ideas!
text: ya borabele. Hape ba ka ba le menahano e metjha e ba thabisang!

SourceText: • May start to ask questions about religion
text: • Ba ka nna ba qala ho botsa dipotso ka bodumedi

SourceText: • Can be very self-conscious and sensitive. May be very active. By now they should be getting better at managing anger and frustration.
text: • Ba ka ba hlokolosi haholo ka boemo ba hae le ho kgopiseha le feela. Ba ka ba mahlahahlaha haholo. Jwale e lokela ebe ba ba betere tabeng ya ho laola bohale le ho swetseha.

SourceText: • Be patient and accepting of the person they are becoming - even if it is not what you had imagined
text: • Eba le mamello mme o amohele motho eo ebang yena - esita leha ese seo o neng o se nahanne

SourceText: • Encourage them to begin to take responsibility for the future
text: • Mo kgothalletse ho qala ho jara boikarabelo nakong e tlang

SourceText: • Keep supporting them and loving them so that they feel comfortable, secure, and safe
text: • Tswela pele ho mo kgothatsa le ho mo bontsha lerato e le hore a ikutlwe a phutholohile, a sireletsehile ebile bolokehile

SourceText: If you are concerned that your child might be delayed in their development, here is a link to services in your area that may also be helpful: [INSERT LOCAL LINK]

SourceText: You can also visit UNICEF's website for more helpful information about child development [INSERT LOCAL UNICEF LINK]
text: Hape o ka kena webosaeteng ya UNICEF hore o fumana dintlha tse eketsehile tse molemo tse amanang le kgolo ya ngwana [INSERT LOCAL UNICEF LINK]

text: • Ho tswela pele o mo bontsha lerato, ho mo tshehetsa le ho mo tataisa le ho haha

SourceText: • Monitor who their friends are, have clear rules to keep them safe

SourceText: All children, including those living with disabilities, need love, respect and time especially at difficult times.
text: Bana bohle, ho kopanyelletsa le ba holofetseng, ba hloka lerato, tlhompho le nako haholoholo dinakong tse thata.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you support children living with disabilities.
text: Shebella video ena e ka o thusang ho tshehetsa bana ba holofetseng.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you support children living with disabilities.
text: Mamela molaetsa ona o mamelwang o ka o thusang ho tshehetsa bana ba holofetseng.

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about how to support children living with disabilities.
text: O ska kgathatseha! Ka dinako tsohle o ka thaepa “Thuso” haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka tsela ya ho tshehetsa bana ba holofetseng.

SourceText: Here are 6 simple tips that you can do to support children living with disabilities:
text: Bona dikeletso tsena tse bonolo tse 6 tsa seo o ka se etsang ho tshehetsa bana ba holofetseng:

SourceText: 1. Keep your child safe and well
text: 1. Tiisa hore bana ba hao ba sireletsehile ebile ba ya hantle

SourceText: 2. Try to understand what they are feeling
text: 2. Leka ho utlwisisa tsela eo ba ikutlwang ka yona

SourceText: 3. Communicate and talk with them
text: 3. Buisana le ho qoqa le bona

SourceText: 4. Praise them!
text: 4. Ba babatse!

SourceText: 5. Make things that you do the same every day to help them feel secure
text: 5. Tiisa hore o etsa se tshwanang letsatsi le letsatsi ho ba thusa ho ikutlwa ba sireletsehile

SourceText: 6. Ask for help if you can
text: 6. Kopa thuso haeba o sa kgone

SourceText: Type "1" to "6" to learn more about each tip. Type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Thaepa “1” ho ya ho “6” hore o ithute haholwanyane ka keletso ka nngwe. Thaepa “N” ho emisa keletso ena.

SourceText: Step 4. Praise them!
text: Mohato wa 4. Ba babatse!

SourceText: • Praise them for behaving well, and for trying.
text: • Ba babatse ha ba itshwere hantle, le ha ba entse boiteko.

SourceText: • Focus on what they can do, not what they can't.
text: • Ameha ka seo ba ka se etsang, eseng seo ba ke keng ba kgona ho se etsa.

SourceText: • Only help children when they need it. It is also good to build independence!
text: • Ba thuse feela ha ba hloka thuso. Hape ke hantle ho ba ruta ho ikemela!

SourceText: Step 6. Ask for help if you can
text: Mohato wa 6. Kopa thuso haeba o sa kgone

SourceText: • Share the load with other adult family members.
text: • Kopa ditho tse ding tsa lelapa tse hodileng hore di o jarise morwalo.

SourceText: •  You are not alone! Keep connected with people who understand your situation.
text: • Tseba hore ha o mong! Dula o buisana le batho ba utlwisisang boemo ba hao.

SourceText: Here is a comic on how you can reinforce your child's strength.
text: Ena ke tsela ya boswaswi ya ho tiisa ngwana wa hao mmoko.

SourceText: • Share your challenges AND your successes.
text: • Buisanang ka diphpetso HAMMOHO LE dintho tseo le atlehileng ho di etsa.

SourceText: • It is normal to feel stressed, frustrated, and afraid at this time.
text: • Ke ho tlwaelehileng ho ikutlwa o imetswe maikong, o ferekane ebile o tshohile nakong ena.

SourceText: • Be kind to yourself and take a break when you need to!
text: • Inahanele mme ho nke kgefu ha ho hlokahala!

SourceText: Child: "la la la la…."
text: Ngwana: "la la la la…."

SourceText: Teen: "la la la la…"
text: Motjha: "la la la la…."

SourceText: Disabled Child: "la la la la…"
text: Ngwana ya Holofetseng: "la la la la…."

SourceText: Parent: "It was so lovely to hear you singing while I was preparing dinner. Food is ready! Please tidy the room and put away the toys."
text: Motswadi: “Le binne ha monate ha ke ntse ke pheha tinare. Dijo di lokile! Ke kopa le hlwekise kamore ya lona mme le phuthe dithoye.”

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to support children living with disabilities:
text: Ka kopo kgetha palo e nngwe haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka tsela ya ho tshehetsa bana ba holofetseng:

SourceText: Teen: "Here is the toy box. We can put the toys inside."
text: Motjha: “Lebokose la dithoye ke lena. Re ke tshela dithoye kahara lona.”

SourceText: Disabled Child: "Please remember my favourite car!"
text: Ngwana ya Holofetseng: “Ke kopa o ska lebala koloi eo ke e ratang!”

SourceText: Child: "I have it right here!"
text: Ngwana: “Ke e behile hantle!”

SourceText: Here is a link to disability services in your area that may also be helpful: [INSERT LOCAL LINK]
text: Linking ena eo tla fumana ditshebeletso tsa batho ba holofetseng sebakeng sa heno tseo le tsona di ka thusang: [INSERT LOCAL LINK]

SourceText: Parent: "I am so happy you have tidied up your toys together! It is dinnertime!"
text: Motswadi: “Ke thabile hore ebe le phuthile dithoye tsa lona hantle! Ke nako ya tinare!”

SourceText: Disabled child: "Can you help me come to dinner?"
text: Ngwana ya holofetseng: "Ke kopa o nthuse ho ya dijong tsa tinare?"

SourceText: Parent: "Thank you for asking. Let's go together. You are so strong!"
text: Motswadi: “Kea leboha hore ebe o kopile. A re tsamaye hammoho. O matla hakaakang!”

SourceText: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support. Chat later!
text: Hopola hore kamehla o thaepe “Thuso” haeba o ka batla dikeletso tse ding tsa botswadi kapa tshehetso e nngwe. A re bue hamorao!

SourceText: Step 1. Keep your child safe and well
text: Mohato wa 1. Tiisa hore bana ba hao ba sireletsehile ebile ba ya hantle

SourceText: • Keep your country's COVID-19 rules, and also help @fields.child_nickname_disabled to be active - do whatever exercise you can with them inside or outside your home
text: • Boloka melao ya naha ya heno ya COVID-19 , mme o thuse le @fields.child_nickname_disabled ho dula a le mahlahahlaha - kahoo ikwetlise ka tsela efe kapa efe le yena katlung le kantle
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated. @results.count is a number (counter for list)

SourceText: • Keep emergency contact numbers somewhere easy to see
text: • Boloka dinomoro tse letsetswang boemong ba tshohanyetso moo ho leng bonolo ho di bona

SourceText: • Keep your country's COVID-19 rules, and also help your child to be active - do whatever exercise you can with them inside or outside your home
text: • Boloka melao ya naha ya heno ya COVID-19 , mme o thuse le ngwana wa hao ho dula a le mahlahahlaha - kahoo ikwetlise ka tsela efe kapa efe le yena katlung le kantle

SourceText: Step 5. Make daily plans to help them feel secure
text: Mohato wa 5. Etsa meralo ya letsatsi le letsatsi ya ho mo thusa hore a ikutlwe a sireletsehile

SourceText: • Having things that are the same each day helps children feel secure and safe.
text: • Ho etsa dintho tse tshwanang letsatsi le letsatsi ho thusa bana ba hao hore ba ikutlwe ba bolokehile ebile ba sireletsehile.

SourceText: • Make a daily plan that includes some things they like to do.
text: • Etsa moralo wa letsatsi le letsa o akerelletsang dintho tseo ba ratang ho di etsa.

SourceText: • Help @fields.child_nickname_disabled connect to friends and family members through phone, writing cards, or drawing pictures.
text: • Thusa @fields.child_nickname_disabled hore a kopane le metswalle le ba lelapa ka founo, ka ho ba ngolla dirarete kapa ho ba toroyela ditshwantsho.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: • Help your child connect to friends and family members through phone, writing cards, or drawing pictures.
text: • Thusa ngwana wa hao hore a kopane le metswalle le ba lelapa ka founo, ka ho ba ngolla dirarete kapa ho ba toroyela ditshwantsho.

SourceText: Step 2. Try to understand how they are feeling
text: Mohato wa 2. Leka ho utlwisisa tsela eo a ikutlwang ka yona

SourceText: • @fields.child_nickname_disabled may be feeling a lot of stress, anxiety, and frustration.
text: • @fields.child_nickname_disabled a ka nna a ikutlwa a na le seterese se sengata, a tshwenyehile kapa a ferekane.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: • Tell them that you love them
text: • Mo bolelle hore o a mo rata

SourceText: • Praise them for being good and for trying to be good!
text: • Mo babatse ha a entse hantle le ha a lekile ho itshwara hantle!

SourceText: • Your child may be feeling a lot of stress, anxiety, and frustration.
text: • Ngwana wa hao a ka nna a ikutlwa a na le seterese se sengata, a tshwenyehile kapa a ferekane.

SourceText: • Give @fields.child_nickname_disabled choices: this gives them a sense of control and builds self-esteem.
text: • O fe @fields.child_nickname_disabled dintho tseo a ka di kgethang: mo fe boikutlo ba hore o laola bophelo ba hae mme o mo thuse ho ba le seriti.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: • Use simple language and clear instructions. If words aren't good for them, try gestures and pictures.
text: • Sebedisa puo e bonolo le ditaelo tse hlakileng. Haeba a sa utlwisise mantswe, leka ho etsa matshwao le ho toroya ditshwantsho.

SourceText: • Give your child choices: this gives them a sense of control and builds self-esteem.
text: • O fe ngwana wa hao dintho tseo a ka di kgethang: mo fe boikutlo ba hore o laola bophelo ba hae mme o mo thuse ho ba le seriti.

SourceText: Step 3. Talking and communicating with your child
text: Mohato wa 3. Qoqa mme o buisane le ngwana wa hao.

SourceText: • Get down to @fields.child_nickname_disabled’s level when you speak.
text: • Kotsama ho fihlela o le boemong ba @fields.child_nickname_disabled ha o bua le yena.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: • Look at them and smile
text: • Mo shebe mme o bososele

SourceText: • Give them time to tell you or show you what they think
text: • Mo fe nako ya hore a o bolelle kapa a o bontshe hore o ntse a nahana

SourceText: • Tell @fields.child_nickname_disabled that you understand
text: • Bolella @fields.child_nickname_disabled hore o a utlwisisa
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: • Get down to your child’s level when you speak.
text: • Kotsama ho fihlela o le boemong ba ngwana wa hao ha o bua le yena.

SourceText: • Tell your child that you understand
text: • Bolella ngwana wa hao hore o a utlwisisa

SourceText: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Children living with disabilities need love, respect and time – just like any other child.
text: O sebeditse ka ho eketsa thulusi e nngwe Mokotleng wa hao wa Dithulusi tsa Botswadi! Bana ba holofetseng ba hloka lerato, tlhompho le nako – jwaloka bana ba bang bohle.

SourceText: You have added another layer to your House of Support! Children living with disabilities need love, respect and time – just like any other child.
text: O ekeditse mokato o mong Ntlong ya hao ya Tshehetso! Bana ba holofetseng ba hloka lerato, tlhompho le nako – jwaloka bana ba bang bohle.

SourceText: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support.  You can also change the type of messages you receive for an older or younger child. Just select "Technical Support". Chat to you later!
text: Hopola hore kamehla o thaepe “Thuso” haeba o ka batla dikeletso tse ding tsa botswadi kapa tshehetso e nngwe.  O ka boela wa fetola mofuta wa melaetsa eo o e fumanang bakeng sa ngwana e moholwanyane kapa e monyane. Kgetha feela “Technical Support”. Ke tla bua le wena hamorao!

SourceText: Hello @fields.user_name! Today we are going to learn what we can do when our children are already misbehaving or have already misbehaved…
text: Dumela @fields.user_name! Kajeno lena re tlo ithuta hore na re ka etsang ha bana ba sa itshware hantle kapa ba ile ba itshwara ka tsela e sa nepahalang...
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Hello! Today we are going to learn what we can do when our children are already misbehaving or have already misbehaved…
text: Dumela! Kajeno lena re tlo ithuta hore na re ka etsang ha bana ba sa itshware hantle kapa ba ile ba itshwara ka tsela e sa nepahalang...

SourceText: Use consequences for refusing to follow instructions or forgetting household rules. Consequences help teach our children responsibility for what they do. They also allow discipline that is controlled. This is more effective than hitting or shouting.
text: Sebedisa ditlamorao tsa ho hana ho mamela ditaelo kapa ho lebala melao ya lelapa. Ditlamorao di ruta bana ba rona ho jara boikarabelo ka seo ba se etsang. Hape di thusa kgalemelo e laolehileng. E atleha ho feta ho shapa kapa ho tjwedietsa bana.

SourceText: Children and teens often act disrespectfully or like they only care about themselves. Growing up is a difficult time when they are learning about who they are and how they want to be in the world. Luckily, there are other ways to discipline your teen without using violence…and they work well!
text: Hangata bana le batjha ba itshwara ka tsela e sa hlompheng kapa ba rata ho itjheba bobona feela. Nako ya kgolo ke nako e thata ya ha bana ba ithuta hore na bona ke bomang le hore na ba batla ho ba lefatsheng lena jwang. Ka lehlohonolo, ho na le ditsela tse ding tsa ho kgalemela motjha o sa be mabifi... mme le tsona di sebetsa hantle!

SourceText: Giving calm consequences help teach our children responsibility for what they do. They also allow discipline that is controlled. This is more effective than hitting or shouting.
text: Ho phethisa ditlamorao o kgobile matshwafo ho ruta bana ba rona ho jara boikarabelo ka seo ba se etsang. Hape di thusa kgalemelo e laolehileng. E atleha ho feta ho shapa kapa ho tjwedietsa bana.

SourceText: Here are 5 tips for using consequences:
text: Bona dikeletso tsena tse 5 tsa ho phethisa ditlamorao:

SourceText: 1. Give a choice before consequence
text: 1. Mo fe kgetho pele ho ditlamorao

SourceText: 2. Stay calm but be firm
text: 2. Dula o kgobile matshwafo empa o tiise ka hanong

SourceText: 3. Be realistic and follow through
text: 3. Ebe dintho tse utlwahalang mme o di phethise

SourceText: 4. Reconnect afterwards
text: 4. Kopanang hape kamora moo

SourceText: 5. Consequences for breaking rules
text: 5. Ditlamorao tsa ho tlola melao

SourceText: To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "5". You can also type "N" to move on.
text: Hore o ithute haholwanyane ka dikeletso tsena, thaepa “1” ho ya ho “5”. Hape o ka thaepa "N" ho fetela pele.

SourceText: Consequences can also be used when your children forget a household rule, like going to bed at a certain hour or doing schoolwork before T.V.
text: Ditlamorao di ka boela tsa sebediswa ha bana ba lebala melao ya lelapa, jwaloka ho robala ka hora e itseng kapa ho etsa mosebetsi wa sekolo pele ba shebella T.V.

SourceText: 2. Try to stay calm but firm when giving the consequence.
text: 2. Leka ho dula o kgobile matshwafo empa o tiise ka hanong ha ho phethisa ditlamorao.

SourceText: If you start yelling, it will just make things worse. Take a deep breath before you speak in a clear, calm, and firm voice.
text: Ha o qala ho omana, seo se tla etsa hore dintho di be mpe le ho feta. Hemala hodimo pele o bua ka tsela e hlakileng, o theotse moya empa o tiisitse ka hanong.

SourceText: Make sure you can follow through with the consequence. For example, taking away a teenager’s phone for a week is hard to enforce. Taking it away for one hour is more realistic.
text: Tiisa hore o ka phethisa ditlamorao. Ka mohlala, ho ka ba thata ho amoha motjha founo beke kaofela. Ke ho utlwahalang haholo ho mo amoha yona ka hora e le nngwe.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about using consequences:
text: Ka kopo kgetha palo e nngwe haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka ho phethisa ditlamorao:

SourceText: Here is a comic that shows a parent giving their child a choice to follow the instruction or receive a consequence.
text: Ena ke tsela ya boswaswi e bontshang motswadi ya fang ngwana kgetho ya ho latela ditaelo kapa ho tobana le ditlamorao.

SourceText: Parent: “In 5 minutes it will be time to give me back the phone and start your school work.”
text: Motswadi: “Ho setse metsotso e 5 pele o kgutlisetsa founo ho nna ebe o qala mosebetsi wa hao wa sekolo.”

SourceText: Teen (distractedly): “Uh-huh…”
text: Motjha (a sitisehile): “Uh-huh…”

SourceText: Parent: “5 minutes is up. Please give me the phone.”
text: Motswadi: “Metsotso e 5 e fedile. Ke kopa hore o mphe founo.”

SourceText: Teen: “No, I am not done. I just need to get to the next level.”
text: Motjha: “Tjhe, ha ke so qete. Ke tlameha ho fihla boemong bo latelang.”

SourceText: Parent: “You have a choice, either you give me the phone now, or you cannot use it after dinner.”
text: Motswadi: “O tla ikgethela, hore na o mpha founo hona jwale, kapa o ke ke wa e sebedisa kamora dijo tsa mantsiboya.”

SourceText: Teen (not happy but agreeing): “Fine.”
text: Motjha (ha aa thaba empa o a dumela): “Ho lokile.”

SourceText: Parent: “Thank you for giving me the phone back, Carter. Now please do your school work. After that we can take a walk or play a game together.”
text: Motswadi: “Kea leboha hore ebe o kgutliseditse founo ho nna, Hloni. Jwale ke kopa hore o etse mosebetsi wa hao wa sekolo. Kamora moo re tla thapolla maoto kapa re bapale papadi mmoho.”

text: 1. Neha ngwana wa hao kgetho ya ho latela ditaelo tsa hao pele o mo bolella ditlamorao.

SourceText: 4. Reconnect afterwards.
text: 4. Kopanang hape kamora moo.

SourceText: Once the consequence is over, give @fields.child_nickname a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.
text: Hang ha ditlamorao di fedile, o fe @fields.child_nickname monyetla wa ho etsa ntho e nngwe e ntle, mme o mo babatse ka lebaka leo.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Once the consequence is over, give your child a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.
text: Hang ha ditlamorao di fedile, o fe ngwana wa hao monyetla wa ho etsa ntho e nngwe e ntle, mme o mo babatse ka lebaka leo.

SourceText: For example, you can tell @fields.child_nickname that if they do not do their schoolwork before dinner, they cannot watch their favourite T.V. show that evening.
text: Ka mohlala, o ka bolella @fields.child_nickname hore haeba a sa etse mosebetsi wa sekolo pele ho dijo tsa mantsiboya, a ke ke a shebella lenaneo leo a le ratang mantsiboyeng ao.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: For example, you can tell your child that if they do not do their schoolwork before dinner, they cannot watch their favourite T.V. show that evening.
text: Ka mohlala, o ka bolella ngwana wa hao hore haeba a sa etse mosebetsi wa sekolo pele ho dijo tsa mantsiboya, a ke ke a shebella lenaneo leo a le ratang mantsiboyeng ao.

SourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! When your child is behaving badly, try responding in a calm way with a fair consequence. It will help them learn that their actions have an impact on themselves and others. It also teaches them about responsibility and respect!
text: Mosebetsi o tswileng matsoho! O ekeditse boiphihlelo bo bong Mokotleng wa hao wa Dithulusi tsa Botswadi! Ha ngwana wa hao a itshwara hampe, leka ho arabela o theotse moya ho mo bolella ditlamorao tse mo tshwanelang. Seo se tla mo thusa hore a ithute hore diketso tsa hae di ama yena le batho ba bang. Hape seo se mo ruta ho jara boikarabelo le tlhompho!

SourceText: Well done! You have added another layer to your House of Support! When your child is behaving badly, try responding in a calm way with a fair consequence. It will help them learn that their actions have an impact on themselves and others. It also teaches them about responsibility and respect!
text: Mosebetsi o tswileng matsoho! O ekeditse mokato o mong Ntlong ya hao ya Tshehetso! Ha ngwana wa hao a itshwara hampe, leka ho arabela o theotse moya ho mo bolella ditlamorao tse mo tshwanelang. Seo se tla mo thusa hore a ithute hore diketso tsa hae di ama yena le batho ba bang. Hape seo se mo ruta ho jara boikarabelo le tlhompho!

SourceText: Today's Tip is about how we can support our teens when they experience really difficult situations.
text: Keletso ya Kajeno e amana le kamoo re ka tshehetsang batjha ba rona ha ba tobana le maemo a boima e le kannete.

SourceText: When our children share difficult experiences with us, we may initially get angry because we are afraid for them. But that is when we need to stay calm, listen, and be open.
text: Ha bana ba rona ba re bolella dintho tse boima tse ba hlahetseng, qalong re ka nna ra halefa hobane re ba tshohetse. Empa ke yona nako eo ka yona re tlamehang ho dula re kgobile matshwafo, re ba mamele mme re ba phetlele sefuba.

SourceText: Do you want some tips that can help you respond in a more supportive way?
text: Na o batla dikeletso tse ding tse ka o thusang ho arabela ka tsela e mo tshehetsang le ho feta?

SourceText: Remember that you can also change the type of messages you receive for an older or younger child. Just select "Technical Support." Chat to you later @fields.user_name!
text: Hopola hore o ka boela wa fetola mofuta wa melaetsa eo o e fumanang bakeng sa ngwana e moholwanyane kapa e monyane. Kgetha feela “Technical Support.” Ke tla bua le wena hamorao @fields.user_name!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Remember that you can also change the type of messages you receive for an older or younger child. Just select "Technical Support." Chat to you later!
text: Hopola hore o ka boela wa fetola mofuta wa melaetsa eo o e fumanang bakeng sa ngwana e moholwanyane kapa e monyane. Kgetha feela “Technical Support.” Ke tla bua le wena hamorao!

SourceText: When our children share something that is especially troubling, we need to remember to stay calm, listen, and be open.
text: Ha bana ba rona ba re phetela ntho e re kgathatsang haholo, re tlameha ho hopola ho dula re kgobile matshwafo, re ba mamele mme re ba phetlele sefuba.

SourceText: Here's a video on how you can support your teen when they are experiencing difficult situations.
text: Shebella video ya kamoo o ka tshehetsang motjha wa hao kateng ha a tobane le boemo bo boima.

SourceText: Here's an audio message on how you can support your teen when they are experiencing difficult situations.
text: Mamela molaetsa o mamelwang wa kamoo o ka tshehetsang motjha wa hao kateng ha a tobane le boemo bo boima.

SourceText: Here are some things you can do when your teen shares something difficult with you:
text: Tsena ke dintho tseo o ka di etsang ha motjha wa hao a o phetela ntho e itseng e bohloko:

SourceText: • Take a deep breath before you respond.
text: • Hemela hodimo pele o araba.

SourceText: • Listen to what your child is saying. Notice how they are feeling.
text: • Mamela seo ngwana wa hao a o bolellang sona. Hlokomela hore na yena o ikutlwa jwang.

SourceText: • Notice how you feel. Ask yourself, "What does my child need right now?"
text: • Hlokomela tsela eo wena o ikutlwang ka yona. Ipotse, “Ngwana wa ka o hloka eng hona jwale?”

SourceText: • Reassure your child that you are there for them.
text: • Netefalletsa ngwana wa hao hore o tla wa o tsoha le yena.

SourceText: • You can deal with the consequences later but right now your child needs you.
text: • O ka sebetsana le ditlamorao hamorao empa hona jwale ngwana wa hao o hloka wena.

SourceText: • Discuss possible solutions or next steps to take action.
text: • Buisanang ka ditharollo tse ka thusang kapa mehato e latelang eo le ka e nkang.

SourceText: • Remind your child again that you love them and thank them for sharing with you.
text: • Hopotsa ngwana wa hao hape hore o a mo rata mme o mo lebohe ha a o phetetse taba eo.

SourceText: We understand that this can be really difficult. Please type "Help" if you want any extra support or guidance.
text: Rea utlwisisa hore kannete ho ka ba thata. Ka kopo thaepa “Thuso” haeba o batla thuso kapa tataiso efe kapa efe e eketsehileng.

SourceText: Here is a comic that shows how you can support your child during a crisis.
text: Ena ke tsela ya boswaswi e bontshang kamoo o ka tshehetsang ngwana wa hao kateng nakong ya ditsietsi.

SourceText: Parent: “What’s wrong, my dear? Come and sit by me and tell me what happened.”
text: Motswadi: “Molato ke eng, ngwana ka? Tloo o tlo dula pela ka mme o mpolelle se etsahetseng.”

SourceText: Child: “It’s that person…they touched me…”
text: Ngwana: “Ke motho yane...o ntshwere...”

SourceText: Parent: “Take your time... I am listening.”
text: Motswadi: “O se ke wa potlakela ho qeta taba... Ke o mametse.”

SourceText: Child: “… they held me down…told me I would be in trouble if I told anybody…”
text: Ngwana: “… a nkwebetella fatshe…yaba o re ke tla kena mathateng haeba nka bolella motho e mong…”

SourceText: Parent: “I believe you. You are not in trouble. It is not your fault. This is a big thing and we will find a way to get the help you need. I wonder where we can go for help…?”
text: Motswadi: “Kea o kgolwa. O ke ke wa kena mathateng. Hase phoso ya hao. Ena ke taba e tebileng mme re tla fumana tsela ya ho fumana thuso eo o e hlokang. Kea ipotsa hore na ebe re ka ya hokae hore re fumane thuso…?”

SourceText: Child: “The clinic? But could you come with me?”
text: Ngwana: “Ebe tliliniking? Empa na o tla tsamaya le nna?”

SourceText: Parent: “Yes, they will know what to do. Of course, I will come with you. Remember, this is not your fault. I love you and we will get through this.”
text: Motswadi: “E, ba tla tseba hore na ba lokela ho etsang. Jwang kapa jwang ke tlo tsamaya le wena. O hopole, hase phoso ya hao. Kea o rata ebile re tla bo hlola bothata bona.”

SourceText: Child: “Thanks so much.”
text: Ngwana: “Ke lebohile haholo.”

SourceText: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support.
text: Hopola hore kamehla o thaepe “Thuso” haeba o ka batla dikeletso tse ding tsa botswadi kapa tshehetso e nngwe.

SourceText: Well done @fields.user_name! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Try following these steps whenever your child shares something difficult. Supporting your child through a crisis will also teach them how to support others in difficult times. Good for you!
text: Mosebetsi o tswileng matsoho @fields.user_name! O ekeditse boiphihlelo bo bong Mokotleng wa hao wa Dithulusi tsa Botswadi! Leka ho latela mehato ena neng kapa neng ha ngwana wa hao a o phetela ntho e boima. Ha o tshehetsa ngwana wa hao ha a tobane le tsietsi, seo se tla mo ruta hore le yena a tshehetse ba bang ha ba le mathateng. Re thaba le wena!

SourceText: When we are able to have peaceful and loving relationships, our children feel more secure and loved. Kindness and taking care of yourself help.
text: Ha re kgona ho ba le dikamano tse nang le kgotso le tse lerato, bana ba rona ba tla ikutlwa ba sireletsehile ebile ba ratwa haholo. Ho itshwara ka mosa le ho itlhokomela ho a thusa.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you support positive family relationships at home.
text: Shebella video ena ho o thusa ho tshehetsa dikamano tse mofuthu ka lapeng.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you support positive family relationships at home.
text: Mamela molaetsa ona o mamelwang ho o thusa ho tshehetsa dikamano tse mofuthu ka lapeng.

SourceText: Here are 6 simple steps that you can do to support family harmony at home:
text: Bona mehato ena e 6 e bonolo eo o ka e latelang ho tshehetsa dikamano tse mofuthu ka lapeng.

SourceText: 1. Be a model of behaviour for your kids
text: 1. Eba mohlala wa hore na bana ba hao ba lokela ho itshwara jwang

SourceText: 2. Keep it positive
text: 2. Bua ka ntho e lokelang ho etswa

SourceText: 3. Listen carefully to others
text: 3. Mamela batho ba bang ka hloko

SourceText: 4. Share the load
text: 4. Ba abele boikarabelo

SourceText: 5. Take care of yourself
text: 5. Itlhokomele

SourceText: 6. Do nice things together as a family.
text: 6. Etsang dintho tse ntle mmoho le le lelapa.

SourceText: Type "1" to 6" to learn more about these tips. Type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Thaepa “1” ho ya ho “6” hore o ithute haholwanyane ka dikeletso tsena. Thaepa “N” ho emisa keletso ena.

SourceText: Step 4. Share the load
text: Mohato wa 4. Ba abele boikarabelo

SourceText: Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared. Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members
text: Ho hlokomela bana le ditho tse ding tsa lelapa ho thata, empa ho boholo haholo ha mesebetsi e abuwe. Leka ho abela ditho tsa lelapa mesebetsi ya lelapa, ya tlhokomelo ya ngwana, le mesebetsi e meng ka ho lekana

SourceText: Step 5. Take care of yourself
text: Mohato wa 5. Itlhokomele

SourceText: Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household. It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break
text: Etsa lenaneo bakeng sa nako eo o “fumanehang” le nako eo “o sa fumaneheng” le batho ba bang ba baholo lelapeng la hao. Ha ho phoso ho kopa thuso ha o ikutlwa o kgathetse kapa o imetswe maikutlong e le hore o ka nka kgefu

SourceText: Step 6. Do nice things together as a family
text: Mohato wa 6. Etsang dintho tse ntle mmoho le le lelapa

SourceText: Let each family member take turns choosing a whole family activity. Find ways to spend time alone with other adults in your home, too!
text: Tlohella setho ka seng sa lelapa hore se etelle pele ho kgetheleng lelapa lohle seo leka se etsang. Hape, fumana ditsela tsa ho qeta nako le le bang le batho ba bang ba baholo lapeng la hao!

SourceText: Step 1. Be a model of behaviour for your kids
text: Mohato wa 1. Eba mohlala wa hore na bana ba hao ba lokela ho itshwara jwang

SourceText: How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too! Try to talk kindly to everyone in the family, adults and children.
text: Tsela eo re buang le ho itshwara ka yona kapela bana ba rona e ka susumetsa haholo tsela eo le bona ba itshwarang ka yona! Leka ho buisana le ditho tsohle tsa lelapa la hao ka mosa, eba ke batho ba baholo kapa bana.

SourceText: Step 2. Use positive language. It works!
text: Mohato wa 2. Sebedisa puo e monate. E sebetsa hantle!

SourceText: Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”
text: Bolella ba bang seo o batlang hore ba se etse ho fapana le seo o sa batleng hore ba se etse: Ho fapana le hore “Tlohelang ho etsa lerata,” leka “Ke kopa le theole lerata”

SourceText: Decide to take a break from arguing when you see arguments building up, and go into another room or outside if you can.
text: Etsa qeto ya ho kgaotsa ngangisano ha o bona dingangisano di qala, mme o kene kamoreng e nngwe kapa o tswele kantle haeba o ka kgona.

SourceText: You can always type "Help" if you need an activity to help you with stress.
text: Hopola hore ka dinako tsohle o ka thaepa lentswe “Thuso”, ha o hloka seo o ka se etsang ho o thusa ka seterese.

SourceText: Praise others to make them feel appreciated and good about themselves. Simple words like, “Thank you for clearing the dinner,” or “Thank you for watching the baby” can make a big difference
text: Babatsa batho ba bang hore ba ikutlwe ba ananelwa ebile ba ikutlwe hantle. Mantswe a bonolo jwaloka, “Kea leboha ka ho hlwekisa kamora tinare,” kapa “Kea leboha ka ho hlokomela ngwana” a ka etsa phapang e kgolo.

SourceText: Bad communication between adults in the household can have a negative impact on our children. The more we practice modeling peaceful, loving relationships for our children, the more secure and loved they will feel.
text: Ho se buisane hantle pakeng tsa batho ba baholo lapeng ho ka ama bana ba rona hampe. Ha re atisa ho itshwara ka tsela e kgothalletsang kgotso, dikamano tse lerato bakeng sa bana ba rona, ke moo ba tlang ho ikutlwa ba sireletsehile ebile ba ratwa haholo.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to support family harmony at home:
text: Ka kopo kgetha palo e nngwe haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka ho tshehetsa momahano ya lelapa hae.

SourceText: Step 3. Be a great listener
text: Mohato wa 3. Eba momamedi ya hlwahlwa

SourceText: Listen to others when they are talking with you. Be open and show them that you hear what they are saying. It can help to summarise what you have heard before responding: “What I hear you saying is…”
text: Mamela batho ba bang ha ba bua le wena. Ba phetlele sefuba mme o ba bontshe hore o mametse seo ba se buang. Ho ka ba molemo ho akaretsa seo o se utlwileng pele o araba: “Haeba kea o utlwa o re…”

SourceText: Well done for adding another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Over the next few days, try taking a deep breath or walking away for a bit when you start getting angry at someone. Every time you find a way to resolve conflicts in a peaceful way, you increase your child's brain development. Be proud of yourself when you do it!
text: O sebeditse ka ho eketsa boiphihlelo bo bong Mokotleng wa hao wa Dithulusi tsa Botswadi! Matsatsi a mmalwa a tlang, leka ho hemela hodimo kapa ho tloha hanyane ha o ikutlwa o qala ho halefela motho e mong. Nako le nako ha o fumana tsela ya ho rarolla diphapang ka tsela e nang le kgotso, o eketsa kgolo ya boko ba ngwana wa hao. Eba motlotlo ka wena ha o kgonne!

SourceText: Well done for adding another layer to your House of Support! Over the next few days, try taking a deep breath or walking away for a bit when you start getting angry at someone. text: Kea utlwisisa hore kannete ho ka ba thata dinakong tsena. Ka kopo thaepa “Thuso” haeba o batla thuso kapa tataiso efe kapa efe e eketsehileng. A re bue hamorao!

SourceText: Here are some tips that might help when your baby cries:
text: Bona dikeletso tse ding tse ka o thusa ha lesea la hao le lla:

SourceText: 1. Why babies cry
text: 1. Hobaneng ha lesea le lla

SourceText: 2. Respond as soon as you can
text: 2. Arabela kapele kamoo o ka kgonang

SourceText: 3. Check to see why your baby is crying
text: 3. Sheba hore na ke hobaneng ha lesea la hao le lla

SourceText: 4. Comfort your baby
text: 4. Thodisa lesea la hao

SourceText: 5. Take a break if you need it
text: 5. Nka kgefu haeba o e hloka

SourceText: 6. Be gentle and patient with yourself
text: 6. Itshware ka mosa mme o imamelle

SourceText: 7. If you think your baby is injured or sick, call or visit a clinic
text: 7. Haeba o nahana hore lesea la hao le lemetse kapa lea kula, letsetsa kapa o etele tliliniking

SourceText: To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "7". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Hore o ithute haholwanyane ka tsena, thaepa “1” ho ya ho “7”. Hape o ka thaepa “N” ho emisa keletso ena.

SourceText: If your baby cries for a long time and does not stop, they might be injured or sick. You should seek medical help immediately.
text: Haeba lesea la hao le lla ka nako e telele mme le sa kgaotse, mohlomong le lemetse kapa lea kula. O lokela ho batla thuso ya bongaka hanghang.

SourceText: Go to your baby when you hear them crying. You will not spoil your baby by picking them up. Babies who are carried and cuddled frequently, during both fussy and contented periods, may actually cry less.
text: Leba ho lesea la hao ha o utlwa le lla. O tla be o sa tefise lesea la hao haeba o le nka. Masea a nkuwang le ho kopuwa kgafetsa, ebang ke ha a sa thaba le ha a kgotsofetse, ha a lle haholo.

SourceText: 1. Why do babies cry?
text: 1. Hobaneng ha masea a lla?

SourceText: Crying is a normal part of your baby's development. Sometimes babies even have crying patterns. Crying usually increases at 2-3 weeks old and is generally highest when your baby is around 6 to 8 weeks. Often babies will start crying less around 3 to 4 months. Of course, remember that every baby is different!
text: Ho lla ke karolo e tlwaelehileng ya kgolo ya lesea. Ka dinako tse ding masea a bile a ba le ditsela tsa ho lla. Hangata masea a lla haholo ha a le dibeke di 2-3 mme ka tlwaelo lesea la hao le tla llela hodimo ka ho fetisisa ha le na le dibeke tse 6 ho ya ho 8. Hangata masea a fokotsa ho lla ha a le dikgwedi di 3 ho ya ho tse 4. Empa o hopole hore lesea le leng le le leng le na le botho bo ikgethang!

SourceText: 3.  Check to see why your baby is crying
text: 3.  Sheba hore na ke hobaneng ha lesea la hao le lla

SourceText: There are lots of reasons why babies cry. It might be hunger, pain, too much going on, rough handling, feeling cold/hot, wanting contact or attention, or feeling irritable. Babies can cry when they sense tension in the room. And sometimes they cry for no reason at all!
text: Ho na le mabaka a mangata a etsang hore masea a lle. Mohlomong seo se bakwa ke tlala, ho utlwa bohloko, ntho di ngata tse etsahalang, ho nkwa ka bohale, ho ikutlwa a hatsetse/a tjhesa, ho batla ho tshwarwa kapa ho elwa hloko, kapa ho ikutlwa a tenehile. Masea a ka lla haeba a utlwa ho hloka kutlwano katlung. Ka dinako tse ding a lla ho se na lebaka ho hang!

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about what to do when your baby is crying:
text: Ka kopo kgetha palo e nngwe haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka seo o ka se etsang ha lesea la hao le lla:

SourceText: Here is a comic on coping with a colicky baby
text: Ena ke tsela ya boswaswi ya ho sebetsana le lesea le tlallaneng moya ka mpeng

SourceText: Parent 1: "We should do something."
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Re tlameha ho etsa ho hong.”

SourceText: Parent 2: "Okay, I'll try feeding them."
text: Motswadi wa 2: “Ho lokile, ke tla leka ho mo jesa.”

SourceText: Baby: "aaaaaaaa"
text: Lesea: "aaaaaaaa"

SourceText: Parent 1:  "What is wrong with them?"
text: Motswadi wa 1:  “Bothata ke eng?”

SourceText: Parent 2: "I don't know. It has been an hour and they are still crying. I cannot take it anymore. They are driving me crazy, I just want to shake them!"
text: Motswadi wa 2: “Ha ke tsebe. O se a qetile hora kaofela a ntse a lla. Ha ke tsebe hore na ke etse jwang. O nkopanya kelello, ke bona ho le betere hore ke nne ke mo sisinye!”

SourceText: Parent 2: "I can see that this has been a stressful night for you. How about you get some sleep while I take Frankie into the other room. I will try wrapping them up in a blanket."
text: Motswadi wa 2: “Kea bona hore bona hore ha o a bo hlotha bosiu bo fetileng. Ako robale hanyane mme ke tla ya le Thabi ka kamoreng e nngwe. Ke tla leka ho mo phuthela ka kobo.”

SourceText: Parent 1: "Thank you. I was getting so angry at myself."
text: Motswadi wa 1: Kea leboha! Ke ne ke utlwa hore kea itenehela.”

SourceText: Parent 1: "How did you manage to get them to sleep?"
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Na o ile wa ka wa kgona ho robala?”

SourceText: Parent 2: "I think they wore themselves out but we should take them to the clinic tomorrow morning."
text: Motswadi wa 2: “Ke nahana hore le yena o kgathetse empa re tlameha ho mo isa tliliniking hosane hoseng.”

SourceText: Call someone for help - a family member, a friend. Sometimes just talking with someone is enough, but if you feel overwhelmed, ask someone for help. Calling for help is a sign of strength.
text: Kopa motho e mong hore a o thuse - ebang ke setho sa lelapa kapa motswalle. Ka dinako tse ding ho bua le motho e mong ho lekane, empa haeba o ikutlwa o imetswe haholo, kopa thuso ya motho e mong. Ho kopa thuso ke letshwao la motho ya matla.

SourceText: Here's a video that might help you when @fields.child_nickname cries.
text: Shebella video ena e ka o thusang ha @fields.child_nickname a lla.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Here's a video that might help you when your baby cries.
text: Shebella video ena e ka o thusang ha lesea la hao le lla.

text: Mamela molaetsa ona o tla o thusang ha @fields.child_nickname a lla!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you when your baby cries.
text: Mamela molaetsa ona o tla o thusang ha lesea la hao le lla!

SourceText: 5. Take a break!
text: 5. Nka kgefu!

SourceText: If you are getting angry because @fields.child_nickname won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Check on @fields.child_nickname every 5-10 minutes.
text: Haeba o halefiswa ke hore ebe @fields.child_nickname ha a thole, ha ho phoso ho mo siya a kakaletse sebakeng se sireletsehileng ebe o tloha pela hae hanyane. Sheba hore na @fields.child_nickname o ntse a ya jwang kamora metsotso e meng le e meng e 5-10.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.
text: Haeba o halefiswa ke hore ebe lesea la hao ha le thole, ha ho phoso ho le siya le kakaletse sebakeng se sireletsehileng ebe o tloha pela lona hanyane. Sheba hore na lesea la hao le ntse le ya jwang kamora metsotso e meng le e meng e 5-10.

SourceText: We know that this is not easy. You are not a bad father if your baby continues to cry after you have done all you can to calm them. You are doing your best!
text: Rea tseba hore sena hase bonolo. Hase hore o ntate e mobe haeba lesea la hao le tswela pele ho lla kamora ho etsa sohle seo o ka se kgonang ho le thodisa. O etsa sohle se matleng a hao!

SourceText: We know that this is not easy. You are not a bad mother if your baby continues to cry after you have done all you can to calm them. You are doing your best!
text: Rea tseba hore sena hase bonolo. Hase hore o mme e mobe haeba lesea la hao le tswela pele ho lla kamora ho etsa sohle seo o ka se kgonang ho le thodisa. O etsa sohle se matleng a hao!

SourceText: We know that this is not easy. You are not a bad parent if your baby continues to cry after you have done all you can to calm them. You are doing your best!
text: Rea tseba hore sena hase bonolo. Hase hore o motswadi e mobe haeba lesea la hao le tswela pele ho lla kamora ho etsa sohle seo o ka se kgonang ho le thodisa. O etsa sohle se matleng a hao!

SourceText: Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed @fields.child_nickname or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - @fields.child_nickname can actually sense tension from you, too!
text: Leka ho thatela lesela ka lepae, etsa morethetho o phodileng, kapa bina kapa o letse mmino o mathemalodi. Mohlomong o tlameha ho fepa @fields.child_nickname kapa ho le tjhentjha leleiri. Mohlomong le ikutlwa le tjhesa kapa le bata haholo. Kapa mohlomong o tlameha ho le kuka. Nka Kgefu mme o leke ho phomotsa methapo - hantlentle @fields.child_nickname le ka utlwa haeba le wena o sa thaba!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed your baby or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - your baby can actually sense tension from you, too!
text: Leka ho thatela lesela ka lepae, etsa morethetho o phodileng, kapa bina kapa o letse mmino o mathemalodi. Mohlomong o tlameha ho fepa lesea la hao kapa ho le tjhentjha leleiri. Mohlomong le ikutlwa le tjhesa kapa le bata haholo. Kapa mohlomong o tlameha ho le kuka. Nka Kgefu mme o leke ho phomotsa methapo - hantlentle lesea la hao le ka utlwa haeba le wena o sa thaba!

SourceText: Today's Tip is about how we can support our children when they are feeling sad, scared, angry, and confused.
text: Keletso ya Kajeno e amana le kamoo re ka tshehetsang bana ba rona ha ba ikutlwa ba kwatile, ba halefile ebile ba ferekane.

SourceText: Remember that you can also change the type of messages you receive for an older or younger child. Just select "Tech Support". Chat to you later @fields.user_name!
text: Hopola hore o ka boela wa fetola mofuta wa melaetsa eo o e fumanang bakeng sa ngwana e moholwanyane kapa e monyane. Kgetha feela “Tech Support.” Ke tla bua le wena hamorao @fields.user_name!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Remember that you can also change the type of messages you receive for an older or younger child. Just select "Tech Support". Chat to you later!
text: Hopola hore o ka boela wa fetola mofuta wa melaetsa eo o e fumanang bakeng sa ngwana e moholwanyane kapa e monyane. Kgetha feela “Tech Support.” Ke tla bua le wena hamorao!

SourceText: Be open to your children. They get stressed too - sometimes from different things from you. Allow them to express how they feel and accept their feelings. Try to listen to them and think about how it must feel for them.
text: Phetlela bana ba hao sefuba. Le bona ba tshwarwa ke seterese - ka dinako tse ding se bakwa ke dintho tse sa tshwaneng le se o bakelang seterese. Ba tlohelle ba bolele kamoo ba ikutlwang kateng mme o amohele maikutlo a bona. Leka ho ba mamela le ho nahana hore na e tlameha ebe ba ikutlwa jwang.

SourceText: Here are some tips for how we can help our children learn how to cope with their emotions:
text: Tsena ke tse ding tsa dikeletso tse ka thusang bana ba rona ho sebetsana le maikutlo a bona:

SourceText: 1. Be open to your child
text: 1. Phetlela ngwana wa hao sefuba.

SourceText: 2. Share your own feelings
text: 2. Mo bolelle maikutlo a hao

SourceText: 3. Help your child learn how to talk about feelings
text: 3. Thusa ngwana wa hao hore a ithute ho ntsha maikutlo a hae

SourceText: 4. Talking about difficult emotions
text: 4. Bua ka maikutlo a thata

SourceText: 5. Notice the positive emotions
text: 5. Lemoha maikutlo a matle

SourceText: 6. Show your child that you care
text: 6. Bontsha ngwana wa hao hore o a tsotella

SourceText: To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Hore o ithute haholwanyane ka tsena, thaepa “1” ho ya ho “6”. Hape o ka thaepa “N” ho emisa keletso ena.

SourceText: Your child will look to you for support and reassurance. Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling. Accept how they feel and give them comfort.
text: Ngwana wa hao o tla lebella hore o mo tshehetse le ho mo kgodisa hore ke motho wa bohlokwa. Mamela bana ba hao ha ba o bolella maikutlo a bona. Amohela maikutlo a bona mme o ba tshedise.

SourceText: When you share your own feelings with your children, you help them recognise their own feelings. It can also help your children learn self-discipline and to understand their own feelings.
text: Ha o bolella bana ba hao kamoo o ikutlwang kateng, o ba thusa ho lemoha maikutlo a bona. Hape seo se ka thus abana ba hao ho ithuta boitshwaro le ho utlwisisa maikutlo a bona.

SourceText: There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Even babies can feel and express these emotions. As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.
text: Ho na le maikutlo a 6 a motheo: Ho Thaba, Ho Hlonama, Ho Halefa, Ho Nyonya, Ho Makala, le Ho Tshoha. Esita le masea a ka ikutlwa le ho bontsha maikutlo ana. Ha bana ba ntse ba hola, ba ithuta ho lemoha maikutlo a mang a mangata, jwaloka ho nyakalla, ho swetseha, ho ba motlotlo, ho hlora, ho ba le kgotso, ho ikutlwa ba le molato kapa ho ferekana.

SourceText: It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy. This may be especially the case for boys and men.
text: Ke ho tlwaelehileng hore motho a thatafallwe ke ho bua ka le ho bolela maikutlo a hae. Boholo ba rona re ne re bolellwa hore re se ke ra lla ha re utlwile bohloko kapa re se ke ra tsheha ha re thabile. Ka ho kgetheha taba ena e ama bashanyana le banna.

SourceText: But we all have the same feelings, and  we can learn how to become aware of our own emotions, to experience them in our body, and to communicate about them.
text: Empa re na le maikutlo a tshwanang, ebile re ka ithuta tsela ya ho lemoha maikutlo a rona, ho utlwa hore a ama mmele ya rona jwang, le ho buisana le batho ba bang ka yona.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about talking about emotions:
text: Ka kopo kgetha palo e nngwe haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka ho bua ka maikutlo:

SourceText: Here's a video that can help you teach your child how to cope with their emotions.
text: Shebella video ena e o thusang ho ruta ngwana wa hao tsela ya ho sebetsana le maikutlo a hae.

SourceText: Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help @fields.child_nickname be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

SourceText: Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help your child be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!
text: Ho bua ka maikutlo ho ka thusa bana ho laola bohale, ho nyahama le ho swetseha. Hape ho ka thusa ngwana wa hao ho lemoha haholwanyane maikutlo a matle a kang ho ba le kgotso, thabo, kapa ho kgoba matshwafo. Seo se ka ba sa thusa bana ho thabela dinako tse monate kapa boikutlo ba lerato!

SourceText: Use physical and verbal support to make @fields.child_nickname feel accepted and loved. A hug or saying, "I understand," can mean a lot. Remind @fields.child_nickname that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

SourceText: Parent: “How are you doing, Andy?”
text: Motswadi: “O ntse o ya jwang, Andy?”

SourceText: Teen (looking sad): “I wish I could hang out with my friends.”
text: Motjha (o shebahala a hloname): “Ekare nka tjhakela metswalle ya ka.”

SourceText: Parent (thinking): "Hmmm…that can wait…"
text: Motswadi (o a nahana): "Hmmm…butle hanyane…"

SourceText: Parent (looks back to teen):“I understand it is hard to be separate from your friends. Especially since I am sure they are missing you, too. Let’s think of some ways that you could reach out to them.”
text: Motswadi (o sheba motjha): “Kea utlwisisa hore ha ho bonolo ho arohana le metswalle ya hao. Ebile kea tseba hore le bona ba o hlolohetswe. A re ke re nahane ka ditsela tse ding tsa ho buisana le bona.”

SourceText: Teen: "Maybe I can make a TikTok video to share with them. But I am not sure how…can you help me?”
text: Motjha: “Mohlomong nka ba romella video ya TikTok. Empa ha ke tsebe hore na e etsuwa jwang…ke kopa o nthuse hle!”

SourceText: Parent: “I would be happy to help and would like to know more about TikTok, too!”
text: Motswadi: “Ke tla thabela ho o thusa ebile le nna nka rata ho ithuta haholwanyane ka TikTok!”

SourceText: Here is a comic that shows how you can give your teen love and support when they share difficult emotions with you…
text: Ena ke tsela ua ya boswaswi e bontshang hore o bontsha motjha wa hao lerato ebile o a mo tshehetsa ha a o bolella maikutlo a hae a bohloko…

SourceText: Child: “Why can’t I go play with my friends today?”
text: Ngwana: “Hobaneng nke ke ka ya bapala le metswalle ya ka kajeno?”

SourceText: Parent: “I can see that you are upset, Sam. It can be difficult when we feel separated from our friends.”
text: Motswadi: “Sam, kea bona ha o a thaba ngwanaka. Ho thata ha re utlwa eka re thibetswe ho ya ho metswalle ya rona.”

SourceText: Parent: “We are not allowed to visit other people right now because of COVID-19.
text: Motswadi: “Ha rea dumellwa ho etela batho ba bang hona jwale ka lebaka la COVID-19.

SourceText: This will keep them and us safe while making sure our health services are able to support those who are sick."
text: Seo se tla re sireletsa le ho ba sireletsa mme ka nako e tshwanang se thusa lipetlele le ditliliniki tsa rona ho thusa ba kulang.”

SourceText: Parent: “As soon as we are able, you can play with your friends. In the meantime, we can draw some pictures of your favourite times playing with them.”
text: Motswadi: “Hang ha ho kgoneha, o tla bapala le metswalle ya hao. Empa pele monyetla oo o hlaha, re ka toroya ditshwantsho tsa dinako tseo o di ratang haholo ha o ne o bapala le metswalle ya hao.”

SourceText: Child: “Okay!”
text: Ngwana: “Ho lokile!”
