SourceText: Here are 6 steps on how we can reduce negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like tantrums using what we call Ignore:
text: Bona mehato ena e 6 ya kamoo o ka bokotsang boitshwaro ba ho ipitsetsa mahlo ka ditsela tse fosahetseng le ho tseka llela dintho jwaloka ho ithabukanya re sebedisa seo re se bitsang Iphapanye:

SourceText: 1. Try to redirect your child’s attention
text: 1. Leka ho bontsha ngwana ntho e nngwe

SourceText: 2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore
text: 2. Tiisa hore ke boitshwaro boo o ka iphapanyetsang bona

SourceText: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child
text: 3. Iphapanyetse boitshwaro eseng ngwana wa hao

SourceText: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour
text: 4. Babatsa ngwana wa hao kapele kamora hore a itshware hantle lekgetlong le latelang

SourceText: 5. Be consistent when ignoring
text: 5. Etsa dintho ka tsela e tshwanang ha o iphapanya

SourceText: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times.
text: 6. Tiisa hore o fa ngwana wa hao nako e ngata ha a etsa dintho tse ntle ka dinako tse ding.

SourceText: To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to move on.
text: Hore o ithute haholwanyane ka dikeletso tsena, thaepa “1” ho ya ho “6”. Hape o ka thaepa "N" ho fetela pele.

SourceText: Here is a comic on combining consequences and ignore.
text: Ena ke tsela ya boswaswi ya ho sebedisa ditlamorao le ho iphapanya ka nako e le nngwe.

SourceText: Parent 1: "Bailey, please clear the dishes after dinner"
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Keke, ke kopa o hleke dijana kamora tinare”

SourceText: Parent 2: "Sam, time to get ready for bed. Come with me."
text: Motswadi wa 2: “Sam, ke nako ya ho ya robala. Ha re ye.”

SourceText: Parent: "The household rule is that you have to help clean up after dinner before you can play with your toys."
text: Motswadi: “Molao wa lapeng mona ke hore o tlameha ho hlwekisa kamora tinare pele o ka ya bapala ka dithoye tsa hao.”

SourceText: Child: "I don't want to clear the dishes. I want to play with my new toy car. "
text: Ngwana: “Ha ke batle ho hleka dijana. Ke batla ho bapala ka koloi ya ka e ntjha.”

SourceText: Parent 1: "Bailey, either you clear the table now, or you will not be able to play with your toys later tonight"
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Keke, o tlo hlwekisa tafole hona jwale, kapa o ke ke wa kgona ho bapala ka dithoye tsa hao mantsiboyeng ana”

SourceText: Child: "But it is not fair! Sam doesn't have to clean up after dinner!"
text: Ngwana: “Empa hase hantle! Hore ebe Sam yena ha a hlwekise kamora tinare!”

SourceText: Parent 1: "Because you did not listen, you cannot play with your toys. Please get ready for bed.
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Hobane ha o a ka wa mamela, o ke ke wa bapala ka dithoye tsa hao. Ke kopa o itokisetse ho ya robala.”

SourceText: Child: "But that is not fair!"
text: Ngwana: “Empa hase hantle!”

SourceText: Child: "But that is not fair. Waaaah!"
text: Ngwana: “Empa hase hantle! Waaaah!"

SourceText: Parent 1: "It is so nice to see that you got ready for bed all by yourself!"
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Ke thabela ho bona hore o itokiseditse ho ya robala o sa thuswe!”

SourceText: Child: "Now can I play with my toy car?"
text: Ngwana: “Na nka bapala ka koloi ya ka ya thoye?”

SourceText: Parent 1: "You can play with your car tomorrow. It is bedtime. Come, my sweetie, I will tell your favourite bedtime story."
text: Motswadi wa 1: “O ka bapala ka koloi ya hao hosane. Hona jwale ke nako ya ho robala. Tloo moshanyana ka, ke tlo o phetela pale eo o e ratang mantsiboyeng ana.”

SourceText: Parent 1: "Once upon a time..."
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Ba re enere..."

SourceText: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention
text: 1. Leka ho bontsha ngwana ntho e nngwe

SourceText: When they start demanding for something or whining, first try to redirect them to a positive behaviour or activity. Praise them for that positive behaviour!
text: Ha a qala ho batla kapa ho llela ntho e itseng, o qale ka ho leka ho mo bontsha hore na boitshwaro kapa ketso e nepahetseng ke efe. Mo babatse ha a itshwara ka tsela e nepahetseng!

SourceText: These are behaviours like whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child. But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!
text: Ke boitshwaro bo kang ho lla, ho tseka dintho, ho ipitsetsa mahlo, ho ithabukanya le ditsela tse ding tse ngata tse fosahetseng tsa ho bitsa mahlo a batho le ho batla dintho tse etsang hore re nahane hore ngwana ke ngwana e mobe. Empa ha ho na bana ba babe, ke feela boitshwaro bo thatafatsang dintho!

SourceText: When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.
text: Ha o iphapanyetsa boitshwaro ba ngwana wa hao (empa eseng ngwana wa hao!), ngwana wa hao o ithuta hore ho rata ho tseka dintho ha ho sebetse.

SourceText: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way.
text: Haeba boitshwaro bona ba bona bo re ama, bana ba rona ba tla ithuta hore re tla etsa ho hong ha ba itshwara ka tsela eo. Ka dinako tse ding ba ithuta hore ha ba batla dintho tse ngata, re tla phethisa ditakatso tsa bona.

SourceText: This takes time AND patience. Normally your child will try to test you and behave worse. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.
text: Ho hlokeha nako LE mamello. Hangata ngwana wa hao o tla batla ho o leka ebe o itshwara hampe le ho feta. Ena ke nako e ntle ya ho Nka Khefu le ho Dula o Kgobile Matshwafo.

SourceText: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times
text: 6. Tiisa hore o fa ngwana wa hao nako e ngata ha a etsa dintho tse ntle ka dinako tse ding

SourceText: Children need attention. If children get plenty of attention for just being themselves, as well as for the “good” things that they do, it helps them to feel good about themselves, and they do more of what they are asked.
text: Bana ba hloka nako. Haeba bana ba fuwa nako e ngata ka lebaka la seo ba leng sona, hammoho le ka lebaka la dintho tse “ntle” tseo ba di etsang, seo se ba thusa hore ba ikutlwe ba thabile, ebile ba tla etsa boiteko ba ho phethisa seo ba se kopuwang.

SourceText: Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.
text: Boitshwro ba ngwana wa hao bo ka tswela pele ho mpefala.  Ho bohlokwa hore o tswele pele ho iphapanyetsa boitshwaro bo jwalo.

SourceText: Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.
text: Hangata ngwana wa hao o tla teneha le ho feta ha o qala ho iphapanyetsa boitshwaro bo itseng ba hae moo ngwana a batlang ho leka boikemisetso ba hao.

SourceText: If you find yourself ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, it is either because you are not being consistent (sometimes ignoring and sometimes giving in) OR you are not spending enough positive time with your child. One-on-One Time is super important!
text: Haeba o iphumana o iphapanyetsa boitshwaro ba ngwana wa hao haholo, mohlomong ke hobane o sa etse dintho ka tsela e sa fetoheng (ka dinako tse ding o iphapanya mme ka dinako tse ding o inehela) KAPA ha o qete nako e lekaneng le etsa dintho tse molemo le ngwana wa hao. Ho bohlokwa ka ho fetisisa ho ba le Nako ya Boinotsing!

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to use ignore to reduce tantrums or other difficult behaviours:
text: Ka kopo kgetha palo e nngwe haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka ho sebedisa mokgwa wa ho iphapanya ho fokotsa ho ithabukanya kapa boitshwaro bo bong bo o thatafalletsang bophelo:

SourceText: Ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining or tantrums. Your @fields.child_nickname’s behaviour might at first get worse, but with time they will learn that it does not work. Be consistent and patient. And make sure that you are also giving @fields.child_nickname plenty of positive attention at other times. You can do it!
text: Iphapanyetse mekgwa e mebe ya ho ipitsetsa mahlo le ho tseka dintho jwaloka ho di llela kapa ho ithabukanya. Boitshwaro ba @fields.child_nickname bo ka nna ba mpefala qalong, empa ha nako e ntse e feta o tla ithuta hore boitshwaro boo ha bo sebetse. Etsa dintho ka tsela e tsitsitseng mme o be le mamello. Hape tiisa hore o fa @fields.child_nickname nako e ngata le etsa dintho tse molemo ka dinako tse ding. O ka atleha!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

Be consistent and patient. And make sure that you are also giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times. You can do it!
text: Iphapanyetse mekgwa e mebe ya ho ipitsetsa mahlo le ho tseka dintho jwaloka ho di llela kapa ho ithabukanya. Boitshwaro ba ngwana wa hao bo ka nna ba mpefala qalong, empa ha nako e ntse e feta o tla ithuta hore boitshwaro boo ha bo sebetse. Etsa dintho ka tsela e tsitsitseng mme o be le mamello. Hape tiisa hore o fa ngwana wa hao  nako e ngata le etsa dintho tse molemo ka dinako tse ding. O ka atleha!

SourceText: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child.
text: 3. Iphapanyetse boitshwaro eseng ngwana wa hao.

SourceText: Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention. You should still be aware of what @fields.child_nickname is doing.
text: Ho iphapanyetsa boitshwaro ho bolela ho tloha sebakeng se itseng le ho bua ntho e bontshang hore o o tenne. O ntse o lokela ho bona hore na @fields.child_nickname o etsang.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention. You should still be aware of what your child is doing.
text: Ho iphapanyetsa boitshwaro ho bolela ho tloha sebakeng se itseng le ho bua ntho e bontshang hore o o tenne. O ntse o lokela ho bona hore na ngwana wa hao o etsang.

SourceText: For example, if @fields.child_nickname whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to @fields.child_nickname when they start to have a tantrum. This happens to all of us!
text: Ka mohlala, haeba @fields.child_nickname a llela dipompong lebenkeleng, qalong o ka nna wa re “tjhe” empa wa inehela ha @fields.child_nickname a qala ho ithabukanya. Sena sea re etsahalla kaofela!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum. This happens to all of us!
text: Ka mohlala, haeba ngwna wa hao a llela dipompong lebenkeleng, qalong o ka nna wa re “tjhe” empa wa inehela ha ngwana wa hao a qala ho ithabukanya. Sena sea re etsahalla kaofela!

SourceText: Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give @fields.child_nickname plenty of positive attention and love as soon as they have calmed down.
text: Ho ithabukanya ho ka o sithabetsa le ho ba thata ho ngwana wa hao feela kamoo ho leng kateng ho wena. Tiisa hore o fa @fields.child_nickname nako e ngata le etsa dintho tse molemo esita le ho mo bontsha lerato hang ha a thola.

SourceText: Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give your child plenty of positive attention and love as soon as they have calmed down.
text: Ho ithabukanya ho ka o sithabetsa le ho ba thata ho ngwana wa hao feela kamoo ho leng kateng ho wena. Tiisa hore o fa ngwana wa hao nako e ngata le etsa dintho tse molemo esita le ho mo bontsha lerato hang ha a thola.

SourceText: At this time, it is more important that you involve @fields.child_nickname in a positive activity instead of talking about what just happened. You can do that later like at night or the next day. Right now @fields.child_nickname needs love.
text: Ka nako eo, ho bohlokwa haholo hore o kenyelletse @fields.child_nickname ha le etsa dintho tse thabisang ho fapana le ho bua ka se qetang ho etsahala. O ka bua ka ntho eo hamorao bosiung boo kapa letsatsing le hlahlamang. Hona jwale @fields.child_nickname o hloka lerato.

SourceText: Today's Parenting Tip is all about Praise. How did the above message make you feel? We all appreciate it when the good things we do are recognised by others, especially when it is someone who is close to us.
text: Keletso ya Botswadi ya kajeno e anana le Pabatso. Molaetsa o ka hodimo o entse hore o ikutlwe jwang? Kaofela rea thaba ha batho ba bang ba elellwa mesebetsi ya rona e metle, haholoholo ha e le motho eo re nang le kamano e haufi le yena.

SourceText: Praise your children when they are behaving well! They may not show it but you’ll see them doing that good behaviour again…
text: Babatsa bana ba hao ha ba itshwara hantle! Ba ka nna ba se bontshe empa o tla ba bona ba itshwara hantle hape…

SourceText: Hi @fields.user_name! I just wanted to thank you for making this commitment to improve the life of your children. It shows you really care!

SourceText: Hi! I just wanted to thank you for making this commitment to improve the life of your children. It shows you really care!
text: Dumela! Ke laktsa ho o leboha ka boikemisetso bona ba hao ba ho ntlafatsa bophelo ba bana ba hao. Seo se bontsha hore kannete o a ba tsotella!

SourceText: Keep it positive! Make sure your children get lots of praise when they are behaving well. This will make them want to behave that way more often.
text: Bua ka ntho e lokelang ho etswa! Tiisa hore o babatsa bana ba hao haholo ha ba itshwara hantle! Seo se tla etsa hore ba itshware hantle ka tsela eo le ho feta ka makgetlo a mangata.

SourceText: We all appreciate it when the good things we do are recognised by others, especially when it is someone who is close to us.
text: Kaofela rea thaba ha batho ba bang ba elellwa mesebetsi ya rona e metle, haholoholo ha e le motho eo re nang le kamano e haufi le yena.

SourceText: Praise works for our children, too. When you bring more attention to positive behaviour, they are likely to do it more often. They also will feel good about themselves!
text: Pabatso e ka thusa esita le bana ba rona. Ha o totobatsa boitshwaro ba bona bo botle haholo, ba tla itshwara ka tsela e tshwanang le ho feta. Hape seo se tla ba tsosa morolo!

SourceText: Here are 3 simple steps to get it right:
text: Bona mehato ena e 3 e bonolo e ka o thusang hore o atlehe:

SourceText: 1. Be positive
text: 1. Bua hantle

SourceText: 2. Be specific
text: 2. Toba taba!

SourceText: 3. Be enthusiastic
text: 3. Bontsha tjheseho

SourceText: To learn more about one of these steps, type "1" to "3". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Hore o ithute haholwanyane ka mehato ena, thaepa “1” ho ya ho “3”. Hape o ka thaepa “N” ho emisa keletso ena.

SourceText: Step 3. Be enthusiastic
text: Mohato wa 3. Bontsha tjheseho

SourceText: Really mean it when you say it! The more real you are the better it will feel.
text: Ba bolelle se hlileng se leng pelong ya hao! Dintho di tla ntlafala ha o dula o ba bolelle se hlileng se leng pelong ya hao.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about praise:
text: Ka kopo kgetha palo e nngwe haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka ho pabatso:

SourceText: Here is a comic on praising your child.
text: Ena ke tsela ya boswaswi ya ho babatsa ngwana wa hao.

SourceText: Here is a comic on praising your teen.
text: Ena ke tsela ya boswaswi ya ho babatsa motjha wa hao.

SourceText: Parent: “Thank you for being quiet while I talked to my boss. I appreciate it! Here, you can use my phone to WhatsApp your friends”
text: Motswadi: “Kea leboha hore ebe o ile wa thola ha ke ntse ke bua le mookamedi wa ka. Ke leboha haholo! Nka founo ya ka ke ena o bue le metswalle ya hao ka WhatsApp”

SourceText: Teen: “Thanks! I really want to see how they are doing.”
text: Motjha: “Kea leboha! Kannete bona ke ba hlolohetswe ebile ke lekatsa ho tseba hore na ba ntse ba ya jwang.”

SourceText: Silence
text: Ho a thola

SourceText: Parent: “Thank you for playing quietly while I was doing work. In 5 minutes I will be able to join you.”
text: Motswadi: “Kea leboha hore ebe o ile wa bapala o thotse ha ke ntse ke sebetsa. Ke tlo bapala le wena kamora metsotso e 5.”

SourceText: Parent: “I really appreciate you playing quietly together while I worked. Now I can play with you for a bit. What would you like to do?”
text: Motswadi: “Kannete kea leboha hore ebe le ile la bapala le thotse ha ke ntse ke sebetsa. Jwale ke tlo bapala le lona hanyane. Na o ka thabela ho etsang?”

SourceText: Challenges are stressful. But problem-solving can really help. There are 6 basic steps for problem solving:
text: Diphephetso di baka seterese! Empa ho molemo haholo ho tseba ho rarolla mathata. Ho na le mehato e 6 e bonolo ya ho rarolla mathata:

SourceText: 1. Identify the problem
text: 1. Hlwaya bothata

SourceText: 2. Think of possible solutions
text: 2. Nahana ka mekgwa e ka sebetsang ya ho bo rarolla

SourceText: 3. Figure out what the results of each solution would be
text: 3. Nahana hore na tharollo ka nngwe e tla fella ka eng

SourceText: 4. Choose one solution
text: 4. Kgetha tharollo e le nngwe

SourceText: 5. Try it out!
text: 5. E leke!

SourceText: 6. Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution
text: 6. Na seo se sebeditse? Re thaba le wena! Haeba e sa sebetsa, leka tharollo e nngwe

SourceText: We can also teach our children the same steps.
text: Le rona re ka ruta bana ba rona mehato yona eo.

SourceText: When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame our children. But what they really need is someone to help them work through their problems.
text: Ha ntho e mpe e etsahala, hangata re halefela le ho beha bana ba rona molato. Empa hantle ntle seo ba se hlokang ke motho ya ka ba thusang ho sebetsana le mathata a bona.

SourceText: Take a Pause! Become aware of anger and stress. Take a deep breath or count to 10 before you react. Then respond in a calmer way.
text: Nka Kgefu! Elellwa kgalefo le seterese. Hemela hodimo mme o bale ka makgetlo a 10 pele o nka bohato. Arabela o kgobile matshwafo.

SourceText: Help @fields.child_nickname learn how to solve problems. As children get older, they become more independent and sometimes push the boundaries that we create to keep them safe.
text: Thusa @fields.child_nickname a ithute tsela ya ho rarolla mathata. Ha bana ba ntse ba hola, ba lokoloha haholo mme ka dinako tse ding ba batla ho tlosa meedi eo re ba behetseng yona ho ba sireletsa.

SourceText: Try to redirect. Stop it before it starts! When your children get restless, you can distract them with something interesting or fun: "Come, let's play a game together!"
text: Leka ho ba kgutlisetsa tseleng. E thibele pele e qala! Ha bana ba hao ba hloka botsitso, o ka kgutlisetsa tseleng ka ntho e thahasellisang kapa e ba thabisang: “Tlo re tlo bapala game hammoho!”

SourceText: If your baby is starting to crawl or walk, you can also redirect them by physically picking them up and focusing their attention on something else interesting. Use a lively and cheerful voice!
text: Haeba lesea la hao le qala ho kgasa kapa ho tsamaya, o ka boela wa le kgutlisetsa tselang ka ho le nka le ho le bontsha ntho e nngwe e thahasellisang. Sebedisa lentswe le mahlahahlaha le le thabileng!

SourceText: Here is a comic that shows how you can use redirect!

SourceText: Child: “Give it to me!”
text: Ngwana: “Mphe yona!”

SourceText: Teen: “I had it first!”
text: Motjha: “Ke e nkile pele!”

SourceText: Parent: “Cameron and Billy, come and help me prepare dinner. We are making your favourite dish!”
text: Motswadi: “Thabo le Thabang, tlong le tlo nthusa ho lokisa dijo. Re pheha dijo tseo le di ratang!”

SourceText: Parent: “Thank you for helping me get these veggies clean for our dinner tonight!”
text: Motswadi: “Kea leboha hore ebe le nthusitse ho hlwekisa meroho eo re tlo e ja dijong tsa mantsiboya!”

SourceText: Keep it positive. It is normal to want to say something about @fields.child_nickname's negative behaviour, like “Don’t whine,” or “Stop running in the house.” Instead, just say something that you want @fields.child_nickname to do, like "Speak with a calm voice," or "Remember to walk inside the house."

SourceText: Keep it positive. It is normal to want to say something about your child's negative behaviour, like “Don’t whine,” or “Stop running in the house.” Instead, just say something that you want your child to do, like "Speak with a calm voice," or "Remember to walk inside the house."
text: Bua ka ntho e lokelang ho etswa. SourceText: We are now spending a lot more time online. Being connected helps us stay positive…but it also presents risks and dangers.
text: Jwale re qeta nako e ngata haholo inthaneteng. Ho ba inthaneteng ho ka re thusa ho dula re nahana dintho tse ntle…empa ho boetse ho na le maraba le dikotsi.

SourceText: Here are 5 tips that can help you keep yourself safe online:

text: 3. Qalang mekgwa o molemo le e bolokileng inthaneteng

SourceText: 1. Learn about risks and dangers

SourceText: Keep personal information private, especially from strangers. – some people are not who they say they are!

SourceText: You can also create healthy and safe online habits like creating device-free spaces and times in your house (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).

SourceText: Remember that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).

SourceText: Here are some tips for sharing books with your child:
text: Bona tse ding tsa dikeletso tsa ho adimana ka dibuka le ngwana wa hao:

SourceText: 1. Follow your child's interest
text: 1. Tseba dintho tseo ngwana wa hao a di thahasellang

SourceText: 2. Use a lifely voice
text: 2. Sebedisa lentswe le sehlahlo

SourceText: 3. Pointing and naming
text: 3. Ho supa le ho reha mabitso

SourceText: 4. Be positive and supportive
text: 4. Bua dintho tse molemo mme o tshehetse

SourceText: 5. Making actions and links
text: 5. Ho etsa diketso tse itseng le ho amahanya

SourceText: 6. Talking about feelings
text: 6. Ho bua ka maikutlo

SourceText: 7. Babies and books go well together
text: 7. Masea le dibuka ke mathe le leleme

SourceText: 2. Use a lively voice
text: 2. Sebedisa lentswe le sehlahlo

SourceText: Speak with a lively or animated voice. This will help to keep the child’s attention on the book.
text: Bua ka lentswe le sehlahlo le le bontshang thabo. Sena se etsa hore ngwana a tsepamise mohopolo bukeng.

SourceText: 7. Babies and Books!
text: 7. Masea le Dibuka!

SourceText: Even very young babies enjoy book-sharing and looking at the pictures together with a parent or caregiver. In fact, regular book-sharing helps their development and learning. And it is okay for them to put the book in their mouth - they are exploring!
text: Esita le masea a manyane haholo a rata ho kadimana ka dibuka le ho sheba ditshwantsho mmoho le motswadi kapa mohlokomedi. Hantlentle ho kadimana ka dibuka ho ba thusa ho hola le ho ithuta. Ebile ha ho na bothata haeba a beha buka molomong - ke kamoo a ithutang kateng!

SourceText: Here are some examples!
text: Mehlala e meng ke ena!

SourceText: “Look, she is smiling. Why do you think she is smiling? What made you smile today?”
text: “Bona, o a bososela. O nahana hore ke hobaneng ha a bososela? Ke eng e entseng hore o bososele kajeno?”

SourceText: “The monkey is sad because he is all on his own. Can you remember when you were last sad?”
text: “Tshwene e kwatile hobane e dutse e le nngwe. Na o sa hopola la ho qetela ha o ne o kwatile?”

SourceText: “That tiger looks angry. Why do you think he is angry? Do you remember when I got angry this morning?”
text: “Nkwe ena e bonahala e halefile. O nahana hore ke hobaneng ha e halefile? Na o sa hopola ha ke ne ke kwatile hoseng?”

SourceText: Well done! You have added another layer to your House of Support! Over the next few days, try to spend some time reading or looking at a book or magazine with your child. Sharing books with your child will help them to learn to speak, think, and focus better. It also builds their brain!
text: Mosebetsi o tswileng matsoho! O ekeditse mokato o mong Ntlong ya hao ya Tshehetso! Matsatsing a seng makae a tlang, leka ho qeta nako o bala kapa o shebile buka kapa makasine le ngwana wa hao. SourceText: Pointing to and naming an object or person in the book will help @fields.child_nickname learn new words. Children learn through repetition, so repeat the word and look for other opportunities to use the word (in the book or elsewhere).

SourceText: Connect things in the book with familiar things in @fields.child_nickname’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask @fields.child_nickname to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and @fields.child_nickname can do the same.

SourceText: Connect things in the book with familiar things in your child’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask your child to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and your child can do the same.
text: Amahanya dintho tse bukeng le dintho tseo ngwana wa hao a di bonang hangata bophelong. Ka mohlala, haeba ngwana ya bukeng a rwetse dieta, kopa ngwana wa hao hore a supe dieta tsa hae. Haeba motho ya bukeng a tsoka letsoko, wena le ngwana wa hao le ka etsa se tshwanang.

SourceText: Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about @fields.child_nickname’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.
text: Dibuka ke tsela e ntle haholo eo bana ba ka ithutang haholwanyane ka maikutlo. O ka sebedisa sefahleho le lentswe ho mo thusa ho utlwisisa maikutlo a mantswe a kang ho thaba, ho hlonama, ho halefa, kapa ho tshoha. O ka sebedisa se etsahalang bukeng ha o bua ka maikutlo a @fields.child_nickname ka sebele, le lebaka le ka etsang hore batho ba ikutlwe ka tsela e itseng.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about your child’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.
text: Dibuka ke tsela e ntle haholo eo bana ba ka ithutang haholwanyane ka maikutlo. O ka sebedisa sefahleho le lentswe ho mo thusa ho utlwisisa maikutlo a mantswe a kang ho thaba, ho hlonama, ho halefa, kapa ho tshoha. O ka sebedisa se etsahalang bukeng ha o bua ka maikutlo a ngwana wa hao ka sebele, le lebaka le ka etsang hore batho ba ikutlwe ka tsela e itseng.

SourceText: Millions of families are struggling to make ends meet. When money is tight, this can make us feel anxious, stressed, and sad. How we understand and talk about money with our children is important. Our children can also help us to spend and save in ways that will benefit the family.
text: Malapa a dimilione a sokola ho iphedisa. Ha tjhelete e lekane ditlhoko feela, seo se ka etsa hore re ikutlwe re tshwenyehile, re imetswe ebile re halefile. Tsela eo re utlwisisang le ho bua ka tjhelete ka yona le bana ba rona e bohlokwa. Bana ba rona ba ka boela ba re thusa ho sebedisa le ho baballa tjhelete ka ditsela tseo lelapa le tla fumana  melemo ka tsona.

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you want this tip at another time. Chat to you later @fields.user_name!
text: O ska kgathatseha! Ka dinako tsohle o ka thaepa “Thuso” neng kapa neng haeba o batla keletso ena ka nako e nngwe. Ke tla bua le wena hamorao @fields.user_name!

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you want this tip at another time. Chat to you later!
text: O ska kgathatseha! Ka dinako tsohle o ka thaepa “Thuso” neng kapa neng haeba o batla keletso ena ka nako e nngwe. Ke tla bua le wena hamorao!

SourceText: Millions of families are struggling to make ends meet. When money is tight, this can make us feel anxious, stressed, and sad. How we understand and talk about money is important. We can also learn about how we can save in ways that will benefit the family.
text: Malapa a dimilione a sokola ho iphedisa. Ha tjhelete e lekane ditlhoko feela, seo se ka etsa hore re ikutlwe re tshwenyehile, re imetswe ebile re halefile. Tsela eo re utlwisisang le ho bua ka tjhelete ka yona e bohlokwa. Hape re ka ithuta ho boloka tjhelete ka ditsela tseo lelapa le ka fumanang molemo ka tsona.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you make a budget and save money together as a family.
text: Shebella video ena e tla o thusa ho etsa bajete le ho baballa tjhelete mmoho le le lelapa.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you make a budget and save money together as a family.
text: Mamela molaetsa ona o mamelwang ho o thusa ho etsa bajete le ho baballa tjhelete mmoho le le lelapa.

SourceText: Making a budget.
text: Ho etsa bajete.

SourceText: A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times. Making a budget can help you have enough at the end of the month so that you need to borrow less.
text: Bajete ke hore na re etsa qeto ya ho sebedisa tjhelete e kae, esita le dinakong tse boima. Ho etsa bajete ho ka le thusa hore le be le tjhelete e lekaneng ho fihlela bofelong ba kgwedi e le hore le se ke la tlameha ho kadima tjhelete e ngata.

SourceText: Do you want 4 quick steps to help you make a budget and save money?
text: Na o thabela ho fumana mehato e 4 ka potlako e ka o thusang ho etsa bajete le ho baballa tjhelete?

SourceText: Step 1: What do we spend on now?
text: Mohato wa 1: Hona jwale re sebedisa tjhelete ha re reka eng?

SourceText: • Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen.
text: • Fumana pampiri (kapa koranta ya kgale kapa khateboto) le pene.

SourceText: • Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
text: • Toroya ditshwantsho tsa dintho tsohle tseo wena le lelapa le sebedisang tjhelete ho tsona kgwedi ka nngwe.

SourceText: • Write next to each picture how much each thing costs.
text: • Ngola pela setshwantsho ka seng hore na ntho ka nngwe e ja bokae.

SourceText: • Add up how much money you have to spend each month.
text: • Kopanya hore na ke tjhelete e kae eo o e sebedisang kgwedi le kgwedi.

SourceText: Do you want to receive Step 2?
text: Na o ka rata ho fumana Mohato wa 2?

SourceText: Step 2: Talk about needs and wants
text: Mohato wa 2: Buisanang ka dintho tseo le di hlokang le tseo le di batlang.

SourceText: • Needs: Which things are important or must haves for your family to survive? (like food, soap to wash hands, needs for ill or disabled family members).
text: • Dintho tseo le di hlokang: Ke dintho dife tsa bohlokwa kapa tseo lelapa le tlamehang ho ba le tsona hore le phele? (dintho tse kang dijo, sesesa sa ho hlapa matsoho, dintho tseo ba lelapa ba kulang kapa ba holofetseng ba di hlokang).

SourceText: • Wants: Which things are nice to have but not essential?
text: • Dintho tseo le di batlang: Ke dintho dife tseo le ka ratang ho ba le tsona empa ese tsa bohlokwa?

SourceText: Do you want to receive Step 3?
text: Na o ka rata ho fumana Mohato wa 3?

SourceText: Step 3: Build your own budget
text: Mohato wa 3: Haha bajete ya hao

SourceText: • Find a bag of stones or anything with lots of bits. This is your money for the month.
text: • Fumana mokotla wa majwe kapa eng kapa eng e nang le ditjhelete tse ngata tsa tshepe. Ena ke tjhelete ya hao ya kgwedi.

SourceText: • As a family, decide what you will spend on what, and put the stones on your picture.
text: • Le le lalapa, etsa qeto ya hore na le tla sebedisa bokae ho reka eng, mme le behe majwe setshwantshong ka seng.

SourceText: • If you can save even a tiny amount for the future, or for an emergency  – it can make a big difference over time.
text: • Haeba le ka boloka tjhelete e nyane bakeng sa kamoso, kapa bakeng sa boemo ba tshohanyetso – ha nako e tse e feta, seo se ka etsa phapang e kgolo.

SourceText: Do you want to receive Step 4?
text: Na o ka rata ho fumana Mohato wa 4?

SourceText: Step 4: Find out where you can get extra help
text: Mohato wa 4: Fumana ng hore na le ka fuwa thuso e eketsehileng hokae

SourceText: Your government or community groups may be giving money, vouchers, or food parcels to families in need. Ask about whether places in your community are giving support.
text: Mmuso wa heno kapa dihlopha motseng wa heno di ka nna tsa fana ka tjhelete, divaotjhara kapa diphuthelwana tsa dijo ho malapa a hlokang. Botsa hore na ho na le dibaka tse fanang ka diphallelo motseng wa heno.

SourceText: Well done for adding another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Over the next few days, try following these steps to create a family budget. You can even involve your partner in the discussion. Millions of families find that learning ways to manage money as a family reduces family arguments and brings everyone together. That's real success!
text: O sebeditse ka ho eketsa boiphihlelo bo bong Mokotleng wa hao wa Dithulusi tsa Botswadi! Matsatsing a seng makae a tlang, leka ho latela mehato ena ha o etsa bajete ya lelapa. O ka ba wa kenyelletsa molekane wa hao dipuisanong tseo. Malapa a dimilione a fumane hore ho ithuta ditsela tsa ho laola tjhelete e le lelapa ho fokotsa dikgang ka lapeng ebile ho momahanya lelapa. Eo ke yona katleho ya sebele!

SourceText: Well done for adding another layer to your House of Support! Over the next few days, try following these steps to create a family budget. You can even involve your partner in the discussion. Millions of families find that learning ways to manage money as a family reduces family arguments and brings everyone together. That's real success!
text: O sebeditse ka ho eketsa mokato o mong Ntlong ya hao ya Tshehetso! Matsatsing a seng makae a tlang, leka ho latela mehato ena ha o etsa bajete ya lelapa. O ka ba wa kenyelletsa molekane wa hao dipuisanong tseo. Malapa a dimilione a fumane hore ho ithuta ditsela tsa ho laola tjhelete e le lelapa ho fokotsa dikgang ka lapeng ebile ho momahanya lelapa. Eo ke yona katleho ya sebele!

SourceText: Millions of families are struggling to make ends meet especially due to the COVID-19 pandemic. When money is tight, this can make us feel anxious, stressed, and sad. How we understand and talk about money with our children is important. Our children can also help us to spend and save in ways that will benefit the family.
text: Malapa a dimilione a iphedisa ka thata haholoholo nakong ena ya sewa sa COVID-19. Ha tjhelete e lekane ditlhoko feela, seo se ka etsa hore re ikutlwe re tshwenyehile, re imetswe ebile re halefile. Tsela eo re utlwisisang le ho bua ka tjhelete ka yona le bana ba rona e bohlokwa. Bana ba rona ba ka boela ba re thusa ho sebedisa le ho baballa tjhelete ka ditsela tseo lelapa le tla fumana  melemo ka tsona.

SourceText: Making a budget with your children and teens.
text: Ho etsa bajete le bana le batjha ba hao.

SourceText: A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times. Making a budget together helps children understand that we all need to make hard decisions in difficult times. It can also help you have enough at the end of the month so that you need to borrow less.
text: Bajete ke hore na re etsa qeto ya ho sebedisa tjhelete e kae, esita le dinakong tse boima. Ho etsa bajete e kopanetsweng ho thusa bana ho utlwisisa hore ka dinako tse ding, kaofela re tlameha ho etsa diqeto tse boima. Hape ho ka le thusa hore le be le tjhelete e lekaneng ho fihlela bofelong ba kgwedi e le hore le se ke la tlameha ho kadima tjhelete e ngata.

SourceText: Do you want 4 quick steps to help you make a budget and save money with your children?
text: Na o thabela ho fumana mehato e 4 ka potlako e ka o thusang ho etsa bajete le ho baballa tjhelete le bana ba hao?

SourceText: • Discuss with your children what things you could try to spend less on as a family.
text: • Buisana le bana ba hao ka dintho tseo le ka di lekang hore le sebedise tjhelete e fokolang le le lalapa.

SourceText: Well done for adding another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Over the next few days, try following these steps by involving your child in creating a family budget. Millions of families find that learning ways to manage money as a family reduces family arguments and brings everyone together. That's real success!
text: O sebeditse ka ho eketsa boiphihlelo bo bong Mokotleng wa hao wa Dithulusi tsa Botswadi! Matsatsing a seng makae a tlang, leka ho latela mehato ena ka ho kenyelletsa bana ha ho etswa bajete ya lelapa. Malapa a dimilione a fumane hore ho ithuta ditsela tsa ho laola tjhelete e le lelapa ho fokotsa dikgang ka lapeng ebile ho momahanya lelapa. Eo ke yona katleho ya sebele!

SourceText: Well done for adding another layer to your House of Support! Over the next few days, try following these steps by involving your child in creating a family budget. Millions of families find that learning ways to manage money as a family reduces family arguments and brings everyone together. That's real success!
text: O sebeditse ka ho eketsa mokato o mong Ntlong ya hao ya Tshehetso! Matsatsing a seng makae a tlang, leka ho latela mehato ena ka ho kenyelletsa bana ha ho etswa bajete ya lelapa. Malapa a dimilione a fumane hore ho ithuta ditsela tsa ho laola tjhelete e le lelapa ho fokotsa dikgang ka lapeng ebile ho momahanya lelapa. Eo ke yona katleho ya sebele!

SourceText: Create routines! Your children will feel more secure and safe when they know what is expected of them and how each day will go. Make a plan with them with time for play, meals, chores, school, and sleep.
text: Eba le mananeo a ho etsa dintho! Bana ba hao ba ikutlwa ba sireletsehile ebile ba bolokehile haholo haeba ba tseba hore na ho lebeletswe eng ho bona le hore na letsatsi ka leng le tla tsamaya jwang. Rala dintho le bona mme moralo oo o kenyelletse nako ya ho bapala, ya dijo, ya mesebetsi, ya sekolo le ya ho robala.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you create daily routines with your children.
text: Shebella video ena ho o thusa ho etsa mananeo a letsatsi le letsatsi le bana ba hao.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you create daily routines with your children.
text: Mamela molaetsa ona o mamelwang ho o thusa ho etsa mananeo a letsatsi le letsatsi le bana ba hao.

SourceText: Daily routines, such as time for schoolwork, play, meals, and sleep, can help our children feel safe and secure. They also give our children a sense of security.
text: Mananeo a letsatsi le letsatsi, jwaloka nako ya mosebetsi wa sekolo, ho bapala, dijo, le ho robala, a ka thusa bana hore ba ikutlwe ba bolokehile ebile ba sireletsehile. Hape a etsa hore bana ba bona hore ho na le tshireletso.

SourceText: Here are 4 simple tips that you can use when establishing routines with your children:
text: Bona mehato ena e bonolo e 4 eo o ka e sebedisang ho qala mananeo le bana ba hao:

SourceText: 1. Give one instruction at a time
text: 1. Fana ka taelo e le nngwe ka nako

SourceText: 2. Use transition warnings to help move from one activity to the next one
text: 2. Sebedisa ditemoso tsa hore ho tla ba le phetoho ho ba thusa ho tloha mosebetsing o mong ho ya ho o mong

SourceText: 3. Create regular eating and sleeping times
text: 3. Eba le dinako tse tsitsitseng tsa kamehla tsa ho ja le ho robala

SourceText: 4. Involve your teen in creating daily routines
text: 4. Kenyelletsa motjha wa hao ha o etsa mananeo a letsatsi le letsatsi

SourceText: To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to 4". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Hore o ithute haholwanyane ka dikeletso tsena, thaepa “1” ho ya ho “4”. Hape o ka thaepa “N” ho emisa keletso ena.

SourceText: 1. Help your younger children learn routines by taking them through the activity step by step. Give one instruction at a time. Praise them each time they follow!
text: 1. Thusa bana ba hao ba banyane ho ithuta mananeo ka ho ba phethisa mosebetsi mohato ka mohato. Fana ka taelo e le nngwe ka nako. Ba babatse nako le nako ha ba latela ditaelo!

SourceText: 2. Transition warnings can also be very helpful. They give your child some time to prepare for the next activity: "In 5 minutes it will be time to pack up the toys before bedtime…"
text: 2. Hape ho ka ba molemo haholo ho fana ka ditemoso tsa ho fetola mosebetsi. Di fa ngana nako ya ho itokisetsa mosebetsi o latelang: “Ho setse metsotso e 5, e tla be e le nako ya ho phutha dithoye pele le ilo robala…”

SourceText: 3. Regular eating and sleeping times are especially important for babies. Not enough sleep can make your child cranky, irritable, and short tempered.
text: 3. Ho bohlokwa haholo ho masea ho ba le dinako tse tshwanang tsa ho ja le ho robala. Haeba lesea la hao le sa robale hantle, seo se ka le etsa ngwana ya llang, ya kgopisehang le wa sefelapelwana.

SourceText: Here are some tips for how to help your child prepare for bedtime:
text: Bona dikeletso tsa kamoo o ka thusang ngwana wa hao ho itokisetsa ho ya robala:

SourceText: • Try to have regular bedtimes each day as much as possible.
text: • Ha ho kgoneha leka ho ba le nako e tshwanang ya ho robala letsatsi le letsatsi.

SourceText: • Try to make it quiet and the lights in the room dim.
text: • Leka ho etsa hore kamore ebe e kgutsitseng mme mabone a be lerootho.

SourceText: • Spend some time with your child. You can sing a lullaby or tell a calm story.
text: • Qeta nako e itseng le ngwana wa hao. O ka bina pina e koiettsang kapa wa pheta pale e thobang maikutlo.

SourceText: • Give your child a hug and kiss goodnight before leaving the room.
text: • O hake ngwana wa hao le ho mo suna hore a robale hantle pele o tswa ka kamoreng eo a robetseng ho yona.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about creating daily routines:
text: Ka kopo kgetha palo e nngwe haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka ho qala mananeo a letsatsi le letsatsi:

SourceText: 4, Involve your teen in creating daily routines
text: 4. Kenyelletsa motjha wa hao ha o etsa mananeo a letsatsi le letsatsi

SourceText: Here are some suggestions for routines that you could establish with your children:
text: Bona tse ding tsa dikeletso tsa ho etsa mananeo ao o ka a thehang le bana ba hao:

SourceText: Bedtime
text: Nako ya ho robala

SourceText: Schoolwork and Online Classes
text: Mosebetsi wa Sekolo le Ditlelase tsa Inthaneteng

SourceText: Chores
text: Mesebetsi

SourceText: Mealtime
text: Nako ya dijo

SourceText: Play/free time
text: Nako ya ho bapala/ya ho se etse letho

SourceText: T.V. or gadget time
text: Nako ya T.V. kapa sesebediswa

SourceText: Storytime
text: Nako ya dipale

SourceText: One-on-One Time
text: Nako ya Boinotsing

SourceText: You can add more, too! Here is a comic on creating a daily routine with your child.
text: O ka kenya le tse ding! Ena ke tsela ya boswaswi ya ho etsa lenaneo la letsatsi le letsatsi le ngwana wa hao.

SourceText: Parent: “Now let’s look at the multiplication tables…”
text: Motswadi: “Jwale a re shebe ditheibole tsa ho thaemesa…”

SourceText: Parent: “Thank you for helping me make lunch, Junior”
text: Motswadi: “Kea leboha ka hore o nthuse ka dijo tsa motshehare, Junior”

SourceText: Child: “My favourite!”
text: Ngwana: “Ke dijo tseo ke di ratang!”

SourceText: Parent “And they all lived happily ever after…Goodnight, my love.”
text: Motswadi “Mme kamora moo kaofela ba ile ba phela ba thabile…O robale hamonate, ngwanaka!”

SourceText: Parent: "Thank you for being so supportive with the kids today.”
text: Motswadi: “Kea leboha ka hore o nthuse hakaalo ka bana kajeno.”

SourceText: 4. Involve @fields.child_nickname in creating daily plans. Set goals and rewards together. Let them plan when they do schoolwork and when they can relax!
text: 4. Kenyelletsa @fields.child_nickname ha o qala etsa meralo ya letsatsi le letsatsi. Behang dipakane le meputso mmoho. Ba tlohele hore ba etse moralo wa hore na ba tla etsa mosebetsi wa sekolo neng hona ba phomole neng!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: 4. Involve your teen in creating daily plans. Set goals and rewards together. Let them plan when they do schoolwork and when they can relax!
text: 4. Kenyelletsa motjha wa hao ha o etsa mananeo a letsatsi le letsatsi Behang dipakane le meputso mmoho. Ba tlohele hore ba etse moralo wa hore na ba tla etsa mosebetsi wa sekolo neng hona ba phomole neng!

SourceText: I am sorry it did not go well. How did your child respond?
text: Ke maswabi hore dintho ha dia ka tsa tsamaya hantle. Ngwana wa hao o ile a arabela jwang?

SourceText: Being specific is not rude or insensitive, it really helps others understand you clearly and prevents confusion in the family. Emotions like anger and stress are part of our lives. All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is know how to handle it by taking a few deep breaths before responding.
text: Ho toba taba hase ho tella kapa ho se nahanele maikutlo a batho ba bang, hantlentle ho thusa ba bang ho o utlwisisa ka ho hlakileng le ho qoba pherekano ka lapeng. Maikutlo a kang kgalefo le seterese ke karolo ya bophelo ba rona. Seo re tlamehang ho se etsa ha re ikutlwa re halefile ebile re na le seterese ke ho tseba tsela ya ho sebetsana le boemo ka ho phefumulohela hodimo ka makgetlo a seng makae pele re arabela.

SourceText: It’s okay to not want to share at that time. Find some time later on when you feel calmer to explain so that everyone can understand.
text: Ho lokile ho se batle ho bua ka nako eo. Fumana nako e nngwe hamorao ha o ikutlwa o theotse moya ho hlalosa e le hore bohle ba ka utlwisisa.

SourceText: Sharing emotions – especially the difficult ones – sets an important example for your child or teen ! It actually makes everyone in the family stronger, because you can understand and support each other better.
text: Ho bolela maikutlo – haholoholo a boima – ho beha mohlala wa bohlokwa bakeng sa ngwana kapa motjha wa hao! Hantlentle seo se etsa hore bohle ka lapeng baa be matla, hobane le ka utlwisisana le ho tshehetsana hantle.

SourceText: Sharing emotions is about explaining how you are feeling so @fields.child_nickname is aware and learns to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It’s up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later: “I am feeling angry/stressed now, can you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight”.
text: Ho pheta maikutlo ho amana le ho hlalosa hore na o ikutlwa jwang e le hore @fields.child_nicknamea lemohe le ho ithuta ho etsa se tshwanang. O ka kgetha hore na ke dintlha tse kae tseo o tla mo phetela tsona ka boemo. Ho ya ka wena! Hape o ka kgetha karabo ya dipotso hamorao: “Ke ikutlwa ke halefile/ke imetswe maikutlong hona jwale, ke kopa o ke o mphe nako? Re ka bua ka taba eo hape mantsiboya”.

SourceText: Sharing emotions is about explaining how you are feeling so your child or teen  is aware and learns to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It’s up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later: “I am feeling angry/stressed now, can you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight”.
text: Ho pheta maikutlo ho amana le ho hlalosa hore na o ikutlwa jwang e le hore ngwana kapa motjha wa hao a lemohe le ho ithuta ho etsa se tshwanang. O ka kgetha hore na ke dintlha tse kae tseo o tla mo phetela tsona ka boemo. Ho ya ka wena! SourceText: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it, and keep giving the good example by noticing and sharing emotions. Over time, @fields.child_nickname will learn to do the same – and they will feel even more loved and cared for.
text: Hangata qalong ho thata ho qala ntho e ntjha. Iphe nako ya ho e tlwaela, mme o nne o behe mohlala o motle ka ho lemoha maikutlo le ho a phetela ba bang. Ha nako e ntse e feta, @fields.child_nickname o tla ithuta ho etsa se tshwanang – mme o tla ikutlwa a ratwa ebile a hlokomelwa haholo.

SourceText: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it, and keep giving the good example by noticing and sharing emotions. Over time, your child or teen  will learn to do the same – and they will feel even more loved and cared for.
text: Hangata qalong ho thata ho qala ntho e ntjha. Iphe nako ya ho e tlwaela, mme o nne o behe mohlala o motle ka ho lemoha maikutlo le ho a phetela ba bang. Ha nako e ntse e feta, ngwana kapa motjha wa hao o tla ithuta ho etsa se tshwanang – mme o tla ikutlwa a ratwa ebile a hlokomelwa haholo.

SourceText: 1. Treat each other as equals
text: 1. Tshwaranang jwaloka batho ba lekanang

SourceText: Family and friends might tell you how a husband or a father should act. But both men and women benefit when they talk to each other and make decisions together! For example, next time you’re making a decision, try involving your partner and ask what they think.
text: Ba lelapa le metswalle ba ka bolela kamoo monna kapa ntate a etsang dintho kateng. Empa bobedi banna le basadi ba fumana molemo ha ba buisana le ho etsa diqeto mmoho! Ka mohlala, nakong e tlang ha o etsa diqeto, leka ho kenyelletsa molekane wa hao le ho mo botsa hore na o nahana jwang.

SourceText: Family and friends might tell you how a wife or a mother should act compared to a husband or father.  But both men and women benefit when they talk to each other and make decisions together! For example, next time you’re making a decision, try involving your partner and ask what they think.
text: Ba lelapa le metswalle ba ka bolela kamoo mosadi kapa mme a lokelang ho etsa dintho kateng ha ho bapiswa le monna kapa ntate.  Empa bobedi banna le basadi ba fumana molemo ha ba buisana le ho etsa diqeto mmoho! Ka mohlala, nakong e tlang ha o etsa diqeto, leka ho kenyelletsa molekane wa hao le ho mo botsa hore na o nahana jwang.

SourceText: Family and friends might tell you how a partner or a parent should act. But both men and women benefit when they talk to each other and make decisions together! For example, next time you’re making a decision, try involving your partner and ask what they think.
text: Ba lelapa le metswalle ba ka bolela kamoo molekane kapa motswadi a etsang dintho kateng. Empa bobedi banna le basadi ba fumana molemo ha ba buisana le ho etsa diqeto mmoho! Ka mohlala, nakong e tlang ha o etsa diqeto, leka ho kenyelletsa molekane wa hao le ho mo botsa hore na o nahana jwang.

SourceText: Would you like to see a comic about treating each other as equals?
text: Na o ka rata ho bona tsela ya boswaswi ya ho tshwarana jwaloka batho ba lekanang?

SourceText: Parent 1: “My dear, you look worried. What’s wrong?”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Ratu, ekare o kgathatsehile. “Molato ke eng?”

SourceText: Parent 2: “The stove has not been working very well recently. I think the stove might be broken.”
text: Motswadi wa 2: “Morao tjena setofo sena ha se sebetse hantle. Ke nahana hore e tlameha ebe se robehile.”

SourceText: Parent 1: “I noticed this too when I was cooking last week. I wanted to ask you: do you think we should buy a new one?”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Le nna ke lemohile taba ena bekeng e fetileng ha ke pheha. E re nke ke o botse: na o nahana hore re reke setofo se setjha?”

SourceText: Parent 2: “Buying a new one would be really expensive. How about we talk about it after dinner, and we can make a decision together?
text: Motswadi wa 2: “Setofo se setjha se turu haholo. Ho tla ba jwang hore re buisane ka taba ena kamora tinare, hore re tle re etse qeto eo hammoho?

SourceText: Parent 1: “That sounds great. Thank you for cooking dinner, my dear!”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Moo ke dumellana le wena. Ke lebohela ka hore o phehe dijo tsa tinare hle ratu!”

SourceText: Parent 1: “I am grateful we can talk about this and make this decision together. It makes a lot more sense to try to get it repaired first.”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Kea leboha hore re buile ka taba ena le ho etsa qeto mmoho. Ehlile ke ntho e utlwahalang hore se ke se lokiswe pele.”

SourceText: Parent 2: “Me too. I feel a lot better now that we have talked about it together.”
text: Motswadi wa 2: “Le nna ke bona jwalo. Ke utlwa eka ke betere kamora hore re buisane ka taba ena re le babedi.”

SourceText: When mothers and fathers are both engaged with the parenting of their children, everyone benefits, including the children! Show your partner that you appreciate it when they spend quality time with your children.
text: Ha mme le ntate ba tshwarisane mojaro wa kgodiso ya bana, bohle, ho akarelletsa le bana ba fumana melemo! Bontsha molekane wa hao hore o ananela nako eo a e qetang a etsa dintho tsa bohlokwa le bana ba lona.

SourceText: Would you like to see a comic about becoming a confident parent and a supportive partner?
text: Na o ka thabela ho bona tsela ya boswaswi ya ho ba motswadi ya nang le boitshepo le molekane ya tshehetsang molekane wa hae?

SourceText: Parent 1: “Good job, Jessie! You are reading very well!”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “O etsa mosebetsi o babatsehang, Lerato! Kannete o bala hamonate!”

SourceText: Parent 2: “The weather today is so nice. It is a shame I have not had time to go outside for a walk.”
text: Motswadi wa 2: “Kajeno lehodimo le apohile hamonate. Ke feela hore ha ke so fumane nako ya ho thapolla maoto kantle.”

SourceText: Parent 1: “If you would like to get some fresh air and exercise, my dear, I can continue helping the children with their homework while you go for your afternoon walk.”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Ratu, haeba o ka thabela ho hahlwa ke moya o phodileng le ho ya ikwetlisa, nka tswela pele ho thusa bana ka mesebetsi ya bona ya sekolo ha o ntse o thapolla maoto kantle thapameng ena.”

SourceText: Parent 2: “That would be wonderful, my love! Thank you for being so supportive.”
text: Motswadi wa 2: “Nka thaba jwang rato la ka! Kea leboha ka hore o nthuse hakana.”

SourceText: Parent 1: “Of course! It is fun to help the children with their reading practice! They are doing so well.”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Kannete! Ho monate ho thusa bana ha ba prakthisa ho bala! Ba sebetsa hantle haholo.”

SourceText: Sharing family responsibilities with your partner can make life less stressful! Can you think of ways you can share the workload? Doing tasks together can also make them more fun!
text: Ho jarisana mesebetsi ya lelapa le molekane wa hao ho ka fokotsa seterese bophelong! Na ho na le ditsela tseo o nahanang hore o ka kenya letsoho ka tsona mosebetsing wa katlung? Hape ho etsa mesebetsi mmoho ekaba ntho e monate!

SourceText: Would you like to see a comic about sharing family responsibilities?
text: Na o ka thabela ho bona tsela ya boswaswi ya ho jarisana mesebetsi ya lelapa?

SourceText: Child: “Wow, there are so many clothes in here!”
text: Ngwana: “Kgele, ho na le diphahlo tse ngata hakaakang!”

SourceText: Parent 1: “You’re right, Kyle, there is quite a lot to do.”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Ehlile di ngata haholo wena Bohlokwa.”

SourceText: Parent 1: “If we do it together it will take less time!”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Empa re tla nka nako e kgutshwane haeba re di etsa mmoho!”

SourceText: Parent 1: “Doing tasks together is also fun”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Hape ho monate ho sebetsa mmoho”

SourceText: Parent 2: “Thank you, my love. Sharing the workload makes it less stressful.”
text: Motswadi wa 2: Kea leboha, rato la ka. Ho jarisana mosebetsi ho fokotsa seterese.”

SourceText: All adults have disagreements sometimes. But solving issues through fighting is not effective. Instead, if you start feeling angry, walk away for a bit or take a deep breath before responding in a calmer way.
text: Batho bohle ba baholo ha ba dumellane ka dinako tse ding. Empa ho rarolla ditaba ka ho lwana ha ho atlehe. Ho fapana le moo, haeba o ikutlwa o tlallana ke bohale, tloha sebakeng seo hanyane kapa o phefumulohele hodimo pele o araba ka tsela e kgutsitseng.

SourceText: Would you like to see a comic about resolving conflict peacefully?
text: Na o ka rata ho bona tsela ya boswaswui ya ho rarolla kgohlano ka tsela e nang le kgotso?

SourceText: Parent 1: “Dinner is ready!”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Tinare e lokile!”

SourceText: Child: “Look, it is raining so much outside!”
text: Ngwana: “Bona, ho na pula ya ditlwebelele kantle!”

SourceText: Parent 1: “I am glad you brought in the laundry earlier, my dear. Otherwise, it would have been soaked by now!”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Kea leboha hore ebe o ile wa phutha washene ka nako, ratu. Ho seng jwalo di ka be di kolobile hona jwale!”

SourceText: Parent 1: “I thought you said you would bring in the laundry today?”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Ke nahana hore o itse o tla hleka washene kajeno.”

SourceText: Parent 1: “No, I was busy cooking dinner! You told me you would take care of it! How could you forget? Now all the laundry is wet!”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Ha kea kgona, ke ne ke phathahane ke lokisa dijo tsa mantsiboya! O itse o tla e hlokomela. Ho tlile jwang hore o e lebale? Jwale washene yohle e metsi!”

SourceText: Parent 2: “I’m really sorry. It was a mistake!”
text: Motswadi wa 2: “Ao, ntshwarele hle. Ke entse phoso!”

SourceText: Parent 1(thinking): I can’t believe he forgot! But everyone can make mistakes. Take a deep breath…
text: Motswadi wa 1 (o a nahana): Ha ke dumelae hore o lebetse! Empa batho bohle ba etsa diphoso. Phefumulohela hodimo…

SourceText: Parent 1: “I’m sorry if I sounded upset. I just got stressed because I have had a long day.”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “O ntshwarele ha ke utlwahetse ke kwatile. Ke ne ke imetswe ke ditaba tsa letsatsi la kajeno.”

SourceText: Parent 2: “I am sorry that I forgot the laundry. I know you have had a long day. I will make sure to take care of it after dinner.”
text: Motswadi wa 2: “O ntshwarele ha ke lebetse washene. Kea tseba hore dintho ha dia tsamaya hantle kajeno. Empa ke tla e phothoma kamora tinare.”

SourceText: Listening and talking to those around us is key to a more peaceful home. Talking to your partner about issues before they become problems can help avoid arguments from building up.
text: Tsela le atlehang ya hore ho be le kgotso ka malapeng a rona ke ka ho mamela le ho bua le batho bao re dulang le bona. Ho buisana le molekane wa hao ka ditaba pele eba mathata ho ka le qobisa dikgang le pele di qala.

SourceText: Parent 1: “Are you okay, my love? You look tired.”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Ho ntse ho ya jwang, moratuwa? O bonahala o kgathetse.”

SourceText: Parent 2: “I didn’t sleep well last night and so I am feeling quite tired.”
text: Motswadi wa 2: “Ha kea robala hantle bosiung bo fetileng mme jwale ke ikutlwa ke kgathetse tjena.”

SourceText: Parent 1: “I am sorry to hear that, Amir. Is there anything I can do to help?”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Ke maswabi ho utlwa seo, Thabiso. Ebe nka o thusa jwang?”

SourceText: Parent 2: “I might try and get an earlier rest this evening.”
text: Motswadi wa 2: “Nka nna ka leka ho ya robala ka nako mantsiboyeng ana.”

SourceText: Parent 1: “I can take over the children’s bedtime routine after dinner tonight, so that you can get some extra rest.”
text: Motswadi wa 1: “Ke tla hlokomela bana ka dintho tseo ba di etsang pele ba ilo robala kamora tinare kajeno, e le hore o ka phomola ka ho lekaneng.”

SourceText: Parent 2: “That would be lovely. Thank you so much, my dear.”
text: Motswadi wa 2: “Tseo ke ditaba tse monate. Ke leboha ha holo hle ratu.”

SourceText: Would you like to see a comic about listening and talking to each other?
text: Na o ka rata ho shebella tsela ya boswaswi ya ho mamelana le ho buisana?

SourceText: First, we can find ways to encourage our children to behave well more often. Spending One-on-One Time with them is an important first step!
text: Ntlha ya pele, re ka fumana ditsela tsa ho kgothalletsa bana ba rona ho itshwara hantle hangata. Ho qeta Nako ya Boinotshing le bona ke bohato ba pele!

SourceText: Second, we can learn effective ways to manage difficult behaviours in a loving but firm way.
text: Ntla ya bobedi, re ka ithuta ditsela tse atlehang tsa ho laola boitshwaro bo ka re thatafalletsang bophelo ka tsela e lerato empa re tiisitse ka hanong.

SourceText: There are 2 main ways that we can do to help our children behave positively more often.
text: Ho na le ditsela tse ka sehloohong tse 2 tseo re ka thusang bana ba rona hore ba itshware hantle le ho feta kgafetsa.

SourceText: Hi! Have you tried to talk to your partner about your feelings and any difficulties you are facing recently?
text: Dumela! Na morao tjee o lekile ho buisana le molekane wa hao ka maikutlo a hao le ka mathata afe kapa afe ao le tobaneng le wona?

SourceText: Good for you! Talking about challenges and our emotions can be hard. How was your experience?
text: Re thaba le wena! Ho ka ba thata ho bua ka mathata le maikutlo a rona. Ho tsamaile jwang?

SourceText: Sharing how we feel and talking about the difficulties we’re facing actually makes everyone in the family stronger! By sharing emotions you can better understand and support each other.
text: Ho bolela kamoo re ikutlwang kateng le ho bua ka mathata ao re tobaneng le wona ho ka matlafatsa bohle ka lapeng! Re na le monyetla o motle wa ho utlwisisana le ho tshehetsana haeba re bolellana maikutlo a rona.

SourceText: Sharing your emotions or difficulties you are facing is about making others more aware of how you are feeling. You get to decide how much you want to share. You can also choose to share more at a later time.
text: Ho bolela maikutlo a hao kapa mathata ao o tobaneng le wona ho amana le ho tsebisa batho ba bang kamoo o ikutlwang kateng. Ke wena ya etsa qeto ya hore na o tla ba bolella dintlha tse kae. O ka boela wa kgetha ho ba bolella tse ding hamorao.

SourceText: Talking about our feelings or challenges we’re facing can help others understand and support you better. Emotions and challenges are a part of life and learning how to handle these can help you avoid conflict with loved ones and make life less stressful.
text: Ho bua ka baikutlo kapa diphephetso tseo re tobaneng le tsona ho ka thusa batho ba bang ho re utlwisisa le ho re tshehetsa hantle. Maikutlo le diphephetso ke karolo ya bophelo mme ho ithuta ho sebetsana le tsona ho ka o qobisa dikgohlano le batho bao o ba ratang mme ha fokotsa seterese bophelong.

SourceText: Starting something new can be difficult. Give yourself and others time to get used to it. By setting a good example by sharing your emotions and challenges you’re facing others will feel start to feel more comfortable sharing too.
text: Ho qala ntho e ntjha ho ka ba thata! Iphe nako ya ho e tlwaela mme o fe le ba bang nako e jwalo. Ka ho beha mohlala o motle wa ho bolela maikutlo le diphephetso tseo o tobaneng le tsona, ba bang ba tla ikutlwa kapa ba tla qala ho ikutlwa ba phutholohile hore le bona ba bolele kamoo ba ikutlwang kateng.

SourceText: It’s okay if you don’t want to share at that time. You can choose to share how you’re feeling at a later time once you feel calmer.
text: Ho lokile ha o sa batle ho bua ka nako eo. O ka kgetha ho bolella batho ba bang kamoo o ikutlwang kateng hamorao ha o ikutlwa o theotse moya.

SourceText: We are sorry to hear that. What was hard for you when talking about your feelings and challenges you are facing?
text: Re maswabi ho utlwa seo. Ke eng e o thatafalletseng ha o bua ka maikutlo le diphephetso tseo o tobaneng le tsona?

SourceText: I am sorry to hear that. What was hard for you when talking about your feelings and challenges you are facing?
text: Ke maswabi ho utlwa seo. Ke eng e o thatafalletseng ha o bua ka maikutlo le diphephetso tseo o tobaneng le tsona?

SourceText: It can be hard sometime to remember. Next time you spend one-on-one time, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. You can even say “thank you for spending time with me!”.
text: Ka dinako tse ding ho boima ho hopola. Nakong e tlang ha o qeta nako ya boinotsing, leka ho nahana ka ntho e le nngwe eo o ka mo babatsang ka yona. O ka ba wa re “kea leboha ka hore o qete nako le nna!”

SourceText: No problem, try to notice how they respond next time!
text: Ha ho na bothata, leka ho lemoha kamoo a arabelang kateng nakong e tlang!

text: Jwale bana le batjha ba rona ba qeta nako e ngata haholo inthaneteng. Ho ba inthaneteng ho ka ba thusa ho dula re nahana dintho tse ntle…empa ho boetse ho na le maraba le dikotsi.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you keep your children safe online.
text: Shebella video ena e tla o thusa ho sireletsa bana ba hao inthaneteng.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you keep your children safe online.
text: Mamela molaetsa ona o mamelwang o tla o thusa ho sireletsa bana ba hao inthaneteng.

SourceText: Here are 6 tips that can help you keep your children safe online:
text: Latela mehato ena e 6 e ka o thusa ho sireletsa bana ba hao inthaneteng:

SourceText: 4. Spend time with your child online
text: 4. • Qeta nako le ngwana wa hao inthaneteng.

SourceText: 5. Build open communication
text: 5. Ba phetlele sefuba ha o buisana le bona

SourceText: 6. Report and seek help
text: 6. Tlaleha mme o kope thuso

SourceText: • Adults targeting children for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.
text: • Batho ba baholo ba tsomang bana ka merero ya thobalano ho social media, moo ba bapalang dipapadi, le dipolatefomong tsa ho romela melaetsa.

SourceText: • Teens sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos of themselves.
text: • Batjha ba abang tlhahisoleseding ya botho le dinepe kapa divideo tsa bona tsa thobalano.

SourceText: • Cyberbullying from other young people and strangers.
text: • Ho tellwa ke batjha ba bang le batho o sa ba tsebeng inthaneteng.

SourceText: 2. Tech fixes to protect your children online:
text: 2. Maiteko a ho lokisa mathata ka theknoloji ya ho sireletsa bana ba hao inthaneteng:

SourceText: This does not mean we should ban our children from spending time online. It just means that we need to learn how to protect them in a new world.
text: Sena hase bolele hore re lokela ho thibela bana ba rona ho qeta nako inthaneteng. Sena se bolela feela hore re tlameha ho ithuta tsela ya ho ba sireletsa lefatsheng lena le letjha.

SourceText: 5. Build open communication and trusting relationships
text: 5. Buisanang ka ho phetlelana difuba mme le hahe dikamano tsa ho tshepana

SourceText: Tell your children that if they experience something online (or anywhere) that makes them feel upset, uncomfortable, or scared, they can talk to you and you will not get mad or punish them.
text: Bolella bana ba hao hore haeba ba kopana le boemo bo itseng inthaneteng (le kae kapa kae) bo ba halefisang, bo etsang hore ba ikutlwe ba sa phutholoha, kapa ba tshohile, ba ka buisana le wena mme o ke ke wa ba halefela kapa wa ba fa kotlo.

SourceText: Report to INHOPE Hotlines and IWF portals and the Child Helpline in your country to get support if you or your children experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.
text: Tlaleha ho di-Hotline tsa INHOPE le ho diphothale tsa IWF le mohaleng wa Child Helpline naheng ya heno ho fumana tshehetso ha wena kapa ngwana wa hao le tshwarwa ka dikgoka inthaneteng kapa ha ho etsahala dintho tse ding tse sa amoheleheng.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn another way to protect your child online:
text: Ka kopo kgetha palo e nngwe haeba o batla ho tsela e nngwe ya ho sireletsa ngwana wa hao inthaneteng:

SourceText: Here is a comic on discussing online activities with your child
text: Ena ke tsela ya boswaswi ya ho buisana ka dintho tse etsahalang inthaneteng le ngwana wa hao

SourceText: Parent: "Shani, have you done your homework?"
text: Motswadi: “Nthabiseng, na o se o qetile homeweke ya hao?”

SourceText: Child: "Just a minute, I'm finishing this tiktok video"
text: Ngwana: “Ke kopa motsotso o le mong feeka, ke qetela video ya tiktok”

SourceText: Parent: "You are a really great dancer! Tell me about why you like it."
text: Motswadi: “Ka tantshi, o tswa pele ngwana ka! Ako mpolelle hore na ke hobaneng ha o rata tantshi hakana.”

SourceText: Child: "All my friends are on it. I have more than 600 likes and 120 followers."
text: Ngwana: “Metswalle ya ka kaofela e rata tantshi. Ke na le barati ba fetang 600 le balatedi ba 120.”

SourceText: Parent: "I’m proud of how well you dance, Joey. But we need to make sure you are safe on this. I know your friends look at TikTok, but with an open account there are also paedophiles who look at videos of teenagers. Paedophiles are older people who want to attack young children and teens."
text: Motswadi: “Ke ikotla sefuba ka tsela eo o tantshang ka yona, Lebohang. Empa re tlameha ho tiisa hore o sireletsehile ha o tantsha. Kea tseba hore metswalle ya hao e rata TiTok, empa ho na le batho ba hlanyetsang bana ba batlang divideo tsa batjha. Batho ba hlanyetsang bana ke batho ba baholo ba ratang ho etsa thobalano le bana le batjha.”

SourceText: Parent: "Let’s look together online at how we can keep this fun for you but also safe. Look – you can make your account private and control who follows you. So you can accept people you know but not strangers. Can we make a rule together that you can use TikTok but with a private account? I trust you to know who to accept!"
text: Motswadi: “Ke kopa ho kena le wena inthaneteng mme re bone hore re ka etsang ho tiisa hore o tantsha hamonate ebile o sireletsehile. Bona – o ka etsa hore akhaonte ya hao e be ya poraefete mme wa laola batho ba o latelang. O ka amohela batho bao o ba tsebang eseng bao o sa ba tsebeng. Ke kopa hore nna le wena re dumellane hore ka molao molao wa hore o ka sebedisa TikTok hafeela e le akhaonte ya poraefete? Ke tshepa hore o a tseba hore na ke bomang bao o ka ba amohelang!”

SourceText: Parent: "I’m proud of you Shalini..."
text: Motswadi: "Ke ikotla sefuba ka wena Nthabi..."

SourceText: Involve @fields.child_nickname in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.
text: Kenyelletsa @fields.child_nickname ha le theha ditumellano tsa theknoloji tsa lelapa tse amanang le tsela e sireletsehileng ya ho sebedisa sesebediswa sa elektronike.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Create device-free spaces and times in your house
text: Qalang dinako tseo ho sa sebedisweng disebediswa le dinako tsa ho ba katlung

SourceText: (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).
text: (ya ho ja, ho bapala, ho etsa mosebetsi wa sekolo le ho robala).

SourceText: Child tech agreement: https://www.esafety.gov.au/sites/default/files/2020-01/Our%20Family%20Tech%20Agreement_0.pdf

SourceText: Involve your child or teen in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.
text: Kenyelletsa motjha wa hao ha le theha ditumellano tsa theknoloji tsa lelapa tse amanang le tsela e sireletsehileng ya ho sebedisa sesebediswa sa elektronike.

SourceText: Help @fields.child_nickname learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers – some people are not who they say they are!
text: Thusa @fields.child_nickname ho ithuta tsela ya ho sireletsa tlhahisoleseding ya lekunutu, haholoholo ho batho bao o sa ba tsebeng – batho ba bang ha ba seo ba ipolelang hore ba sona!
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Remind your children that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).
text: Hopotsa bana ba hao hore se kenang inthaneteng se dula inthaneteng (melaetsa, difoto le divideo).

SourceText: Actively supervise children’s time online, including computers, smartphones, and tablets.
text: Beha bana ba hao leihlo le ntjhotjho nakong eoo ba keneng inthaneteng, dikhomphiyutheng, dismatefounong le dithebleteng.

SourceText: Help your child learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers – some people are not who they say they are!
text: Thusa ngwana wa hao ho ithuta tsela ya ho sireletsa tlhahisoleseding ya lekunutu, haholoholo ho batho bao o sa ba tsebeng – batho ba bang ha ba seo ba ipolelang hore ba sona!

SourceText: 4. Spend time with your child or teen online
text: 4. Qeta nako le ngwana kapa motjha wa hao inthaneteng

SourceText: Get to know how @fields.child_nickname experiences the digital world.
text: Tseba hore na @fields.child_nickname o ntse a ya jwang ha a sebedisa thepa ya dijithale.

SourceText: Explore websites, social media, games, and apps together.

SourceText: Talk to your teen on how to report things that aren't OK.
text: Buisana le motjha wa hao ka tsela ya ho tlaleha dintho tse sa tsamayeng hantle.

SourceText: Common Sense Media has great advice for apps, games and entertainment for different ages.

SourceText: It‘s hard to feel positive when our kids or teenagers are driving us crazy. We often end up saying “Stop doing that!” But children are much more likely to do what we ask if we give them positive instructions and lots of praise for what they do right.
text: Ho thata ho ikutlwa hantle ha bana kapa batjha ba rona ba re kopanya dikelello. Hangata re qetella re itse “Tlohela ntho eo o e etsang!” Empa menyetla ya hore bana ba etse seo re ba kopang sona e mengata haeba re ba fa ditaelo tsa seo ba lokelang ho se etsa ebile re ba babatsa ha ba entse se nepahetseng.

SourceText: Here's a positive video to help you get your children to follow your instructions more often!
text: Shebella video ena e molemo e ka o thusang ho tiisa hore bana ba hao ba latela ditaelo tsa hao haholo!

SourceText: Here's a positive audio message to help you get your children to follow your instructions more often!
text: Mamela molaetsa ona o molemo o ka o thusang ho tiisa hore bana ba hao ba latela ditaelo tsa hao haholo!

SourceText: Here are 4 steps to help you get your children to follow your instructions more often:
text: Latela mehato ena e 4 e ka o thusang ho tiisa hore bana ba hao ba latela ditaelo tsa hao haholo!

SourceText: 1. Get their attention
text: 1. E re ba o mamele

SourceText: 2. Be positive, specific, and realistic
text: 2. Bua hantle, toba taba mme o bue ntho e utlwahalang

SourceText: 3. One instruction at a time
text: 3. Taelo e le nngwe ka nako

SourceText: 4. Praise them for doing it!
text: 4. Ba babatse ha ba phethile taelo ya hao!

SourceText: To learn more about one of these steps, type "1" to "4". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Hore o ithute haholwanyane ka mehato ena, thaepa “1” ho ya ho “4”. Hape o ka thaepa “N” ho emisa keletso ena.

SourceText: Step 3. Give Instructions One at a Time
text: Mohato wa 3. Fana ka Ditaelo E le Nngwe ka Nako

SourceText: Children are much more likely to do what you ask if you break things up into smaller steps.
text: Ho na le menyetla e mengata ya hore bana ba etse seo o ba kopang sona haeba o beha ditaba ka mehato e menyane.

SourceText: Step 4. Praise Your Children When They Follow Instructions
text: Mohato wa 4. Babatsa Bana ba Hao ha ba Latela Ditaelo

SourceText: They will feel good about it and be more likely to follow instructions in the future!
text: Ba tla ikutlwa ba thabetse seo mme menyetla ya hore ba latele ditaelo kamoso e tla ba mengata!

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to get your children to follow instructions more often:
text: Ka kopo kgetha palo e nngwe haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka tsela ya ho tiisa hore bana ba hao ba latela ditaelo haholwanyane:

SourceText: Can your child actually do what you are asking them? It is very hard for a child to keep quiet inside for a whole day but maybe they can keep quiet for 15 minutes.
text: Na ehlile ngwana wa hao o etsa seo o mo kopang sona? Ho thata haholo hore ngwana a dule a kgutsitse kahare letsatsi lohle empa mohlomong a ka dula a thotse ka metsotso e 15.

SourceText: Here is a comic on using positive words and praise with your teen.
text: Bona tsela ya boswaswi ya ho sebedisa mantswe a molemo le a thoriso ka motjha wa hao.

SourceText: Teen: “Can I watch some T.V. after dinner?”
text: Motjha: “Na nka shebella T.V. kamora tinare?”

SourceText: Parent: “When you clear the table, you can watch an hour of T.V.”
text: Motswadi: “Ha o hlwekisitse tafole, o ka shebella T.V. ka hora e le nngwe.”

SourceText: Parent: “I really appreciate it when you help clean up after dinner. Thank you, Dylan”
text: Motswadi: “Kannete kea leboha haele mona o nthusitse ho hlwekisa tinare. Kea leboha, . Ntswaki”

SourceText: Parent and teen watching T.V. together.
text: Motswadi le motjha ba shebeletse T.V. mmoho.

SourceText: Step 2. Be Specific, Positive, and Realistic!
text: Mohato wa 2. Toba Taba, Bua Hantle, mme o Bue Ntho e Utlwahalang!
