SourceText: Household rules can help keep our children safe from potential dangers both inside the house and in the community. They also help children to know what kind of behaviour is expected from them.
text: Melao ya lelapa e ka thusa bana ba rona hore ba sireletsehe dinthong tse ka bang kotsi ka tlung le setjhabeng. Hape e thusa bana ho tseba hore na ho lebelletswe boitshwaro ba mofuta ofe ho bona.

SourceText: Hello @fields.user_name! Today's Parenting Tip is about how we can involve our children in creating consistent household rules.
text: Dumela @fields.user_name! Keletso ya Botswadi ya kajeno e amana le kamoo re ka kenyelletsang bana ba rona ha re etsa melao ya lelapa e sa fetoheng.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Hello! Today's Parenting Tip is about how we can involve our children in creating consistent household rules.
text: Dumela! Keletso ya Botswadi ya kajeno e amana le kamoo re ka kenyelletsang bana ba rona ha re etsa melao ya lelapa e sa fetoheng.

SourceText: Household rules can help keep our children safe from potential dangers both inside the house and in the community. They also help children to know what kind of behaviour is expected from them.
text: Melao ya lelapa e ka thusa bana ba rona hore ba sireletsehe dinthong tse ka bang kotsi ka tlung le setjhabeng. Hape e thusa bana ho tseba hore na ho lebelletswe boitshwaro ba mofuta ofe ho bona.

SourceText: Here's an audio message on how you can involve your children in establishing household rules.
text: Mamela molaetsa ona o mamelwang wa kamoo o ka kenyelletsang bana ba hao ha le etsa melao ya lelapa.

SourceText: Here's is a video on how you can involve your children in establishing household rules.
text: Shebella video ena kamoo o ka kenyelletsang bana ba hao ha le etsa melao ya lelapa.

SourceText: Here are some simple tips on how you can make household rules with your children and teens:
text: Bona dikeletso tsena tse bonolo tsa kamoo o ka etsang melao ya lelapa o na le bana le batjha ba hao:

SourceText: • Involve your child in establishing household rules.
text: • Kenyelletsa ngwana wa hao ha o etsa melao ya lelapa.

SourceText: • Make your household rules clear and specific.
text: • Etsang melao ya lelapa la hao e hlakileng le e tobang taba.

SourceText: • Make sure your child understands the reasons why you are establishing a household rule.
text: • Tiisa hore ngwna wa hao o utlwisisa mabaka a hore na ke hobaneng ha ho etswa molao wa lelapa.

SourceText: • Make your household rules fair and realistic (just like instructions).
text: • Etsang melao ya lelapa e lokileng le e utlwahalang (jwaloka ditaelo).

SourceText: • Praise and simple incentives can help support your child in following a household rule.
text: • O ka tshehetsa ngwana wa hao hore a latele melao ka ho mo babatsa le ho mo fa dimpho ha a entse hantle.

SourceText: • Add only 1 household rule at a time.
text: • Eketsa molao o le 1 feela wa lelapa ka nako.

SourceText: Children and teens are spending a lot more time online. Here is a comic on how you can create safe and healthy online habits like scheduling time online and offline.
text: Bana le batjha ba rona ba qeta nako e ngata haholo inthaneteng. Ena ke tsela ya boswaswi ya kamoo le ka qalang mekgwa e bolokehileng le e molemo ya inthaneteng e jwaloka ho beha nako ya ho ba inthaneteng le ya ho se be inthaneteng.

SourceText: Parent: “Jack, you have been spending a lot of time on your tablet. Why do you think I am concerned about that?”
text: Motswadi: “Jack, o se o qetile nako e telele haholo o tshwere thebolete ya hao. O nahana hore ke hobaneng ha ke kgathatsehile ka taba eo?”

SourceText: Child: “Um…because I am not doing my schoolwork?”
text: Ngwana: “Em…hobane ha ke so etse mosebetsi wa ka wa sekolo?”

SourceText: Parent: “Yes, that is one reason. It is important that you make the time for your schoolwork. I also like seeing you being more active. Maybe we can make a household rule about gadget use. What do you think would be a fair limit each day?”
text: Motswadi: “E, leo ke le leng la mabaka. Ho bohlokwa hore o iphe nako ya ho etsa mosebetsi wa hao wa sekolo. Hape ke rata ho o bona o le mahlahahlaha haholo. Mohlomong re ka etsa molao wa lelapa o amanang le ho sebedisa dintho tse kang disematefouno. O nahana hore nako e lokileng eo re ka e qetang ka letsatsi ke e kae?”

SourceText: Child: “Um…two hours a day?”
text: Ngwana: “Em…dihora tse pedi ka letsatsi?”

SourceText: Parent: “Hmmm…I think that might be too much time. You have so much else to do every day.”
text: Motswadi: “Hmmm…ke nahana hore etlaba nako e ngata haholo eo. O na le mosebetsi o mong o mongata haholo oo o o etsang letsatsi le letsatsi.”

SourceText: Child: “How about one hour for fun and one hour for learning?
text: Ngwana: “Ho ka ba jwang ha ke qeta hora e le nngwe ya boithabiso le hora e le nngwe ya ho ithuta?

SourceText: Parent: “That sounds reasonable. I would also like you to do your schoolwork before using any gadgets. So from now on, the household rule is that you do your schoolwork before using gadgets and that you can have 1 hour for free time and 1 hour for educational activities. Okay?”
text: Motswadi: “Ke utlwa eka o bua ntho e utlwahalang. Hape nka thabela hore o etse mosebetsi wa sekolo pele o sebedisa disebediswa dife kapa dife tsa elektronike. Kahoo ho tloha jwale ho ya pele, molao wa lelapa ke hore o etsa mosebetsi wa hao wa sekolo pele o sebedisa disebediswa tsa elektronike ebile o ka nka hora nka hora e 1 ya ho itlosa bodutu le hora e 1 ya mesebetsi ya sekolo. Ho lokile?”

SourceText: Child: “Okay.”
text: Ngwana: Ho lokile.”

SourceText: Today's tip is about how we can help to protect our children.
text: Keletso ya kajeno e amana le kamoo re ka thusang ho sireletsa bana ba rona.

SourceText: The idea of talking to children about abuse can be scary. We don't know what to say. But there are some simple things that can help them understand when it is not OK to be touched, and that they can tell you if something ever happens.
text: Ekaba ntho e tshosang ho bua le bana ka tlhekefetso. Ha re tsebe hore na re reng. Empa ho na le dintho tse itseng tse bonolo tse ka ba thusang ho utlwisisa hore na ke neng moo ba SA lokelang ho tshwarwa, le hore ba ka o bolella haeba ho ka etsahala ntho e itseng.

SourceText: When you are walking or doing something together it can be easier to chat.
text: Ha le ntse le tsamaya kapa le etsa ntho e nngwe mmoho, ho ka ba bonolo ho buisana.

SourceText: Do you want to learn more about how to protect your child from abuse?
text: Na o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka tsla ya ho sireletsa ngwana wa hao hore a se ke a hlekefetswa?

SourceText: Here are 3 things that you should make sure your child knows to protect them from abuse:
text: Ho na le dintho tse 3 tseo o lokelang ho tiisa hore ngwana wa hao o a di tseba hore o mo sireletse hore a se ke a hlekefetswa:

SourceText: 1. Learn about private parts
text: 1. A ithute ka ditho tsa sephiring

SourceText: 2. Your body belongs to you
text: 2. Mmele wa hao ke wa hao

SourceText: 3. Bad secrets should be told
text: 3. Makunutu a mabe a lokela ho bolelwa

SourceText: Type "1" to "3" to learn more about these tips. Type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Thaepa “1” ho ya ho “3” hore o ithute haholwanyane ka dikeletso tsena. Thaepa “N” ho emisa keletso ena.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to protect your child from abuse:
text: Ka kopo kgetha palo e nngwe haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka tsela ya ho sireletsa ngwana wa hao hore a se ke a hlekefetswa:

SourceText: 3. Bad secrets should be told.
text: 3. Makunutu a mabe a lokela ho bolelwa.

SourceText: Your children should tell you if there is a secret that makes them feel worried. You will not be angry. Only nice secrets - like a surprise birthday party - should be kept secret.
text: Ngwana wa hao o lokela ho o bolella haeba ho na le lekunutu le etsang hore a ikutlwe a tshwenyehile. O ke ke wa mo kwatela. Ke makunutu a matle feela - jwaloka ho etsetsa motho phathi ya letsatsi la tswalo a sa tsebe - a lokelang ho dula e le lekunutu.

SourceText: The parts of their body that go under people's underwear or a swimsuit are private parts. It is not OK for other people to touch or to ask to look at them, or ask them to look at or touch theirs.
text: Dikarolo tsa mmele ya bona tse kenang kahara antapene kapa diaparo tsa ho sesa ke ditho tsa sephiring. Hase HANTLE hore batho ba bang ba di tshware kapa ba kope ho di bona, kapa o kope ho bona kapa ho tshwara tsa bana ba bang.

SourceText: If someone tries to touch your children's private parts they must say NO and tell a grown up that they trust.
text: Ha motho e mong a leka ho tshwara ditho tsa bana ba hao tsa sephiri ba lokela ho re HA KE BATLE mme ba bolelle motho e moholo eo ba mo tshepang.

SourceText: Stress from caregiving can make us angry. Here is how we can maintain control and keep calm.
text: Seterese se bakwang ke ho hlokomela batho ba bang se ka re halefisa. Ena ke tsela ya ho tiisa hore dintho di tlasa taolo le ho dula re kgobile matshwafo.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you maintain control and keep calm when you get angry.
text: Shebella video ena e tla o thusa ya ho tiisa hore dintho di tlasa taolo le ho dula re kgobile matshwafo ha o halefa.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you maintain control and keep calm when you get angry.
text: Mamela molaetsa ona o mamelwang o tla o thusa ya ho tiisa hore dintho di tlasa taolo le ho dula re kgobile matshwafo ha o halefa.

SourceText: Think about what makes you angry? When does it happen? How do you normally react?
text: Nahana hore na ke eng e o halefisang. Seo se etsahala neng? Hangata o arabela jwang?

SourceText: Prevent anger from starting in the first place. Get some sleep or rest when you are tired. Try to eat something when you are hungry. Ask someone for support when you are feeling alone.
text: Thibela kgalefo ho tloha ha e qala. Robala kapa o phomole ha o kgathetse. Leka ho ja ho hong ha o lapile. Kopa motho e mong hore a o tshehetse ha o jewa ke bodutu.

SourceText: Here are some things that can prevent bad things from happening when you are angry:
text: Tsena ke dintho tse ding tse ka thibelang dintho tse mpe ho etsahala ha o halefile:

SourceText: 1. Cut back on drinking alcohol or don’t drink, especially when the kids are awake.
text: 1. Fokotsa ho nwa jwala kapa o se ke wa nwa, haholoholo ha bana ba tsohile.

SourceText: 2. Do you have weapons or things that can be used to hurt others? Lock them up, hide them or take them out of the home.
text: 2. Na o na le dibetsa kapa dintho tse ka sebediswang ho lematsa batho ba bang? Di notlelle, di pate kapa di tlose lapeng.

SourceText: 3. It’s ok to have your children stay somewhere safe or take them to a place where they can get help.
text: 3. Ho lokile hore bana ba hao ba dule sebakeng se bolokehileng kapa ho ba isa moo ba ka fuwang thuso teng.

SourceText: It is completely normal to experience this challenge. Next time you feel yourself getting angry try to manage this by taking deep breaths in. This can allow you to relax and reduce stress, which can help with managing your emotions. Every time you do this, you increase your child's brain development!
text: Ho tlwaelehile hore batho ba kopane le bothata bo jwalo. Nakong e tlang ha o ikutlwa eka o a halefa, leka ho phefumulohela hodimo hore o kgone ho laola boemo. Sena se ka o thusa hore o phutholohe mme sa fokotsa seterese, e leng se ka o thusang ho laola maikutlo a hao. Nako le nako ha o etsa sena, o eketsa kgolo ya boko ba ngwana wa hao!

SourceText: Go somewhere else for 5 minutes to regain control of your emotions. If you have safe outdoor space, go outside. You can get through this!

text: Haeba o halefiswa ke hore ebe @fields.child_nickname ha a thole, ha ho phoso ho mo siya a kakaletse sebakeng se sireletsehileng, mohlomong kahara bethe ya masea, ebe o tloha pela hae hanyane. Sheba hore na @fields.child_nickname o ntse a ya jwang kamora metsotso e meng le e meng e 5-10.

SourceText: When you take care of yourself, you take care of your children. We all need to connect. Try to talk to friends, family, and other support networks every day. If it has been a while since you reached out to someone, do it now!
text: Ha o itlhokomela, o hlokomela bana ba hao. Motho ke motho ka batho. Leka ho buisana le metswalle, ba lelapa le batho ba bang ba ka o tshehetsang letsatsi le letsatsi. Haeba o se o qetile nako o sa buisane le motho e mong, bua le yena hona jwale!

SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are not having a good day. It is completely normal to be going through a difficult time now. Remember that you are not alone. Here is an activity that might also help...
text: Ke maswabi ho utlwa hore letsatsi la kajeno ha le o tsamaele hantle. Kannete ke ntho e tlwaelehileng ho ba le mathata nakong ena. Hopola hore ha o mong. O ka nna wa leka ho etsa tjena ho lokisa boemo...

SourceText: Make a list of healthy activities that you like to do. Here are some suggestions:
text: Etsa letoto la dintho tse molemo tseo o ka ratang ho di etsa. Bona tse ding tsa diletso ke tsena:

SourceText: • Listening to your favourite music
text: • Mamela mmino oo o o ratang

SourceText: • Going for a walk (if allowed)
text: • Ho thapolla maoto ka ho tsamaya kantle (haeba ho dumelletswe)

SourceText: • Doing some exercise
text: • Ho etsa boikwetliso bo itseng

SourceText: • Drinking a cup of tea by yourself
text: • Ho phoka tee o le mong

SourceText: • Calling up a friend
text: • Ho letsetsa motswalle

SourceText: • Singing, dancing, praying, or reading
text: • Ho bina, ho tantsha, ho rapela, kapa ho bala

SourceText: • Sitting in the sun with your eyes closed
text: • Ho ora letsatsi o kwetse mahlo

SourceText: • Watching your favourite T.V. show
text: • Ho shebella lenaneo leo o le ratang la T.V.

SourceText: Pick one and do it today!
text: Kgetha e le nngwe mme o e etse kajeno!

SourceText: We would love to learn more about how we can improve these messages. Would you be willing to chat with us about your experience? You will receive a free data voucher if you are contacted for an interview!
text: Re lakatsa ho ithuta haholwanyane ka hore na re ka ntlafatsa melaetsa ena jwang. Na o ka rata hore re buisane le wena ka dintho tse o hlahetseng? O tla amohela vaotjhara ya datha ya mahala haeba ho ikopanngwa le wena bakeng sa puisano!

SourceText: Thank you so much! Here is a link to sign up!
text: Ke lebohile ho menahane! LInki eo o ka ingodisang ho yona ke ena!

SourceText: Hello! Did you know that 3 is a magical number? Breathe in to the count of three and breathe out to the count of three. How do you feel now? Do you feel any different?
text: Dumela! Na o ne o tseba hore 3 ke palo ya mohlolo? Hema ho hula moya ka makgetlo a mararo mme o heme ho lokolla moya ka mekgetlo a mararo. Jwale o ikutlwa jwang? Na ha o ikutlwe ka tsela e fapaneng?

SourceText: Here's an audio message to guide you through this activity!
text: Mamela molaetsa ona o tla o tataisa ha o etsa mosebetsi ona!

SourceText: What are your three favourite foods? Can you name three things you can see right now?
text: Mefuta e meraro ya dijo tseo o di ratang haholo ke efe? Na o ka bolela dintho tse tharo tseo o di bonang hona jwale?

SourceText: Can you hear three sounds you can hear right now?
text: Na o utlwa medumo e meraro eo o e utlwang hona jwale?

SourceText: What are the three things you are grateful for right now?
text: Ke dintho dife tse tharo tseo o di lebohelang hong jwale?

SourceText: Breathe in to the count of three and breathe out to the count of three. How do you feel now? Do you feel any different?
text: Hema ho hula moya ka makgetlo a mararo mme o heme ho lokolla moya ka mekgetlo a mararo. Jwale o ikutlwa jwang? Na ha o ikutlwe ka tsela e fapaneng?

SourceText: Three is a magical number!
text: Tharo ke palo ya mohlolo!

SourceText: Here's a video to guide through this activity!

SourceText: Here is a song made just for parents like you.
text: Pina ena e etseditswe batswadi ba kang wena.

SourceText: One-on-One Time with your children is free and fun. It makes children feel loved and secure, and shows them that they are important. It also increases their confidence and self-esteem!
text: Nako ya Boinotshing le bana ba hao ke mahala ebile e monate. E etsa hore bana ba ikutlwe ba ratwa ebile ba sireletsehile, mme e bontsha hore ke ba bohlokwa. Hape e eketsa boitshepo le seriti sa bona!

SourceText: Here are 6 tips to make One-on-One Time with your child a success:
text: Bona dikeletso tse 6 tsa ho etsa hore Nako ya Boinotshing le ngwana wa hao e atlehe:

SourceText: 1. Spend at least five minutes with each child
text: 1. Qeta bonyane metsotso e mehlano le ngwana ka mong

SourceText: 2. Give your child your full attention
text: 2. Tsepamisa maikutlo a hao ho ngwana wa hao ka ho feletseng

SourceText: 3. Let your child choose the activity
text: 3. Tlohella ngwana wa hao a kgethe ntho eo le ka e etsang

SourceText: 4. Follow your child's lead
text: 4. Latela ha ngwana wa hao a etella pele

SourceText: 5. Use words to describe what your child is doing
text: 5. Sebedisa mantswe ho hlalosa seo ngwana wa hao a se etsang

SourceText: 6. Have fun!
text: 6. Le je monate!

SourceText: Even 5 minutes a day of quality time makes a big difference. If you have more than one child, try to find time for each individual child. It can be at the same time each day so your children look forward to it.
text: Esita le metsotso e 5 ka letsatsi e le nako ya bohlokwa ya ngwana e etsa phapang e kgolo. Haeba o na le bana ba mmalwa, leka ho etsetsa ngwana ka mong nako ya hae. Ekaba ka nako e tshwanang letsatsi le letsatsi e le hore bana ba hao ba ka lebella nako eo.

SourceText: Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative.
text: Bana ba tlameha ho etsa dintho ka nako ya bona. Leka ho ba fa nako ya ho ithuta mme o be le mamello. Bapallang kantle le ho kopitsa seo a se etsang empa leka ho mo tlohela ebe yena ya qalang ntho eo a batlang ho e etsa.

SourceText: Choosing builds their self confidence. If they want to do something that isn’t okay, then this is a chance to talk with them about this.
text: Ho kgetha ho mo thusa ho ba le boitshepo. Haeba a batla ho etsa ntho e sa lokelang, jwale ke nako ya ho buisana le yena ka taba eo.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your child:
text: Ka kopo kgetha palo e nngwe haeba o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka ho qeta Nako ya Boinotshing le ngwana wa hao:

SourceText: Here is a comic about spending one-on-one time with your child! Try to follow your child's lead when spending time with them. It will help build self-confidence.
text: Ena ke tsela ya boswaswi ya ho qeta nako ya boinotshing le ngwana wa hao! Leka ho latela boetapele ba ngwana wa hao ha o qeta nako le yena. Seo se mo thusa ho ba le boitshepo.

SourceText: Parent: "I see you are playing quietly with the lego with concentration, Alex."
text: Motswadi: “Kea bona hore o kgona ho tsepamisa maikutlo ha o bapala ka ditene tsa ho bapala, Alex.”

SourceText: Parent: "Wow! You are building such a tall and strong wall with those legos."
text: Motswadi: “Kgele! O haha mohaho o molelele hakaakang le lebota le matla ka ditene tsena tsa ho bapala.”

SourceText: Child: "It is for cows."
text: Ngwana: “Ke lesaka la dikgomo.”

SourceText: Parent: "It will keep the cow safe!"
text: Motswadi: “Moo o tla be o sireleditse dikgomo tsa hao!”

SourceText: Child: "Now you can help me build a house for our family to sleep in!"
text: Ngwana: “Jwale o ka nthusa ho haha ntlo eo lelapa leso le tla robala ho yona!”

SourceText: Parent: "This house is going to keep our family warm and dry. You are such a good builder, Alex!"
text: Motswadi: “Lelapa la rona le tla futhumala ka tlung ena. O sehahi sa nnete, Alex!”

SourceText: Would you like some suggestions for activities to do with your child?
text: Na o ka thabela ditshisinyo tsa dintho tseo o ka di etsang le ngwana wa hao?

SourceText: Here's a video about spending one-on-one time with your child!
text: Shebella video ya ho qeta nako ya boinotshing le ngwana wa hao!

SourceText: Here's an audio message about spending one-on-one time with your child!
text: Mamela molaetsa ona wa ho qeta nako ya boinotshing le ngwana wa hao!

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" whenever you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your child. Chat to you later @fields.user_name!
text: O ska kgathatseha! Ka dinako tsohle o ka thaepa “Thuso” neng kapa neng ha o batla ho ithuta haholwanyane ka ho qeta Nako ya Boinotshing le ngwana wa hao: Ke tla bua le wena hamorao @fields.user_name!

SourceText: Make sure you will not be interrupted. Finish all your chores, switch off the TV and put your phone on silent. It will show your child, they are important.
text: Tiisa hore ha ho na ntho e tla o sitisa. Qeta mesebetsi yohle ya hao, tima TV mme o behe founo ya hao ho silent. Seo se tla bontsha ngwana wa hao, hore o bohlokwa.

SourceText: Ask @fields.child_nickname what they would like to do. You can say, "I have 5 minutes to spend One-on-One Time with you, what would you like to do?"
text: Botsa @fields.child_nickname hore na a ka thabela ho etsa eng. O ka re ho yena, “Ke na le metsotso e 5 eo ke tlo e qeta le wena e le Nako ya Boinotsing, o ka thabela ho etsa eng?”
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Ask your child what they would like to do. You can say, "I have 5 minutes to spend One-on-One Time with you, what would you like to do?"
text: Botsa botsa ngwana wa hao hore na a ka thabela ho etsa eng. O ka re ho yena, “Ke na le metsotso e 5 eo ke tlo e qeta le wena e le Nako ya Boinotsing, o ka thabela ho etsa eng?”

SourceText: If @fields.child_nickname cannot think of anything, you can give them a choice of a couple things that you know they like.
text: Haeba @fields.child_nickname a sa nahane ka eng eng kapa eng, o ka mo fa dintho tse mmalwa tseo a ka kgethang ho tsona tseo o tsebang hore o a di rata.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: If your child cannot think of anything, you can give them a choice of a couple things that you know they like.
text: Haeba ngwana wa hao a sa nahane ka eng eng kapa eng, o ka mo fa dintho tse mmalwa tseo a ka kgethang ho tsona tseo o tsebang hore o a di rata.

SourceText: Listening to @fields.child_nickname is more important than talking to them at this time. If you do talk you should describe what @fields.child_nickname is doing. Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening!

SourceText: One-on-One Time with your teen helps build a positive and trusting relationship. When you really notice them and listen to what they are saying and what they like, you make them feel valued and appreciated.
text: Ho qeta Nako ya Boinotshing le ngwana wa hao ho thusa ho haha dikamano tse ntle le ho tshepana. Haeba kannete o ba hlokomela le ho mamela seo ba se buang le ho rata seo ba se etsang, o etsa hore ba ikutlwe ba ratwa ebile ba ananelwa.

SourceText: Here are 6 tips on how to make One-on-One Time a positive experience for you and your teen:
text: Bona dikeletso tsena tse 6 tsa kamoo wena le motjha wa hao le ka qetang Nako ya Boinotshing hamonate.

SourceText: 2. Let your teen choose the activity

SourceText: Fathers can have difficult relationships with their teenagers, it can be hard to find pleasure from spending time with them. Instead, we spend a lot of time disciplining them or complaining about how they are behaving.

SourceText: Type "SOS" at any time if you would like the details of emergency services or other hotlines. Remember everything you say will be completely private!

SourceText: Quick tip: It can be difficult to know how to talk to your children about something like COVID-19, especially since we are learning about it too.
text: Keletso e kgutshwanyane ke ena: Ho ka ba thata ho tseba hore na o bue le bana ba hao jwang ka taba e kang COVID-19, haholoholo kaha le rona re ntse re ithuta ka yona.

SourceText: The important thing is to be open and listen to your children. Be honest and supportive. Show them that you care.
text: Ntho ya bohlokwa ke ho phetlela bana ba hao sefuba le ho ba mamela. Bua ka botshepehi mme o ba tshehetse Ba bontshe hore o a ba tsotella.

SourceText: Quick tip: It is really hard to help our children continue learning when schools are closed or part-open. One thing that might be helpful is to try and set up a daily schedule that includes time for schoolwork and time for fun.
text: Keletso e kgutshwanyane ke ena: Ho thata haholo ho thusa bana ba rona ho tswela pele ba ithuta dikolo di kwetswe kapa ho dula di bulwa le ho kwalwa. Ntho e nngwe e ka bang molemo ke ho leka ho hlophisa lenaneo la letsatsi le letsatsi le akarelletsang nako ya mosebetsi wa sekolo le nako ya ho ithabisa.

SourceText: Quick tip: Caring for yourself is really important. Take five deep breaths when you feel overwhelmed. Try talking to a friend, or doing something relaxing for yourself? You deserve it!
text: Keletso e kgutshwanyane ke ena: Ho bohlokwa haholo hore o itlhokomele. Phefumolohela hodimo ka makgetlo a mahlano ha o ikutlwa o imetswe. Leka ho buisana le motswalle, kapa ho etsa ntho e tla o thusa ho theola moya. O lokela ho phomola!

SourceText: Quick tip: All children, including those living with disabilities, need love, respect and time especially at difficult times.
text: Keletso e kgutshwanyane ke ena: Bana bohle, ho kopanyelletsa le ba holofetseng, ba hloka lerato, tlhompho le nako haholoholo dinakong tse thata.

SourceText: Quick tip: This is a stressful time for all of us. When a problem comes up, talk about it together! What is the problem exactly? What different solutions are there and what are the consequences of one? That way, you can find a solution that can be OK for everyone.
text: Keletso e kgutshwanyane ke ena: Ena ke nako e boima ho rona kaofela. Ha bothata bo hlaha, buisanang ka bona le kopane! Hantlentle bothata ke eng? Ho na le ditharollo dife tse sa tshwaneng hona tharollo ka nngwe e tla ba le ditlamorao dife? Ka tsela eo, le ka fumana tharollo e loketseng batho bohle.

SourceText: Quick tip: It is normal to be stressed about money. Talk to your children about how much money comes in and what you spend money on as a family each month. When everyone sees where the money goes, it is easier to agree on where you can save money together!
text: Keletso e kgutshwanyane ke ena: Ke ntho e tlwaelehileng ho kgathatseha ka tjhelete. Buisana le bana ba hao ka hore na le le lelapa le fumana tjhelete e kae le hore na le sebedisa tjhelete e kae kgwedi le kgwedi. Ha motho e mong le e mong a bona hore na tjhelete e ya hokae, ho bonolo ho dumellana hore na le ka baballa tjhelete hokae le le mmoho!

SourceText: Here's another tip! A daily stress-reducer can help us with parenting, and make us feel better.  Let’s start with 30 seconds of relaxation for yourself. You deserve this!
text: Keletso e nngwe ke ena! Ntho e re hafolelang seterese letsatsi le letsatsi e ka re thusa ka mosebetsi wa botswadi, mme ya etsa hore re ikutlwe re imolohile.  A re qale ka metsotswana e 30 ya ho phomotsa methapo ya hao. O lokela ho phomola!

SourceText: Would you like to receive this activity now?
text: Na o ka thabela ho amohela ntho ena eo o ka e etsang hona jwale?

SourceText: That's Ok! You can always type "Relax" whenever you want an activity to help you with stress.
text: O ska kgathatseha! Ka dinako tsohle o ka thaepa lentswe “Phomola” neng kapa neng ha o batla seo o ka se etsang ho o thusa ka seterese.

SourceText: Quick tip: All children misbehave. One thing that can help is to praise @fields.child_nickname anytime that they do something good – however small. They may not look like they want your praise but they still really, really do.

SourceText: Well done for Taking a Pause @fields.user_name! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Over the next few days, try taking a pause whenever you are feeling stressed. SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are finding this difficult. Next time, take a deep breath, take some space, and then pick something very small and concrete that you wish your child could do more of that you can praise in your child. You can do this!

SourceText: Keep up the great work! The more you involve your children in solving problems, the more they will learn how to do it on their own.
text: Pele ya pele ka mosebetsi o motle! Ha o kenyelletsa bana haholo tharollong ya mathata, ke moo ba tla ithuta le ho feta ho etsa jwalo ba le bang.

SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are finding this challenging. When we have a problem, we always want to get to the quickest end result and can forget about the steps. Really understanding the problem and the different solutions first helps to come up with the best solution together. You can do this!
text: Ke maswabi ho utlwa hore o fumana sena se le thata. Ha re na le mathata, kamehla re batla ho fumana tharollo ya kapele ka potlako mme re ka lebala ka mehato eo re tlamehang ho e nka. Ho qala ka ho utlwisisa bothata hantle le ditharollo tse sa tshwaneng ho ka le thusa ho tla ka tharollo e molemo ka ho fetisisa mmoho. O ka atleha!

SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are finding this challenging. Sometimes it can be difficult to agree with everyone in the family, especially if not everyone is calm yet. You could agree to try one first, then the other. Or If you get stuck, try to get together later  to agree on the solution together. You can do this!
text: Ke maswabi ho utlwa hore o fumana sena se le thata. Ka dinako tse ding ho ka ba thata ho dumellana le batho bohle lapeng, haholo haeba ese batho bohle ba theotseng moya. Le ka nna la dumellana ka hore le leke tharollo e nngwe pele, ebe le leka e latelang. Kapa haeba le hloleha, lekang ho kopana hape hamorao hore le dumellane ka tharollo mmoho. O ka atleha!

SourceText: It can be hard to find time during your day, with work, chores, and everything else. Can you think of even 30 minutes this week to do this activity? It will make a big difference in keeping your child safe and building a trusting relationship between you. You can do it!
text: Ho ka ba thata ho fumana nako motshehare, ka mosebetsi, mesebetsi ya lelapa le dintho tsohle tseo re tlamehang ho di etsa. Na o nahana hore o ka fumana esita le metsotso e 30 bekeng ena hore o etse mosebetsi ona? Ho tla tabeng ya ho tiisa hore ngwana wa hao o sireletsehile le ho haha dikamano tsa ho tshepana pakeng tsa lona. O ka atleha!

SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are finding this challenging. Creating new and healthy habits like device-free space and time in your house (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping) is a learning process. Try slowly introducing  device-free times, and build up from there. Change takes time, you can do this!
text: Ke maswabi ho utlwa hore o fumana sena se le thata. Ho qala mekgwa e metjha le e metle jwaloka nako ya ho beha disebediswa tsa elektronike fatshe le nako ya ho ba ka tlung (ya ho ja, ho bapala, ho etsa mosebetsi wa sekolo le ho robala) ke tsela ya ho ithuta. Butlebutle qalang dinako tsa ho beha disebediswa tsa elektronike fatshe, mme le ntlafatse ho tloha moo. Phetoho e nka nako, empa o ka atleha ho etsa sena!

SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are finding this challenging. If you think your child is accessing information online which is not age appropriate discuss with them why you have concerns, and why you are not comfortable. Try having your child involved in the conversation and get them to share their views. Having an open conversation is important, and children are more likely to stick to decisions if they feel that they are fair and their opinions have been heard.
text: Ke maswabi ho utlwa hore o fumana sena se le thata. SourceText: Well done @fields.user_name! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Spend some time creating a map with your child or teen that identifies the safe and unsafe places in your community. It will build trust and help keep them safe in the future.

SourceText: When we are reminded of such situations, it is normal to feel upset or angry . It is important to find a time when you are calm, so you can think of what support you need: You may need to talk to someone.
text: Ha re hopotswa ka maemo a jwalo, ho tlwaelehile hore motho a ikutlwe a kwatile kapa a halefile. Ho bohlokwa ho fumana nako ha o kgutsitse, hore ka nahana ka hore na o hloka tshehetso ya mofuta ofe: Mohlomong o tlameha ho buisana le motho e mong.

SourceText: It is completely normal to experience this challenge, this is difficult stuff to talk about. Find a calm time. You can say that we hope these things never happen, but it’s like getting insurance – it's best to think about them and be prepared.
text: Ke ntho e tlwaelehileng ka ho feletseng ho tobana le bothata bona, ho ka ba thata hobua ka taba ena. Fumana nako eo ho kgutsitseng. O ka nna wa re re tshepa hore dintho tsena di ke ke tsa etsahala, empa ho tshwana le ho fumana inshorense – ho molemo ho nahana ka yona le ho dula o itokisitse.

SourceText: That is a completely normal experience, it is shocking to learn that people who are close to us and who we trust may be a danger to our children. Find someone you can talk to about this, perhaps a friend or support service, so you can get the support your need. Remember to take a pause when you are stressed.
text: Bona ke boemo boo batho ba tlwaetseng ho kopana le bona, ebile ho a tshosa ho tseba hore batho ba haufi le rona le bao re ba tshepang ba ka ba kotsi baneng ba rona. Fumane motho eo o ka buisanang le yena ka taba ena, mohlomong motswalle kapa ba ditshebeletso tse tshehetso, hore o fumane tshehetso eo o e hlokang. Hopola hore o nke kgefu ha o imetswe.

SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are finding this challenging. Our children may know things about our communities and technology that we are not aware of. When we actively involve our children in the mapping activity, they feel heard and valued, and it can be easier to come up with a plan that everyone agrees on.
text: Ke maswabi ho utlwa hore o fumana sena se le thata. Bana ba rona ba ka nna ba tseba dintho tse itseng tse amanang le metse ya habo rona le theknoloji tseo re sa di tsebeng. Ha re kenyelletsa bana ba rona ka sehlahlo mosebetsing wa ho etsa dimmapa, ba tla utlwa hore ho na le motho ya ba mamelang le ya ba nkang e le ba bohlokwa, mme ho ka ba bonolo ho tla ka moralo oo bohle ba ka dumellanang le wona.

SourceText: It is difficult to know every detail about our communities. Involve another family member or friend in your mapping activity. You can even visit some of the services available and ask what they do. The more we know, the better we can keep our families safe!

SourceText: It is completely normal to experience this. Try creating a safe space to talk with @fields.child_nickname when you are both calm. SourceText: 1. Close your eyes.
text: 1. Kwala mahlo.

SourceText: 2. Take a deep breath in and let it go.
text: 2. Phefumulohela hodimo mme o tlohele bohale.

SourceText: 3. Notice how you feel.
text: 3. Hlokomela tsela eo o ikutlwang ka yona.

SourceText: 4. Listen to your breath as it goes in and out.

SourceText: 5. When you are ready open your eyes again.

SourceText: If you find yourself always having to give consequences to your children for behaving badly, you might need to spend more positive time with them. It will help them feel more loved and secure...and you less stressed!

SourceText: We all make mistakes! The more consistent we are with our consequences, the more likely our children will choose to behave positively in the future.

SourceText: Sometimes, our children can have very violent tantrums when they do not get their way, especially if they are used to it. Try to move your child to a place where they will not hurt themselves or others. You may need to firmly hold your child while ignoring their behaviour - but only do this if you can remain calm and make sure you are not hurting them! Eventually, your child will calm down.
text: Ka dinako tse ding bana ba ithabukanya ba le mabifi ha dintho di sa etswe kamoo ba ratang kateng, haholoholo haeba ba tlwaetse jwalo. O ka nna wa tlameha ho tshwara ngwana wa hao ka thata o ntse o iphapanyetsa boitshwaro ba hae - empa o etse sena feela haeba o ka kgona ho dula o kgobile matshwafo le ho tiisa hore ha a itematse! SourceText: It is completely normal to feel uncomfortable, confused, or even scared. Everyone feels this way at times. The WHO and UNICEF and websites and local COVID-19 hotlines are great places to find advice on how you and your family can stay safe during COVID-19.
text: Ka sebele ke ntho e tlwaelehileng ho ikutlwa o sa phutholoha, o ferekane kapa o tshohile. Ka dinako tse ding kaofela re ikutlwa jwalo. Diwebosaete tsa WHO le UNICEF hammoho le mehala ya haeno ya COVID-19 e ka ba mehlodi e metle ya dikeletso tsa kamoo wena le lelapa la hao le ka ipaballang kateng nakong ya COVID-19.

SourceText: It is completely normal for children to act out or react negatively during these unprecedented times. Give them space to share how they are feeling and let them know you are there for them. You can also try distracting them with fun activities and games.
text: Ke ntho e tlwaelehileng haholo hore ba itshware ka tsela e fosahetseng dinakong tsena tseo ho seng tse kileng tsa tshwana le tsona. Mo fe monyetla wa ho ntsha maikutlo a hae mme o mo kgodise hore o tla wa o tsoha le yena. Hape o ka leka ho ba kgutlisa ka dintho tsa boithabiso le ka dipapadi.

SourceText: Hi! Every child has challenging behaviour sometimes. Would you like some tips on how to address these behaviours?
text: Dumela! Ngwana e mong le e mong o na le boitshwaro bo thatafatsang dintho ka dinako tse ding. Na o ka thabela dikeletso tsa kamoo o ka sebetsanang le boitshwaro boo?

SourceText: That is okay! You can always access parenting tips by typing "Help".
text: Ho lokile! O ka fihlella dikeletso tsa botswadi ka ho thaepa “Thuso”.

SourceText: Remember that One-on-One time, praise for being good, and consistent routines will also help reduce difficult behaviours.
text: Hopola hore Nako ya Boinotsing, ho babatsa ketso e ntle, le mananeo a sa fetofetoheng di tla thusa ho fokotsa boitshwaro bo jwalo bo thatafatsang dintho.

SourceText: Hi @fields.user_name! How are you feeling?
text: Dumela @fields.user_name! O ikutlwa jwang?
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: Hi! How are you feeling?
text: Dumela! O ikutlwa jwang?

SourceText: Lovely! Take a breath just to appreciate the moment.
text: Ke ditaba tse monate! Kga moya ho ananela nako ena.

SourceText: Marvellous! When you feel good, it is easier to keep it positive throughout the day.
text: Hase moo! Ha o ikutlwa hantle, ho bonolo hore o dule o nahana dintho tse ntle letsatsi lohle.

SourceText: Everyone has challenging days, but you do not need experience it alone. Try reaching out to family and friends for support.
text: Empa kaofela re na le matsatsi a boima, empa ha ho hlokahale hore o tobane le wona o le mong. Leka ho kopa hore ba lelapa le metswalle ba o tshehetse.

SourceText: It is completely normal to feel okay. You do not need to feel great everyday.
text: Ka sebele ke ntho e tlwaelehileng ho ikutlwa hantle. Ha ho hlokahale hore o ikutlwe o thabile ka matsatsi wohle.

SourceText: Life is filled with ups and downs. It is important to recognise and accept how are you feeling. Please remember to be kind to yourself.
text: Bophelo bo na le mathata le menate ya bona. Ho bohlokwa ho elellwa le ho amohela kamoo o ikutlwang kateng. Hopola hle hore o inahanele.

SourceText: Thank you for sharing! All feelings, whether they are good, bad, or okay are welcome here.
text: Rea leboha hore o re phetele taba eo! Maikutlo wohle, ho sa natswe hore na o ikutlwa hantle, hampe, kapa ho itoketse feela, a amohelehile mona.

SourceText: We are made to feel different emotions, and learning to identify them is a great skill. Good job! You know we are here to support you.
text: Re etseditswe hore re utlwe maikutlo a sa tshwaneng, ebile ho ithuta ho a lemoha ke tsebo ya bohlokwa. O sebeditse! O a tseba hore re teng ho o tshehetsa.

SourceText: Thank you for sharing how you are feeling today. If you would like, try this relaxation activity that can help recenter and ground your emotions.
text: Rea leboha ka hore o re bolelle kamoo o ikutlwang kateng kajeno. Haeba o ka thabela, leka ho etsa ntho ena e ka o kgathollang e ka o thusang ho laola le ho tsitsisa maikutlo a hao.

SourceText: Thank you for sharing how you are feeling. Is there anything someone can do to help you feeling better? If so, try reaching out to them, a support system is so important.
text: Rea leboha ka hore o re bolelle kamoo o ikutlwang kateng. Na ho na le eng kapa eng eo motho e mong a ka e etsang ho o thusa hore o ikutlwe habetere? Haeba ho jwalo, leka ho buisana le yena, ho bohlokwa haholo ho ba le batho ba o tshehetsang.

SourceText: We have all experienced difficult days, but remember its important to experience all emotions. Try to do something that can help you feel better, like going for a walk or talking to someone you care about.
text: Kaofela ha rona re ba le matsatsi a thata, empa hopola ho bohlokwa ho ba le maikutlo wohle. Leka ho etsa ho hong ho ka o thusang hore o ikutlwe betere, jwaloka ho thapolla maoto o tsamaya kapa ho bua le motho eo o mo tsotellang.

SourceText: That is excellent news. When you feel good, your family around you also feels good!
text: Tseo ke ditaba tse monate ruri. Ha o ikutlwa o thabile, lelapa la hao le lona le ikutlwa le thabile!

SourceText: We all experience days where we just feel fine, and that is completely okay!
text: Kaofela re na le matsatsi ao re utlwang hore dintho di lokile feela, le ao kannete dintho di re tsamaelang hantle!

SourceText: You should not feel pressured to feel happy and great all the time. All feelings are valid and healthy!
text: O se ke wa iqobella ho ikutlwa o thabile o bile o nyakalletse ka dinako tsohle. Maikutlo wohle a lokile ebile a thusa motho ho phela hantle!

SourceText: Feeling okay is perfectly normal. Try asking how your family members are feeling today. This can help everyone to understand each other better.
text: Ho ikutlwa hantle feela ke boikutlo bo tlwaelehileng haholo. Leka ho botsa ba lelapa la hao hore na ba ikutlwa jwang kajeno. Sena se thusa bohle hore ba utlwisisane hantle.

SourceText: Part of keeping healthy is allowing yourself to feel all your emotions: the good, the bad, and the ones in the middle.
text: Ntho e nngwe e tla etsa hore o dule o phetse hantle ke ho itumella ho ikutlwa ka ditsela tsohle: hamonate, hampe, le ho ikutlwa o le mahareng feela.

SourceText: There are days when we just go with the flow and it is completely perfect.
text: Ho na le matsatsi ao re yang moo moya o fokelang teng mme le hona moo ho lokile.

SourceText: It is completely normal to not feel great all the time. Parents all around the world have felt how you are feeling right now, and it is okay! You are doing great!
text: Ke ntho e tlwaelehileng ka ho feletseng ho se ikutlwe o thabile ka dinako tsohle. Batswadi lefatsheng lohle ba kile ba ikutlwa kamoo o ikutlwang kateng hona jwale, mme ho lokile! O etsa hantle haholo!

SourceText: Just like everyone else, you are allowed to have days where they are not feeling great. Be gentle and patient with yourself. Tomorrow is a new day!
text: Jwaloka batho bohle, o dumelletswe ho ba le matsatsi ao ho wona o sa ikutlweng o thabile. Iqenehele mme o imamelle. Matsatsi a tjhaba ka ho fapana!

SourceText: Having a bad day is not a reflection of your abilities or of you as a parent. Just showing up shows you care.
text: Ho se be le letsatsi le monate ha ho bontshe bokgoni ba hao kapa ha ho amane le wena jwaloka motswadi. Ho hlahella feela ho bontsha hore o a tsotella.

SourceText: We all have difficult days that make us feel upset. Remember to be kind to yourself and others during these days. How you are feeling is not a representation of your abilities!
text: Kaofela re hlahelwa ke matsatsi a boima a etsang hore re ikutlwe re sa thaba. O hopole ho inahanela le ho nahanela ba bang matsatsing ana. Tsela eo o ikutlwang ka yona ha e bontshe bokgoni ba hao!

SourceText: We all have bad days, and we know it can sometimes be difficult to deal with your emotions. Learning how to cope with them in a posiitve way, sets you aside from others. If you have a few minutes to spare, use them to take care of yourself and focus on your breathing. Take this time to reflect on your feelings and try and redirect these emotions into something positive.
text: Kaofela re ba le matsatsi a seng monate, mme rea tseba hore ka dinako tse ding ho ka ba thata ho sebetsana le maikutlo a hao. Ho ithuta ho sebetsana le wona ka tsela e molemo, ho o kgetholla ho batho ba bang. Haeba o na le metsotso e seng mekae ka thoko, e sebedisetse ho itlhokomela le ho ameha ka tsela eo o hemang ka yona. Nka nako ena ho nahana ka tsela eo o ikutlwang ka yona mme o leke le ho kgutlisetsa maikutlo ana tseleng ka ntho e nngwe e molemo.

SourceText: Learning to identify and accept your emotions will allow you to build a stronger relationship with yourself, your family and your community. Well done!
text: Ho ithuta ho lemoha le ho amohela maikutlo a hao ho tla o fa monyetla wa ho haha kamano e matla le wena, le lelapa la hao le batho motseng. Mosebetsi o tswileng matsoho!

SourceText: Here is a short relaxation activity for you:
text: Ena ke ntho e kgutshwane eo o ka e etsang hore o phutholohe:

SourceText: Do you ever feel something so strongly that you want to run away from it? Here's a short activity that might help!
text: Na o kile wa utlwa o tshaba ntho e itseng haholo hoo o batlang ho e baleha? Ena ke ntho e kgutshwane eo o ka e etsang e ka nnang ya o thusa!

SourceText: This activity uses the magic power of three breaths to stay connected and relaxed.
text: Ketso ena e sebedisa matla a mohlolo a ho hema hararo hore o dule o ikutlwa e le wena ebile o phutholohile.

SourceText: Here's an activity to relax your body:
text: Ena ke ketso e ka etsang hore mmele wa hao o phutholohe:

SourceText: Here is a quick relaxation activity...
text: O ka etsa sena ka potlako hore o ikutlwe o phutholohile...

SourceText: How many sounds can you hear? Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers.
text: O utlwa medumo e mekae? Mamela medumo e ka hara kamore le e kantle. E bale ka menwana ya hao ya letsoho.

SourceText: Try again for another ten seconds. Did you hear any new sounds? Did you hear any sounds inside your own body? Notice how you feel now.
text: Leka hape ka metsotswana e meng e leshome. Na ho na le medumo efe kapa efe e metjha eo o e utlwileng? Na ho na le medumo efe kapa efe eo o e utlwileng kahara mmele wa hao? Elellwa tsela eo o ikutlwang ka yona hona jwale.

SourceText: Breathe in to the count of three.
text: Hula moya ka makgetlo a mararo.

SourceText: Instead of moving away from the feeling, let’s move towards it for a moment.
text: Ho fapana le ho furalla boikutlo boo, a re lebeng ho bona ka nakwana.

SourceText: It’s ok. Close your eyes if you feel comfortable. Take a deep breath.
text: Ho lokile. Kwala mahlo haeba o ikutlwa o phutholohile. Phefumulohela hodimo.

SourceText: Become curious. Where are you feeling it in your body? Is it hot or cold? Hard or soft? Tight or loose?
text: Eba le takatso ya ho tseba dintho. Ke hokae mmeleng wa hao moo o utlwang boikutlo boo? Na ho a tjhesa kapa ho a bata? Ho thata kapa ho bonolo? Ho tiile kapa ho hlephile?

SourceText: Ask yourself some questions. What is it telling me? What does it need? How can I be kind to myself in this moment?
text: Ipotse dipotso tse itseng. Bo mpolella eng? Bo hloka eng? Nka inahanela jwang hona jwale?

SourceText: If your mind starts to wander, it’s normal. Just bring it back to the feeling. Keep breathing and feeling.
text: Haeba kelello ya hao e qala ho feresa, ke ntho e tlwaelehileng. E kgutlisetse boikutlong bona. O nne o heme le ho ikutlwa.

SourceText: Reassure yourself. It’s ok to feel. Feeling is healing!
text: Ikgodise. Ha ho na phoso ka ho ikutlwa. Boikutlo ke pheko!

SourceText: Notice your connection with the ground beneath you.
text: Elellwa kamano pakeng tsa hao le lefatshe le tlasa hao.

SourceText: What parts of your body touch the ground? What parts of your body don’t?
text: Ke ditho dife tsa mmele wa hao tse thetsitseng lefatshe? Ke dikarolo dife tsa mmele wa hao tse sa thetseng lefatshe?

SourceText: Notice where it feels warm and where it feels cool.
text: Lemoha hore na ke hokae moo o ikutlwang o futhumetse le hore na ke hokae moo o ikutlwang o phodile.

SourceText: Feel the ground underneath you supporting you. Let your body sink into the support of the ground.
text: Utlwa ha lefatshe le tlasa hao le o thehetsa. Dumella mmele wa hao hore o monngwe ke tshehetso ya lefatshe.

SourceText: Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
text: Hula moya ka makgetlo a mararo. 1, 2, 3.

SourceText: Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
text: Lokolla moya ka makgetlo a mararo. 1, 2, 3.

SourceText: Sit comfortably and close your eyes if you can.
text: Dula o phutholohile mme o kwale mahlo haeba o ka kgona.

SourceText: Imagine a golden ring scanning your body from your feet to your head.
text: Nahana ka reng ya kgauta e sekenang mmele wa hao ho tloha maotong ho ya hloohong.

SourceText: Pay attention as it moves up and down your body. Are there any areas that feel tense? Numb? Painful?
text: Elellwa ha e nyoloha le ha e theoha mmele wa hao. Na ho na le dikarolo dife kapa dife tseo o di utlwang di tsitsipane? Di shwele bohatsu? Di le bohloko?

SourceText: Focus on those areas for a moment. Breathe in to the area and when you breathe out, try to let go of any tension or pain.
text: Ameha ka dibaka tseo ka nakwana. Hema ho hula moya sebakeng seo mme ha o lokolla moya, leka ho tlohela ho tsitsipana le bohloko bofe kapa bofe.

SourceText: Do this for a few breaths.
text: Etsa sena ka ho hema ka makgetlo a mmalwa.

SourceText: Open your eyes. How does your body feel now?
text: Bula mahlo. Mmele wa hao o ikutlwa jwang hona jwale?

SourceText: Try this next time you find yourself lying in bed unable to sleep!
text: Leka sena nakong e tlang ha o iphumana o paqame betheng mme o hlobaela!

SourceText: Listen to the sounds.
text: Mamela medumo.

SourceText: Connection with the ground.
text: Kamano le lefatshe.

SourceText: Notice how you feel now.
text: Elellwa tsela eo o ikutlwang ka yona hona jwale.

SourceText: How do you feel now? Do you feel any different? Deep breathing helps our whole body and mind to calm down.
text: Jwale o ikutlwa jwang? Na ha o ikutlwe ka tsela e fapaneng? Ho hemela hodimo ho thusa mmele wohle le kelello ho kgutsa.

SourceText: Dealing with difficult feelings.
text: Ho sebetsana le maikutlo a thata.

SourceText: Body relaxation.
text: Ho etsa hore mmele o phutholohe.

SourceText: It’s ok to feel. Feeling is healing!
text: Ha ho na phoso ka ho ikutlwa. Boikutlo ke pheko!

SourceText: Let’s use the magic power of three to stay present and relax. At the end of a tough day, thinking of three things to be grateful for can help us find the courage to try again tomorrow.
text: A re sebedise matla a mohlolo a tharo ho dula e le wena le ho kgoba matshwafo. Qetellong ya letsatsi le boima, ho nahana ka dintho tse tharo tseo o di ananelang ho re thusa ho ba sebete hore re leke hape hosane.

SourceText: Here's a short relaxation activity to end the day:
text: Ena ke ntho e kgutshwane eo o ka e etsang qetellong ya letsatsi:

SourceText: Let's take a moment to stop what you are doing and connect with your breath.
text: Nka motsotswana hore o emise seo o ntseng o se etsa mme o be le kamano le phefumuloho ya hao.

SourceText: What is one thing you can be grateful for right now?
text: Ke ntho efe e le nngwe eo hona jwale o e lebohelang?

SourceText: What is one thing that brings you happiness?
text: Ke ntho efe e le nngwe e o tlisetsang thabo?

SourceText: What is one thing that you love?
text: Ke ntho efe e le nngwe eo o e ratang?

SourceText: They don't have to be big. Sometimes the small things in life count the most!
text: Hase setlamo hore ebe dintho tse kgolo. Ka dinako tse ding dintho tse nyane bophelo ke tsa bohlokwa haholo!

SourceText: At the end of the day, take a minute to think about the day.
text: Ha letsatsi le dikela, qeta motsotso o nahana ka letsatsi leo.

SourceText: Think about one positive or fun thing you did.
text: Nahana ka ntho e le nngwe e molemo kapa e thabisang eo o e entseng.

SourceText: Think of one thing you can do differently tomorrow.
text: Nahana ka ntho e le nngwe eo o ka e etsang ka tsela e fapaneng hosane.

SourceText: Think of one thing that you are grateful for.
text: Nahana ka ntho e le nngwe eo o e ananelang.

SourceText: Do you sometimes feel like you are getting everything wrong?  Here's a short activity that might help!
text: Na ka dinako tse ding o utlwa eka ntho e nngwe le e nngwe eo o e tshwarang e a senyeha?  Ena ke ntho e kgutshwane eo o ka e etsang e ka nnang ya o thusa!

SourceText: The magic power of three.
text: Matla a mohlolo a tharo.

SourceText: Close your eyes and think about the day. Name 1 thing that you are grateful for. Name 1 thing that you did well. Name 1 think that you love. You earned a goodnight of sleep!
text: Kwala mahlo mme o nahane ka letsatsi leo. Bolela ntho e 1 eo o e ananelang. Bolela ntho e 1 eo o e entseng hantle. Bolela ntho e 1 eo o e ratang. O tshwanelwa ke ho phomola hamonate bosiu!

SourceText: Take a moment to think over the day. Think of one thing you did today that you are proud of.
text: Nka motsotswana hore o nahane ka letsatsi leo. Nahana ka ntho e le nngwe eo o e entseng kajeno eo o leng motlotlo ka yona.

SourceText: Wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug.
text: Aparela mmele wa hao ka matsoho a hao mme o iphe hak.

SourceText: Think of one thing you did today that you don’t feel proud of. What can you do differently tomorrow?
text: Nahana ka ntho e le nngwe eo o e entseng kajeno eo o seng motlotlo ka yona. O ka etsa eng ka tsela e fapaneng hosane?

SourceText: And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug.
text: Ebe o aparela mmele wa hao ka matsoho a hao mme o iphe hak.

SourceText: Connect with your breath.
text: O be le kamano le phefumuloho ya hao.

SourceText: Take a minute to think about the day.
text: Qeta motsotso o nahana ka tsa letsatsi leo.

SourceText: End of the day.
text: Ha letsatsi le dikela.

SourceText: Be kind to yourself.
text: Inahanela.

SourceText: You earned a goodnight of sleep!
text: O tshwanelwa ke ho phomola hamonate bosiu!

SourceText: It’s ok. You are doing your best so be kind to yourself. Get some rest and try again tomorrow!
text: Ho lokile. O etsa sohle se matleng a hao kahoo inahanele. Phomola mme o leke hape hosane!

SourceText: Do your children ever make you feel like screaming? Give yourself a 10-second pause.
text: Na bana ba hao ba ye ba etse hore o utlwe eka o ka ba tjwedietsa? Iphe metsotswana e 10 o nkile kgefu.

SourceText: Have you only got 30 seconds? Let's take a quick pause together. It might be helpful.
text: Na o na le metsotswana e 30 feela? A re kgefutse hakgutshwane hammoho. Seo se ka ba molemo.

SourceText: Do you sometimes feel your feelings are too much?
text: Na ka dinako tse ding o utlwa eka maikutlo a hao a boima haholo?

SourceText: Talk to someone.
text: Bua le motho e mong.

SourceText: Talk to someone you trust. Talk to a friend. Talk to family. Talk to a plant.
text: Bua le motho e mong eo o mo tshepang. Bua le motswalle. Bua le ba lelapa. Bua le semela.

SourceText: Get your worries off your chest and then let them go. Even if it’s just for a moment.
text: Bulela motho e mong sefuba mme dintho tse o kgathatsang di tla tswa. Le haeba etlaba ka nako e kgutshwane.

SourceText: How do you feel now?
text: Jwale o ikutlwa jwang?

SourceText: A joy shared is twice the joy. A problem shared is half the problem.
text: Thabo e abelanweng ke thabo e imenneng habedi. Bothata bo arolelwanweng ke halofo ya bothata.

SourceText: Here is something fun to help you let go of stress:
text: Ena ke ntho e monate e ka o thusang hore o tlohele seterese se ikele:

SourceText: Sit down, close your eyes and listen to your breath as it goes in and out. Notice how you feel. When you are ready open your eyes again.
text: Dula fatshe, o kwale mahlo mme o mamele phefumuloho ya hao ha moya o kena le ha o tswa. Hlokomela tsela eo o ikutlwang ka yona. Ha o se o lokile bula mahlo hape.

SourceText: Breath in and out slowly 5 times. Then try responding in a calmer way.
text: Hema butle ha o hula moya le ha o o ntsha ka makgetlo a 5. Ebe o leka ho arabela o kgobile matshwafo le ho feta.

SourceText: Choose a song that reflects what you need in this moment. Do you need a gentle song to soothe your tired soul or an upbeat song to help you shake some stress out?
text: Kgetha pina e bontshang seo o se hlokang hona jwale. Na o hloka pina e iphotlileng e thobang moya ha o kgathetse kapa pina e morethetho o matla ho o thusa ho sisinya seterese se tswe?

SourceText: Make a space and move your body to the music. Remember to breathe while you move. Let your breath and the movement go together.
text: Bula sebaka mme o tantshetse mmino oo ka mmele wohle. Hopola ho hema ha o ntse o tsamaya. Etsa hore mohemo le motsamao wa hao di tsamaye mmoho.

SourceText: Even a few minutes of movement can be enough to release stress and lift your mood!
text: Esita le ho tsamaya ka metsotso e se mekae ekaba ho lekaneng ho fokotsa seterese le ho o tsosa morolo!

SourceText: Choose a song that reflects what you need.
text: Kgetha pina e bontshang seo o se hlokang.

SourceText: Five deep breaths.
text: Hemela hodimo ka makgetlo a mahlano.

SourceText: Listen to your breath.
text: Imanele ha o hema.

SourceText: When feelings are too much.
text: Ha maikutlo a hao a o imela.

SourceText: Millions of parents say this helps - A LOT.
text: Batswadi ba dimilione ba re seo se a thusa - HAHOLO.

SourceText: Try this whenever you are feeling stressed and you need a break to reconnect.
text: Leka sena neng kapa neng ha o ikutlwa o imetswe mme o hloka ho nka kgefu hore o iphumane.

SourceText: That's wonderful! We are happy to hear that you are feeling good.
text: Tseo ke ditaba tse monate ruri! Re thabela ho utlwa hore o ikutlwa hamonate.

SourceText: That's wonderful! I am happy to hear that you are feeling good.
text: Tseo ke ditaba tse monate ruri! Ke thabela ho utlwa hore o ikutlwa hamonate.

SourceText: We are sorry to hear that you are not feeling great today. Remember to take it one day at the time. Tomorrow is a new day.
text: Re maswabi ho utlwa hore ha o ikutlwe hantle kajeno. Hopola ho nka letsatsi ka leng ka nako. Matsatsi a tjhaba ka ho fapana.

SourceText: I am sorry to hear that you are not feeling great today. Remember to take it one day at the time. Tomorrow is a new day.
text: Ke maswabi ho utlwa hore ha o ikutlwe hantle kajeno. Hopola ho nka letsatsi ka leng ka nako. Matsatsi a tjhaba ka ho fapana.

SourceText: Hooray! We are delighted to hear that you are doing well.
text: Mahofi! Re thabela ho utlwa hore o ya hantle.

SourceText: Hooray! I am delighted to hear that you are doing well.
text: Mahofi! Ke thabela ho utlwa hore o ya hantle.

SourceText: Fabulous! We are so happy to hear this.
text: Ditaba tse monate! Re habile haholo ho utlwa seo.

SourceText: Fabulous! I am so happy to hear this.
text: Ditaba tse monate! Ke habile haholo ho utlwa seo.

SourceText: What a great feeling! We hope that good feeling continues throughout the entire day.
text: Ha ho na ho hlasimoloha ho fetang hoo! Re lakatsa eka boikutlo boo bo monate bo ka tswela pele letsatsi lohle.

SourceText: What a great feeling! I hope that good feeling continues throughout the entire day.
text: Ha ho na ho hlasimoloha ho fetang hoo! Ke lakatsa eka boikutlo boo bo monate bo ka tswela pele letsatsi lohle.

SourceText: We are glad to hear this! We are sure your family is happy to see you this way as well.
text: Re thabetse ho utlwa seo! Re kgodisehile hore lelapa la hao le lona le thabile ho o bona ka tsela ena.

SourceText: I am glad to hear this! I am sure your family is happy to see you this way as well.
text: Ke thabetse ho utlwa seo. Ke kgodisehile hore lelapa la hao le lona le thabile ho o bona ka tsela ena.

SourceText: What fantastic news! We hope you continue to feel good throughout the day.
text: Ke ditaba tse nyakallisang tseo! Re lakatsa eka o ka tswela pele o thabile letsatsi lohle.

SourceText: What fantastic news! I hope you continue to feel good throughout the day.
text: Ke ditaba tse nyakallisang tseo! Ke lakatsa eka o ka tswela pele o thabile letsatsi lohle.

SourceText: It makes us very happy to hear that you are feeling good! Take that good energy and share it with others!
text: Ho re thabisa haholo ho utlwa hore o ikutlwa hamonate! Abelana le batho ba bang mahlahahlaha ao!

SourceText: It makes me very happy to hear that you are feeling good! Take that good energy and share it with others!
text: Ho nthabisa haholo ho utlwa hore o ikutlwa hamonate! Abelana le batho ba bang mahlahahlaha ao!
